PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General share the view that Senator Withers expressed on radio this morning that the problem in the Attorney-General's Department is just sheer incompetence? If that is so and if his Department is so incompetent, is there any reason why he should delay his resignation as suggested this morning by the major newspapers of this country?

—As I pointed out in the debate in the Senate yesterday, the findings of Mr Costigan are, of course, matters which are of grave concern. There is obviously need for action to be taken in relation to the matters. That action has been taken and very positive action is contemplated. As I have said, the President of the Law Council of Australia or someone nominated by him is going to undertake an examination, in the first place, of the Perth office and have regard to the professional competence and the quality of work in that office, the supervision of it from Canberra, and the diligence with which client departments have followed up their instructions.
—We know all that.

—No, we do not know all that, because it deals with a specific matter, a specific file. We want to get some independent professional judgment about the performance of the office as a whole and the supervision of it from Canberra. It may well be that we will follow that up, depending on what arises from that, with further investigation.
—With your resignation?

—No. I will come to that in a minute. There are serious questions , obviously, about the competence of some areas of the Department. I did not hear Senator Withers. I have had only a quick look at the transcript. My reaction is that he has spoken in very general terms which are not justified about the Department as a whole on what we know simply from the investigation of the handling of a particular case to which Mr Costigan's inquiry was confined.
—What about the other offices right around Australia?

—I have said that we will first look at the Perth office and the supervision of that Perth office by the central office. So, the central office will be looked at for the quality of its supervision. As I have said, that will be done in the first place. I am certainly keeping an open mind as to whether that course of action will be pursued in relation to other offices.
—There is the other small matter of the escort agency.

—I point out to Senator Chipp that on the evidence we have at this stage the officer concerned with that was not dealing with the particular file that was the subject of Mr Costigan's inquiry. He has been suspended and his future is now being examined under the Public Service Act. I do not think, from some comments that I have read and heard during this debate, that people appreciate that Ministers cannot just take action. Senator Chipp has been a Minister and would know that there is a Public Service Act which lays down the procedures to be followed, the rights of public servants and what charges and so on should be laid. Those are the steps that the Government has taken. As I have said, clearly what is called for when a matter of this kind is revealed is prompt, firm and effective action. I believe that that is being taken by me with the support of the Government and that, really, I and the Government would be judged on what we do and how we carry out the steps that we have now said we will take. In those circumstances, I again reject the suggestion in the question that I should resign.
—Which one of those crooks stood over you before your preselection ?
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that remark, in which there were implications of dishonesty on the part of the Attorney-General.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to Australia's overseas aid commitment and to Mr Somare's visit yesterday to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, in Canberra. Is it true that this year Australia is providing a 10 per cent increase or an additional $72m in overseas aid, principally to neighbouring countries in our region of South East Asia and the Pacific? Is it also true that the country that is receiving by far the largest proportion of this development assistance is Papua New Guinea; that it is receiving an untied single payment this year of $ 253m, or one-third of the Papua New Guinea Government's expenditure? If there is merit in Mr Somare's request to stop the real decline in this level of Australian support for Papua New Guinea, bilaterally and sensibly agreed to in the past, will favourable consideration be given by the Government to requiring Papua New Guinea's overseas purchases of equipment and expertise to be directed to Australian industry, to our mutual benefit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I believe that the figures quoted by the honourable senator with regard to overseas aid were broadly correct. Specifically with regard to Papua New Guinea, that country faces increasing economic problems and its Government has asked Australia to consider reviewing the existing arrangements in respect of the Budget support grants. These arrangements cover a five-year period ending in 1985-86. There is provision for an annual real reduction of 5 per cent in the grant. I understand that during the recent visit to Canberra of the Prime Minister, Mr Michael Somare, he discussed his country's needs with our Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In response to Mr Somare's request we have agreed to examine the possibility of bringing forward the mid-term review of the five-year aid arrangements, which in normal circumstances would be undertaken in the 1983-84 year. We have undertaken to provide firm advice to Mr Somare next month as to the proposed date of the review.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the last part of the question, relating to assistance that might be directed to Australian industry, I must say that an integral part of Australia's arrangements with Papua New Guinea in regard to the Budget support grants is an agreement that they be untied, thereby giving that country flexibility to determine its own expenditure priorities. A feature of that aid throughout the term of the agreement is that it is an untied grant, not subject to direction in regard to purchasing or whatever. As I have said, we hope that shortly there will be a statement in regard to any change in the proposed review of the grant. If at that time I can provide information of interest to Senator Teague I will see that he is advised accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to a statement made on 27 June by the Treasurer, commenting on the McCabe-Lafranchi report. The Treasurer said in his statement that he wanted to correct the false impression that there was anything new about bottom-of-the-harbour schemes of which the Government was unaware. I ask the Attorney: In view of the fact that it was clearly the Government's view in June of this year that there was nothing new about these schemes, what had he done as Attorney-General, the principal law officer of the Commonwealth, between his appointment in 1977 and the publication of the McCabe- Lafranchi report, in terms of making inquiries of his Department about what steps were being taken to deal with these schemes? Will he itemise any such inquiries that he made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement of the Treasurer of 27 June referred to bottom-of- the-harbour schemes and straw companies, which were the subject of a great deal of debate yesterday both here and in another place. This problem was raised in about the middle of 1978. The decision of the Government was to take specific action and create a specific offence. The view of the Crown law authorities was not just based upon the view of an officer in Perth. It was the view of senior officers-the then Crown Solicitor, the present Crown Solicitor and others-that there were difficulties with the existing law, problems of proof and so forth, and that the matter should be addressed by a new specific law. That was the policy being followed by the Government in relation to other tax avoidance schemes that were being uncovered and brought to its attention. The Goverment was passing special legislation to deal with them. The Government decided that that was the way this matter should be tackled.

ANSWER.PARA: That is what the Treasurer was referring to in his statement. He was saying that the Government had become aware of this problem, that it had taken action and had passed the legislation, and that it was not revealed to the Government for the first time by the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Honourable senators will remember that the third Costigan report also mentioned the problem. The Treasurer was simply saying that the Government was aware of these matters and had decided to take action against them by direct methods; that is, by legislation which is now known as the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. If the Attorney-General knew in 1978 that this was the view of the Crown law authorities, is it not a fact that it then took two years--
—Two and a half.

—Two and a half years to bring legislation into the Parliament to deal with this matter? Further, was the Attorney-General aware in 1978 of four opinions of Queen's Counsel, in relation to this matter, which had been the subject of discussion?

—It is matter of record that the problem was first raised in mid- 1978. The legislation was passed at the end of 1980. That is clearly a fact. The answer to the second question is that I was not aware of the opinions at that time. Some views were expressed in 1980, when the legislation was going through, that the existing law was adequate. I was aware of some of those views that were being expressed at the time against the passage of the legislation, but that was at the end of 1980 or thereabouts. I was certainly not aware of the Brinsden opinion, which had been obtained in relation to a specific case in Perth, until after the McCabe report was tabled.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I understand that the wheat storage situation in Tasmania has become chronically run down, to a degree where it is possible for the bread industry and feed wheat users' supplies to run out completely. Is it a fact that several silos in Tasmania may not be fully serviced by the ships now carrying grain to Tasmania? Has this fact been drawn to the Minister's attention? Is he aware of the strain being placed on users of both feed and bread wheat by less regular shipping and diminished usable storage capacity? Has the Minister any information on these matters and, particularly, can he say how and when the problems may be rectified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has advised me that he is aware of the matters raised by Senator Archer in this question, namely, that there is a wheat storage problem in Tasmania. Basically, the problem is that existing storage facilities can accommodate the wheat shipments brought in by Australian National Line Lake class carriers only by running down stocks to very low levels . There has been some correspondence between Ministers of the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments. The point has been made that provision of storage facilities is essentially a State responsibility. It is also relevant to point out that users of wheat may feel some responsibility for solving the problem, as I understand that users of wheat in Tasmania place much heavier reliance on public or State provided facilities relative to their own facilities than do mainland users.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clearly in the interests of Tasmanian users and authorities as well as the producers of wheat destined for Tasmania that the problem be resolved. Honourable senators will appreciate that the matter is largely outside the responsibility of the Commonwealth. It is not possible for me to say when the problem will be rectified, but I understand that the Australian Wheat Board is continuing to pursue the matter with the relevant Tasmanian authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the strategic plan drawn up by the Reagan Administration and presented to the United States National Security Council which officially declares that the United States can conduct and win a protracted nuclear war with the Soviet Union? Has the Federal Government received notification of this document, and is the Government aware of its contents? What is the Federal Government's stance in relation to the concept of a winnable and protracted nuclear war? Has it made any representations to the United States about this matter? Is the Federal Government aware of the numerous opinions from people such as the former United States Secretary of State, Cyrus Vance, that it would be absolute madness to believe that a country could fight and win, or even contemplate, a protracted nuclear war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On this matter the Minister for Foreign Affairs has seen Press reports that the United States Department of Defense recently submitted to the United States National Security Council a draft directive relating to United States nuclear policy. The Government has not received notification of any such document or of its purported contents. An essential part of the United States defence policy is to ensure that the United States has sufficient survivable strength in strategic nuclear forces to deter any Soviet nuclear attack. A consideration for United States policy is that Soviet military doctrine appears to contemplate the possibility of fighting a protracted nuclear war. This would include the possibility of the Soviet Union being the first to use nuclear weapons. For these reasons emphasis is placed within the United States strategic program on survivability and endurance of the United States strategic forces. The United States command communications and control systems- C3-are designed explicitly to strengthen deterrents of nuclear attack by making it clear to the Soviet Union that it would not be able to gain advantage from first use of nuclear weapons. The Government does not see the United States strategic program as implying a commitment to either the notion of limited nuclear war or protracted nuclear war. On the contrary, it is clearly designed to prevent nuclear war. The Australian Government's view is that any resort to nuclear weapons by the superpowers or, indeed, any other country could result in all-out nuclear war with inevitable disastrous consequences.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. First, may I have the indulgence of the Senate to say that I am bitterly disappointed with the answer that the Department has furnished to the Minister. My supplementary question is based on a confirmation that this document does exist by an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald. In that article Mr Weinberger, the United States Defense Secretary, conceded the existence of this document; that the United States has a plan to do this. One is filled with horror. I ask the Minister to bring this updated information to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs or his Department and to bring an equally updated reply to the Senate. Mr Weinberger made an extraordinary response when asked whether it was really possible to control nuclear forces in the confusion of battle and to make the calculated decisions of protracted nuclear war; he shook his head and said: 'I don't have any idea'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will undertake to refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs the further information that has been supplied by Senator Chipp. I will ask the Minister to give an early response.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the tabling of the interim reports of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Interim report No. 3 made reference to social security and workers' compensation frauds. I ask the Minister whether any action has been taken in response to those assertions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned in very broad terms the allegations which were made in Interim Report No. 3 in the debate which took place in the Senate yesterday. I have the relevant section of the report here and just to remind honourable senators of the allegation I will read it:

ANSWER.PARA: Material already available to the Commission indicates that very large numbers of painters and dockers have been involved in imposition on the social security system. Such imposition involves the receipt of social security benefits whilst workers under false names are either in receipt of workers' compensation benefits or working at other employments. The Commission's ability to identify false names has enabled these investigations to be pursued and will result in the recovery by Government to a large extent of the amount illegally received. It is not possible at this stage of the investigation to state precisely the amount involved but it will be well over $1,000,000.

The statements contained in the Commission's report were based not only on information which makes it clear to the Commission that there is widespread use of false names among members of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union, with an intent to defraud the Government in respect of social security and workers' compensation payments, but also on cases of fraud which had been detected by the Department of Social Security and/or the Australian Federal Police investigations that actually started before the Royal Commission was commenced and indeed which may have had an influence on its establishment in 1980. In this latter connection, there were 105 cases of fraud investigated in Brisbane and 22 in Adelaide during the period January-December 1980. These 127 cases involved over-payments of $152,000 and in nearly every case unemployment beneficiaries who had been employed as painters and dockers. In 24 cases the fraud involved the receipt of full benefits under the beneficiary's true identity while working under a false identity.

A number of prosecutions have flowed from those investigations and a number of convictions have been obtained. The liaison between my Department and the Commission has continued. Extensive further work is being done which has already uncovered circumstances which will give rise to more detailed investigations. I would prefer not to give further detail to the Senate on the basis that I do not think there is any point in giving any further warning to those who are involved in what appears to be a very widespread defalcation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Attorney-General hear or has he heard of comments made on A.M. this morning by his colleague Senator Withers, who is a former Leader of the Government in this place and a respected lawyer in his own right?
—I hasten to add that he is not respected just in Bunbury. The comments to which I refer are those on section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and went as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government cannot continue to hide behind the secrecy provisions of the Tax Act to explain why it was not told of delays in prosecutions for tax avoidance in the Crown Solicitor's office.
I don't think the secrecy provisions mean much. It was a good political ploy to claim that he didn't know.
The Attorney-General has been claiming that he didn't find out about the incompetence in his Department because of those secrecy provisions.
That's a good political ploy. It is no reason why his officers ought not to have told him in broad terms what the problems were.
Does not this starkly expose the Government's reliance on the privacy provisions contained in the Income Tax Assessment Act for the humbug that it is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Evans was in the chamber earlier when I was asked a question about Senator Withers's comments. I did not hear Senator Withers. I have quickly read the transcript once. But I am aware that Senator Withers made comment along the lines that Senator Evans has just quoted. All that seems to reveal is that Senator Withers is supporting Senator Evans's views of the secrecy provisions against the views that Mr Costigan has formed and amplified at great length in his opinion about the extent to which section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was impeding Ministers in having a full knowledge about affairs of the Australian Taxation Office or about tax files, whether they are in the Taxation Office or in the Attorney-General's Department. That is all that emerges from Senator Withers's comment. Senator Evans may gain comfort from having at least one other person agreeing with him. Up until then he seemed to be out on a limb with his view.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that Mr Costigan made his finding after inquiring into the matter. Senator Evans and the Opposition seem to have been very impressed with all the work that Mr Costigan has done and with all the other findings he has made. But, because it does not suit them politically, they do not seem to want to accept this point. Apart from what Mr Costigan has said, the Crown Solicitor, to whom I have mentioned this matter, has told me that the view which he has taken and which his predecessors have taken is that they do not refer to the Attorney- General tax files in their office that have been referred to them by the Taxation Office. That is the view which they have taken. Whether this can be done in the sanitised way which Senator Evans is now suggesting is beside the point at the moment. Perhaps it can. The Crown Solicitor had not taken that view . The Crown Solicitor had taken the view over the years that his office did not refer specific files or matters-

TALK.START.PARA: —You know what Costigan says about his incompetence as a lawyer.

—This was the view of Mr O'Donovan, the present Crown Solicitor. It was the view that was being taken and that is what was followed. Obviously Mr Costigan has found that there was great substance in that view, because that is the view that he has expressed.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is the Attorney- General saying, as the chief law officer in this nation-a Queen's Counsel in his own right-that it is his understanding of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act that it prohibits tax officers telling anyone else in 'broad terms' what the problems are?

—As I have said, in broad terms the matter was raised with the Government, through the Treasurer. The issue was brought to the attention of the Government in those broad terms and the Government decided to take action, which resulted in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the proposed pay-as-you-earn taxation scheme for sub-contractors. As the Treasurer would be aware, the cash economy type of operation which the Treasury is seeking to eliminate is not the general practice in the professional housing industry. It may happen in some instances where home owners or owner- builders engage a tradesman directly, but there is little evidence of this. Does the Treasurer agree that the proposed scheme, whilst certain to come down heavily on these tax avoiders, may destroy the sub- contracting system in the housing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer made it quite clear in his Budget Speech that the Government will take particular care when implementing the new system to protect the separate status of sub-contractors. If that is the burden of the question, that matter was specifically addressed by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech. The other point that can be emphasised is that this proposed new system is to be competely separate from the PAYE system. The Treasurer advises that the term 'cash economy' has come to be used to refer to payments, whether they are made by cash or cheque. It refers really to payments that are not disclosed in income tax returns.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that the professional housing industry makes payment for labour and services by cheque is no guarantee that the recipients of the payments will include them in their income tax returns. The Treasurer has clearly stated that the new system is seen as protecting contractors, the vast bulk of whom are regarded as being honest. The Government hopes that the system will protect them from unfair competition from those who are currently evading tax. It may be argued that there is little evidence of evasion of the cash economy kind in relation to payments made by home owners or owner-builders. But in a sense, the only direct evidence of evasion generally is obtained when it has been discovered as a result of an investigation. The Treasurer has also stated that there is scope for evasion by payees in relation to this kind of payment. Representatives of the professional building industry have expressed the view that significant evasion is occurring in this area.

In respect of the question asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen, it could be agreed that the proposed new system will come down heavily on tax evaders. It is not a case of coming down on avoiders as suggested in the question. The Treasurer does not agree that this will destroy the sub-contracting system in the housing industry. Perhaps it ought to be recalled that he said there will be considerable consultation before this proposed new system is introduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did he hear this morning's view of Senator Withers that the Government had not been able to distance itself from the behaviour of officers of the Attorney-General's Department? Senator Withers said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we employ them, we pay them and we appoint them.
No master should complain about his incompetent, inefficient servant.
Do these comments effectively express the same view as the Prime Minister in 1972? He said:

If a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistake of his department and offer to resign.
In view of these opinions, will the Minister advise the Prime Minister to seek the resignation of the Attorney-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first place the Prime Minister has made it clear that he has no such intention at all. He has full confidence in the Attorney- General as, indeed, has the great bulk of the people of Australia.

—There are those who laugh here today, when they are sitting absolutely mute on the cesspit of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which is affiliated with the Australian Labor Party, where hundreds of people have committed major crimes, murder, violence and so on; they are laughing and sneering today. Let me cut this down to size. Already today-

—Order! There is too much incessant interjecting at present. I was speaking to the chamber and interjections still continued. If this continues I will name the person who next interjects.
—Mr President, already today--
—You ought to answer the question.
—Order! Senator Georges.
—Well, he should answer the question.
—Senator Georges, if you interject again I will name you.
—Already today the Labor Party is trying to indicate that the Public Service of Australia as to a very large number of public servants is corrupt and incompetent. I reject that completely.
—Who said that?
—Well, Mr President--
—That is a lie. Who said that?
—Mr President, I heard an interjection: 'That is a lie' .
—It is a lie.
—And you are the one who perpetrated it.
—Order! Senator Grimes, that is extremely unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw.
—Yes, on behalf of my colleague, who actually said it, I do withdraw it.

—I take a point of order. The Leader of the Government has been making inflammatory statements and has incited people on this side of the chamber to refute statements that we are in agreement with a cesspool of corruption and murder. We are not, and that is the reason he is getting interjections. I suggest to you, Mr President, that you curb the Leader of the Government's remarks which are inciting members on this side of the chamber.

—I repeat that in fact a Labor senator this morning, when I think the Attorney referred to Perth and said it was confined to several people, said: 'Wait till we get to Brisbane and Adelaide'. Is that a lie? Is that not an indication that in Brisbane--
—This is being directed at me.

—I take a point of order. No senator on this side of the chamber has said this morning, as Senator Sir John Carrick said a couple of minutes ago, that hundreds of public servants in Australia were corrupt. That is what he said .

—I repeat that it was said this morning by the Labor Party, when the inference was that this was a narrow situation: 'Wait till we get to Brisbane and Adelaide'. In other words, the inference was that the divisions of the Crown Law Office there are corrupt and incompetent. Indeed, we had the retort: 'That is a lie'. But it was said. The fact of the matter is, to put this in perspective--

—Senator Georges, I am sorry to do this. I warned you about your incessant interjecting and said that if you interjected again I would name you. I have no alternative at this stage but to name you.

—I hope that it will not be necessary to take any procedures at all. The President having named Senator Georges, I have to ask that Senator Georges be called upon in accordance with Standing Order 440 to make any explanation or apology he may see fit. I hope that we will be able to resolve this matter without the necessary consequences.

It ought to be obvious to everyone here this morning that the actions of the Leader of the Government have been provocative to the extent that they have attracted interjections, interjections that cannot in any way be withheld. This situation has been reached in the Senate because of the provocative statements made by the Leader of the Government in defence of the Attorney-General, who finds himself in considerable trouble at present. I have no desire to be in conflict with you but at the same time I do not see how I can in any way withdraw from this awkward position because the interjection was drawn out of me. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support my colleague, Senator Button. I appreciate the way he has changed the seriousness of the situation with his humour. If I can just speak as someone who has been removed from this place under the Standing Order, I point out that we are in the same situation as we were when I was ejected, and when others in this place have been ejected, in that Senator Sir John Carrick, the Leader, uses a device and uses the Standing Orders to blackguard collectively members of the Opposition in a manner which cannot be replied to except by interjection or by going against the Standing Orders with individual replies. But I do suggest that the proceedings of the chamber are being reduced to a farce level, at a time when there is both a collective smear and an attempt to smear directly and personally so many members of the Government and their supporters, when we get a debate in the terms that we are now getting on this point of order. I claim that only on one occasion was that done correctly. The other times it has been done with the tyranny of numbers and distortion of the facts. Nevertheless, the punishment was meted out and I accepted it. It is true that the Leader of the Government has a great ability--

—Order! I suggest to you, Senator Keeffe, that these points of order are now ranging far and wide. The subject under discussion at present is the interjection and the continued interjection by Senator Georges. I make the ruling that there is no point of order.
—I want to emphasise that point. I really believe-

—Mr President, I was asked a question. In order to put the dimensions of the question into true perspective I remind the Senate that Mr Costigan's report does not relate to a large number of people. Indeed, although there has been a tendency by the Opposition to assume guilt he has no capacity to determine the guilt or innocence of any person at all. It is fundamental that we must try to preserve the rule of law. At the moment several officers of the Western Australian division of the Crown Law office are under suspension, not because they are guilty but because in the collection of information inferences have been drawn upon which the proper legal processes will now be brought to bear. It is utterly wrong for anyone to make allegations by way of decision, by finding guilt. That is a Moscow kind of trial.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the dimension of the situation at the moment. No one is seeking to mitigate or lessen the fact that, if there is significant maladministration in a section of the Public Service, of course it should be cleaned up. It would be incredible if, in a Public Service of several hundred thousand people, there were not significant aberrations from time to time. It was never intended under the Westminster system that a Minister should offer his resignation following every such aberration. Indeed, at this moment we are in no position to judge. According to the ordinary rule of law, which ought to be upheld in this place, we now have to wait and see what decisions and actions are taken with regard to these two people. Against that background I simply ask: Why not observe the rule of law for a change?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: In view of the recent media reports in the Northern Territory, New South Wales and elsewhere, suggesting that some recipients of benefits were abusing the social welfare system, can he advise the Senate to what extent this is happening in Australia, and what action his Department is taking to prevent this from occurring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a system the size of the social security system there are, of course, some problems of abuse. About 2.3 million Australians currently receive income support payments from my Department. There are about 1.4 million age pensioners. Unfortunately, there are about 400,000 people receiving the unemployment benefit. Given such large numbers, it is not really surprising that there are areas of abuse. We acknowledge that the abuse occurs and have procedures designed to reduce it. In trying to prevent abuse of the benefits which are available from my Department, one has to tread a very fine line between having procedures which are reasonable for those who are entitled to benefits to operate and will give people ready access to those benefits and having procedures which are very open to abuse. I believe that in most cases we tread that line fairly carefully.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as benefits control in the Northern Territory is concerned, a number of cases were detected during 1981-82. There were 12 prosecutions in the Northern Territory and 12 convictions under the Crimes Act. Those 12 cases involved payments of some $14,000. In addition, in matters which fell short of requiring prosecution we found 125 cases of incorrect payments, representing a total of $ 100,000 in incorrect payments already made, and an estimate was made that that would have gone on to involve payments of an additional $400,000. Those cases are over and above the cases which involved the fraudulent negotiation of cheques, which is also a problem in the Northern Territory. The general approach of the Department is that it is concentrating on trying to develop means which will reduce the incidence of abuse in the Northern Territory and elsewhere. We are doing that by the development of selective reviews and we are expecting to implement some new schemes in this area during the current calendar year.

I can only say to Senator Kilgariff that all of the examinations I have seen confirm what I think honourable senators would expect, namely, that abuse occurs in very much the minority of cases. It is important not to produce a situation in which the innocent and justified claimants of social security benefits are in some way categorised with those who would abuse the system. That is a consideration which we bear very much in mind. There are particular difficulties in the Northern Territory-difficulties of a mobile population, of many people passing through who perhaps deal with a regional office of my Department on one occasion only. I am satisfied that the staff in those difficult offices do their best to minimise fraud and abuse. However, I believe that we do need to upgrade our systems in a number of ways to reduce the incidence of the problem that Senator Kilgariff raised in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and follows a question asked by my colleague Senator Ryan and the unsatisfactory answer given by Senator Sir John Carrick. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement in the other place yesterday that he had told Senator Durack that had he offered to resign his ministry he, Malcolm Fraser, would have refused to accept the resignation. I ask the Minister: When did this conversation take place, did he in fact offer to resign, and was the Prime Minister responding to such an offer? In any case, is not any Minister able to tender the resignation of his commission without the consent or agreement of the Prime Minister or any other person?
—I do not propose to answer questions about what discussions I have with the Prime Minister. They are personal matters between him and me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and relates to the significant increases in work experience subsidies under the Special Youth Employment Training Program. How does the Government propose to ensure that employers are fully acquainted with the changes in the subsidy rate and the administrative guidelines, and how many of the estimated 74,200 work experience approvals in 1982-83 can be expected to help unemployed youth in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The program about which the honourable senator has asked is one which enables the Commonwealth to subsidise the employment of unemployed young people who have had difficulty competing in the labour market. The levels of assistance vary. There is a subsidy of $75 a week for 17 weeks of employment. An extended form of assistance provides $100 a week for the first 17 weeks and $75 a week for the second 17 weeks. As the honourable senator mentioned in her question, the provisions under the program have been expanded in the recent Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first part of the question, it is obviously important that employers should be aware of the existence of this subsidy so that they will be encouraged to take advantage of it. The Government proposes to ensure that that is so-that is, that employers are fully acquainted with the changes in the subsidy rates and administrative guidelines-by some extensive media advertising, which will commence next week, and by the provision through the Commonwealth Employment Service of handout leaflets explaining in detail the new subsidies and changes to guidelines.

There is not a specific allocation to Tasmania but, based on experience, 3,280 approvals are projected for Tasmania in 1982-83. So it would be the Government's expectation that something over 3,000 young Tasmanians who have had difficulty in finding a place in the labour force will, through this system of subsidising employers, gain valuable work experience and access to the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and follows his reply to Senator Button earlier, when the Attorney-General said that he was aware in a general way of a general view that some held the opinion that the existing law was adequate for the prosecution of some tax avoidance offences. At the time of the discussions concerning the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill in Cabinet, did the Attorney-General attempt to satisfy himself as to the necessity for the legislation by personally calling for, or seeking or reading, any opinions which argued the adequacy of the existing law if only it were to be enforced? If such a request were made of his Department to provide such opinions , did the Attorney-General's Department deny the existence of any such opinions from silk, or did the Attorney-General's Department play down the view held by the legal officers of the Australian Taxation Office that existing law was adequate? In other words, did the Attorney-General's Department mislead him? If no such requests were made, does the Attorney-General agree that his failure to advise the Government after a personal review of opinions available to Government reflects on his capacity as a Queen's Counsel but, more particularly, in the discharge of his duties as Attorney-General?

—Firstly, let me clear up a matter of fact. I made it quite clear that I was not aware of the Brinsden opinion, which was on the file in the Crown Solicitor's Office, until after McCabe. I said that when the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was going through the Parliament views were being expressed by various people. I cannot remember whose opinions were being expressed or what they were. All I am saying is that that point was being made. It was made to the Parliament. It was the subject of public debate. I was aware of what was being said. What I was saying, though, is that the senior officers of my Department had advised and strongly maintained the view that that Bill was needed and that the law was not adequate. That was the view they had held from the time the matter was first brought to the senior officers' attention by the Commissioner of Taxation. Unfortunately, there is no written opinion of those officers that can be referred to, but that was certainly the view they had always held and which they expressed.

—I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand the Attorney- General to be saying that he did not call for the opinions that formed the basis of the advice he received from the chief legal officers in his Department; that he was content to rest on their advice and did not satisfy himself as to whether there were any opinions, pro or contra, within his Department or the Crown Solicitor's Office?

—That is what the Attorney-General's Department and legal officers and senior legal officers are for-to give their views on matters. Hundreds of views are being given by people in the Attorney-General's Department , and the Government would not be able to operate without the views of the senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department.

—Order! I have allowed you a lot of latitude. You have got away from a personal explanation. I ask you to draw your remarks to a very rapid close.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION SERVICE AND BUSINESS OUTLOOK FOR 1982- 83

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report, entitled 'Australian Telecommunications Commission Service and Business Outlook for 1982-83', outlines plans, funding and anticipated revenue for Telecom Australia for this financial year. In doing this the report draws attention to many of the policy problem areas and longer term matters affecting the whole of telecommunications development in Australia. It is important to bear in mind that Telecom became a separate business-oriented authority only in 1975. Since that time it has made tremendous strides as an organisation. Telecom is frequently criticised, sometimes correctly, for slowness, backlogs and lack of flexibility in its policies. There is no doubt that it does have some of those problems. It is important to recognise that it is not realistic to expect a body of this size-it is the largest enterprise in Australia-to change overnight. I believe the response which Telecom has made to some of the criticisms which have been put upon it has been well worth while and important. Pressure should be kept on an organisation such as Telecom to adapt to changing conditions. But there are correct conditions-better than those which this Government allows-under which it should be done. I will come to that in a moment .

Telecom is worthy of congratulation in relation to the new services discussed in its business outlook for 1982-83. I mention particularly improved inwats services, new types of telephones, new small business systems, mobile telephone services, better telex services and digital radio concentrator systems. These innovations and services coming in great numbers from Telecom increasingly refute the assertion that Telecom cannot or does not provide the services which consumers and particularly business require. It is also making great efforts as an organisation to reduce backlogs and to update antiquated services. I congratulate the new Minister for Communications, Mr Brown, for drawing attention to this matter and asking Telecom specifically to concentrate on particular areas where backlogs occur. Telecom expects this year a reduction in the number of manual services from 43,000 to 34,000-a very significant reduction in one year. Telecom expects to instal some 540,000 new telephone services in the coming year, somewhat greater than the demand for this year, thus allowing an attack on the backlog which has built up.

I want to make the point that all this is being done by Telecom as an organisation against a background of an unco-operative Government policy. There are several ways in which the Government has failed to co-operate with the best interests of the development of the telecommunications system in Australia. There is the question of capital available to Telecom. Telecom is expected to provide all these services to which I have referred. However, it is not able to act like normal private sector big business in doing this. This year its internal funding percentage will be 86 per cent from trading surplus, depreciation and long service leave retained funds. That is to say, all new capital works embarked on by Telecom will be financed by the organisation itself up to 86 per cent.

This compares with 1981 figures for other telecommunications organisations overseas in the following ratios: Bell Canada finances 53 per cent of its expansion from internal revenue; in Japan the figure for the National Telecommunications Company is 68 per cent; for the Bell Company in the United States the figure is 67 per cent, and the Deutsches Bundespost finances 44 per cent of its expansion from internal revenue. For Telecom the figure is 85 per cent. Looking at comparative figures of internal financing for private business or other large statutory undertakings, one finds, for example, 56 per cent for Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd, 21 per cent for the State Electricity Commission of Victoria, and 67 per cent for CSR Ltd. So, enormous a corporation as Telecom is, it is required to finance 85 per cent as distinct from those comparative figures to which I have referred for other countries and other businesses. This happens because of Commonwealth Government control over borrowing, which comes directly from this Government's policies. To add to the additional burden Telecom has, it is required in respect of pre-1975 advances paid to Telecom to pay for those at a greatly increased interest rate over the original rate. This is the main reason, the report notes, for the 26 per cent increase in Telecom's interest bill this year.

It is fair enough, as I have said, to press Telecom for efficiency and good use of capital. No one should resist that obvious need. But it is not fair to impose on it restrictions which no other telecommunications organisation or business has, and which are much harsher than is normal for big private business enterprises. The outcome of Government policies in relation to Telecom has been seen recently in steep and frequent tariff increases. For example, the 4 per cent to 7 per cent increase in short-haul STD announced around Budget day and approved by the Minister for Communications represents yet another burden imposed on rural users in respect of telephone services. The report of McKinsey and Co. Inc. on the Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s, which was commissioned by this Government, recommended easier borrowing for Telecom. The Government sat on that report for a year and released it only after it had been leaked by me.

The second handicap of Telecom is refusal to admit it to new technology. I mention two things. As a result of decisions of this Government, Telecom has been precluded from the basic videotex service, where there should be a natural partnership between a public instrumentality such as Telecom and private information providers, a partnership between private and public enterprise working in the best interests of the consumer. I do not know what the ideological basis of that decision was; I can only guess, but the result of the Government's decision in relation to videotex is that users in Australia will be deprived of a service which they could already have had. That is a tragedy in terms of the development of communications policy.

The Government's second omission is the omission of Telecom from the board of Aussat Pty Ltd, the company responsible for the ownership and management of the domestic satellite. If it is good enough for the expected private sector users to be on the Board of that company-all the major television networks, for example-why is Telecom, a large potential user and possibly the largest user, not represented on the board. Why, for that matter, is the Australian Broadcasting Commission, another potentially big user, not represented on the board?

In the Opposition's view, it is essential that Telecom be modern and efficient, but it is also necessary to have an orderly and fair national telecommunications policy which is freed from ideological stupidity. For instance, Telecom mentions in the document moves towards a national integrated digital network. That is sensible, but it has implications for planning and policy in many areas-data networks, news services, cable television and the like. Under this Government it seems unlikely that such mature consideration will occur. I lament this fact and I appeal to the Government to read this report and to act on it in an intelligent and constructive way in the development of a rational communications structure in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Therefore, in the 10 minutes available to me, I shall obviously not canvass all the questions that will be discussed during the passage of that legislation. The Prime Minister intervened during the latter stages of the consideration of parliamentary salaries and allowances by the Remuneration Tribunal and sought to suggest that wages are the main contributing factor to the economic problems facing this country, a matter which is not accepted by the Australian Labor Party. We do not accept that ideological position. We believe that it is a class acceptance by the Prime Minister and one that is not borne out in any proper analysis of the problems facing the Western world in respect to the current recession. Attempting to suggest that a cut in wages and salaries is the panacea to the sort of problems facing our country and the Western world is much too simplistic.

As the Remuneration Tribunal has said, it does not believe that members of parliament should be placed in any position that puts them at a disadvantage as compared with other sections of the community. I remind the Senate that the Remuneration Tribunal's earlier recommendations, which we dealt with in the last session of Parliament, awarded wage increases that took the 2,000 members of the Public Service Second Division to a salary level of $43,000, in round figures, which was a 14 per cent increase, without one reference by the Prime Minister or the Liberal Government to the degree of increase in that determination.

It is easy for the Prime Minister and members of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party, the great majority of whom have other incomes, to talk about wage and salary restraint, when they are in receipt of not only parliamentary salaries but, in most cases, also other forms of income. That is particularly so in respect of the Cabinet. So many graziers with large properties, solicitors and other professional people make up the great bulk of the Cabinet. It is very easy for them to sit in their ivory castle and suggest that other members of parliament and, for that matter, all other members of the community, should practise wage restraint when they apply it to themselves only in respect of the salaries they receive as members of the national Parliament.

In the Remuneration Tribunal's report, which will be the subject of legislation , the increases granted to the judges of the various courts ranged from about $7 ,000 or $8,000. I make that brief reference to what I believe to be the hypocritical position taken by the Prime Minister, an opportunist position and one which, of course, seeks to demean the whole role of parliament and its members who perform their function in that respect.

However, some other changes were made. This brings me to the Tribunal's decision to recommend the recognition of the extra work load involved in electorates which contain excessive numbers, a recommendation which I understand is to be accepted by the Government. This is a departure from previous categories and classifications. Up until now, such recognition has been afforded only to those electorates of greatest size, that is over 5,000 square kilometres . On this occasion, the tribunal has provided a third dimension and has taken this significant and important step. We have been arguing, of course, that extra pressures are imposed upon members of parliament with large electorates to contend with. We do have this absurd position where we have electorates in Tasmania approximating 52,000 to 53,000 voters and we have electorates in Queensland and New South Wales where there are in excess of 90,000 people on the electoral roll. The latest figures indicate that there are now 30 seats in the Australian Commonwealth Parliament, 30 electorates, which have either above or below the 10 per cent tolerance which is the legislation upon which the electorates of Australia should operate. It is anticipated that by 31 October that figure will apply to considerably more than 25 per cent of the electorates.

The Tribunal, in recognising this imbalance which this Government has failed to deal with in terms of any effective redistribution, has recognised the fact that electorates with large populations face particular difficulties and has therefore adjudged that they should be deserving of a special allowance. So the Tribunal has taken into consideration not only a size but also a population category. We are concerned, as an Opposition, at the distortion of the democratic principles that exist in the failure to draw boundaries in such a way as to bring about the obvious democratic principle of every vote cast in an election having one value. The fact that the Tribunal has taken the step of establishing a third category is an innovation which the Opposition welcomes.

Finally, the Tribunal has effected another change in the conditions of the travel allowance to the staff of members of parliament. I refer to clause 9.5 of the report. This year there is an additional clause which appears to have the effect of imposing a further restriction on the movement of staff members from the electorate to Canberra for parliamentary duties. We all recognise the onerous tasks that now fall upon members of parliament in regard to the greater complexities of a modern and developed society. The motive for this change seems to be to protect staff members from some unfair pressure that may have been applied by some members and senators to spend more time in Canberra on parliamentary duties than the allowance covers. While we appreciate the Tribunal 's attempt to protect staff in this way from the demands of their employer who happens to be a member of parliament, at the same time this clause also has the effect of punishing those members of parliament and their staff who use the flexibility of the current system to their general advantage and satisfaction. We believe it would have been reasonable for the Tribunal to recognise the fact that the staff of members of parliament are required in Canberra for parliamentary duties and to grant an adequate allowance for the fulfilment of those duties. When we have regard to the amount of work that our research staff is required to undertake from time to time, rather than reduce the flexibility of staff travel we would like to see some attempt made to eliminate the anomalies that exist. It seems to me that we are reaching a stage where the Tribunal and the Government ought to be recognising the value and the improvement in the debates that take place in the Parliament as a result of providing members of parliament with adequate resources to carry out their parliamentary duties. I wish to make the point that I do not think an annual report like this ought to go through this chamber without some comment as to why the Department has been set up and some comment on the operation of the Department. The Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council was set up on 7 May 1982 because of a crisis in which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) then found himself. It was a crisis which arose because the then Minister for Defence was to be shifted , demoted or removed one way or the other. It was generally recognised by the Prime Minister and by commentators at the time that a move had to be made. Having made that decision, the Prime Minister then had to find some way to shelve the then Minister for Defence. The idea that he and his advisers came up with was one of creating the Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council and appointing a full time Minister. It was an $80,000 per annum answer to a problem that the Prime Minister was not strong enough to contend with and as a consequence we now have a Minister essentially without a job to do, without portfolio, and, as this annual report shows, without any purpose or function.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is spending a lot of time in the House of Representatives now.
—As my colleague says, he is spending a lot of time in the House of Representatives.
—He is keeping an eye on things.
—He is keeping an eye on things. Maybe he could lend his background expertise to some of the Ministers in the Senate who seem at the moment to be much in need of it.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this report we find that it does not answer questions which annual reports normally answer. In fact, it raises more questions than it answers. If we go through it section by section, on page 1, under the heading ' Responsibilities and Functions' we are told that one of the functions of the Department is:
. . . Formal and ceremonial matters including in relation to the Parliament and the States.

That is a rather general statement. It does not give details of what formal ceremonial matters are involved, how many are involved, what number per week, and what in fact are the character of the functions. Are they more than tea parties? Are they organising matters of importance or otherwise? If we go on further in this section we are told that the Minister is responsible for:
summoning meetings of the Executive Council and presiding over meetings which the Governor-General is unable to attend.

One could be uncharitable enough to say that in this respect this current Minister may have been a better stopgap for a previous Governor-General than the present one. That statement once again leaves many questions open. It does not tell us whether the Minister is acting as anything more than a typist or a clerk in sending out notices and summoning meetings of the Executive Council. It does not tell us how many meetings are held. It does not tell us the degree to which the Minister is involved. We are told that he chairs the Legislative Committee of Cabinet. Once again we are not told how often the Committee meets. We are not told how often the Minister has had to chair that Committee. The Minister has to give advice on parliamentary matters generally. That probably explains why he spends so much time in the House of Representatives. The report goes on to say:
The Prime Minister has also announced his intention to call on the Vice- President frequently to act in place of or represent other Ministers . . .
He seems to be the twentieth man of the Cabinet. Once again, we do not have any details as to the actual functions performed. The next section raises questions and leaves them unanswered. It states:
By arrangement, advice and additional administrative support for the Vice- President are provided by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

We are not told to what degree and to what extent, both financially and otherwise, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is involved in propping up this Department. However, we are told that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet advises the Vice-President on parliamentary matters and has provided for him the assistance of a parliamentary liaison officer. What this section shows is that the system of government, the Cabinet system, can continue quite well without this $80,000 indulgence. It shows that the mechanism is already there. We do not know what the administrative expenses are. We do not know the cost of this report. It may well be that the cost of the report will be more than the actual finance provided from the Minister for Finance for the period of operation of this Department. As I said earlier, a number of questions arise out of this report which it does not answer . I think it is scurrilous that a government should set up such a mechanism to solve a ticklish problem for the Prime Minister. I give notice at this stage that when this Department is examined before Senate Estimates Committee A my colleagues and I will expect answers to the questions. I found on my desk a list of some 18 papers which it was proposed would be presented today. Knowing that I had not received a copy of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council report, I asked one of the attendants to obtain a copy for me. He came back and advised me that the report was not yet available. About 10 minutes prior to the end of Question Time I went to the records section of the Senate to request a copy. I was told that it was under embargo until such time as the Minister tabled the list of papers.

I believe we have to stop for a moment and look at what this means. If it is the intention of the Government, by this action, to stifle debate on these papers, then it has certainly been successful. I suggest that no one could properly debate a report that is not presented to him or her until minutes before the matter is raised in the chamber. But that is by the by. It is time the Senate had a look at the situation and determined that all the papers that are to be presented on a Thursday should at least be circulated to members of the Senate at some stage during the week so that we have time to look at them. The majority of them are circulated. I understand that six papers were held under embargo until after the Minister reported to the Senate this morning that he intended tabling these papers.

The report of the Council is an extremely interesting one. It does not say very much; it is not very large. It does at least concur with other thoughts that have been put forward by much more learned people than I about radiation induced genetic abnormalities and radioactivity generally. Under the heading 'biological effects of ionising radiation' on page 1 a statement is made, I believe, for the first time in a government report. The report states:

Large doses of radiation are also known to produce delayed effects, usually after periods of several years. Much the most important of these are an increased incidence of malignant disease in exposed individuals and of genetic change, manifested in their offspring. Increased numbers of human cancers have occurred, particularly in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, as a consequence of the atomic explosions in 1945. Radiation-induced genetic abnormalities have been studied in experimental animals but have not yet been observed in man.

The report goes on to make the point that certain levels of background radiation in industry should be contained to particular levels. This raises a very important issue which I have mentioned in this chamber on a number of occasions. It concerns the mineral sands operation in Capel. Honourable senators will appreciate that, whilst the question that I raised on those occasions concerned what the Federal Government intended to do about radioactive monazite in Capel, I was informed by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) that this was strictly a State matter. The situation now with Capel is that, of course, it cannot any longer be viewed as simply a State matter because the attitude of the Minister for Health in that State is one of complete and utter ignorance. There is a saying that a little knowledge is dangerous. I have to agree with that. The Minister for Health in Western Australia has little knowledge about radioactive substances and he is therefore a very dangerous person. He is dangerous to the community. The attitudes that he adopts are not confirmed by leading people working in the field of radioactivity nor by those people who have been concerned for many years in that area. For instance, I quote briefly from an article in the Daily News of Wednesday, 7 June 1982, by Frazer Guild. It states:
A scientist who helped to develop the atom bomb is alarmed at radiation levels in the mineral sands town of Capel.

The Western Australia Government has insisted there is no health risk. But Professor Joseph Rotbalt, now emeritus professor of physics at the University of London, says urgent action should be taken to clean up the town.

I do not intend to read the whole article because I do not have time to do so in the debate on this report. I will raise it at another time. Another article by the same newspaper on Wednesday, 2 June, states:
It is time for the Western Australia government to face the truth about Capel.
There are serious risks living and working with radioactive mineral sands.

Western Australia's Minister for Health, Mr Young, continues to insist that there are not, but Professor John Gofman, a scientist of world stature, has answered government and industry assurances in the strongest possible terms.
The government's complacent attitude astonishes him.

I must admit that it astonishes me too. I have a report to the Australian Workers Union on radiation hazards in the mineral sands industry compiled by Dr Philip Jennings, who is Associate Professor of Physics at the Murdoch University in Western Australia. One of the points that he makes in his report is:
. . . management should take measures to ensure that radiation dose rates are less than 2.5 millirem per hour in specially designated radiation areas and less than 0.1 millirem per hour elsewhere.

The report details a number of areas where this level is exceeded. For instance, in the monazite store the dose rate goes from 0.5 millerem to 50 millerem per hour. Indeed one has to question what the Western Australia Department of Health is doing. If we really want to know we need only look at a series of questions that were asked in the State Parliament concerning this radioactive substance. The questions were posed by Mr Barry Hodge, the shadow Minister for Health, and were answered by the Minister for Health, the same Mr Young, who is quoted in the newspaper reports. For instance, one of the questions asks:

In view of the high radiation levels adjacent to stored monazite which he reported in his reply to question 37 of 1982, is his department concerned about the doses received by drivers transporting this material?
He replied:
No, the drivers are not adjacent to the packaged monazite.
Another question is:
Is it a fact that the regulations of the Radiation Safety Act specify a maximum radiation dose rate of 2.5 millerem per hour in the cabin of a truck transporting radioactive materials?
The Minister's response was:
This is another misquotation or misrepresentation of the regulations. The regulations do not mention the cabin of the truck. However, the maximum of 2.3 millirem per hour is specified for drivers.

I have to ask this Minister for Health where he thinks the men are manipulating the truck from. Are they sitting out in the back and driving it or are they perhaps sitting on the bonnet? Let me assure the Minister that the majority of truck drivers that I know sit in the cabin of the truck to drive it. The questions go on:
Are drivers transporting monazite monitored for radiation dose?
The answer is:
No.
The next question is:
If not, why not?
The answer is:
Knowledge of radiation dose rates from monazite duration and frequency of transport renders monitoring unnecessary.

I raised this issue in this chamber in February of this year because of my concern for the health of the people in Capel. All of the things I said then and the request that I made to the Federal Government at that time are now being substantiated not only by newspaper journalists but also by world authorities- experts recognised for the contributions they have made in the radiation field. Yet we have a situation where the Federal Government is still sitting on its tail and doing very little because of the State-Federal government degree of responsibility. I was rather horrified not to see any mention in this report of monazite, xenotime or any of these other things that are being found in Capel. I hope that now the matter has been brought to the attention of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council it may see fit, before the next report is presented to this Parliament, to ensure that it at least visits Capel and looks at the monazite industry there.
