TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate House Committee, I present a report on the organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department dated August 1982, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Honourable senators will recall that the reference to the Senate House Committee of the organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department resulted from the Estimates Committee A examination of that Department's proposed expenditure for 1981-82. Estimates Committee A reported that, in the context of the savage reduction in funds for books for the Parliamentary Library, it was puzzled by the extraordinary priorities which led the Joint House Department to propose expenditure on such items as sporting equipment and uniforms for security attendants. In addition, rueful comparisons were made by Estimates Committee A between the ample funds provided to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and the relatively minimal amounts made available to the Senate standing committees and select committees. Estimates Committee A considered that further examination of the Joint House Department was required and recommended to the Senate that the matter be referred to the Senate House Committee for inquiry and report.

In response to the House Committee's invitation to senators and members for submissions, some members of the House of Representatives suggested that, whilst they agreed there was a need for an inquiry into the Joint House Department, the matter would be more appropriately examined by a joint committee. The Senate Committee pointed out in reply that each House has a duty to take such steps as it thinks necessary to inform itself on matters coming before it.

To meet this objective, the Senate had developed the practice whereby Estimates committees recommended to the Senate that certain matters which appeared to warrant further detailed consideration should be referred to the appropriate Senate standing committee for investigation and report. The reference to the Senate House Committee is therefore an example of the follow-up process adopted by the Senate when considering its attitude to matters arising from Appropriation Bills.

In all, the Committee received seven formal submissions, and eight organisations represented by 18 persons gave further evidence during seven public hearings and one in camera hearing. In addition, two senators and three members of the House of Representatives had dicussions with the Committee and the views of other interested organisations were presented.

Certain of the submissions directed the Committee's attention to the review by Urwick International Pty Ltd of the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff which, according to evidence given by the Speaker to the House of Representatives Estimates Committee A on 28 August 1980, recommended the amalgamation of those three departments. The House Committee was also informed that there was considerable disquiet among certain of the parliamentary staff that such an amalgamation might be agreed to and the Committee was urged to call for a copy of the management consultant's report.

The Committee determined that, since part of the reference from the Senate directed its inquiry into the organisation and functions of the Joint House Department, a thorough examination would have to embrace any proposals for new functions or the taking over of existing functions from other parliamentary departments. The Committee formed the opinion that it would be of considerable benefit to its deliberations if a copy of the report were made available by the President as an in camera document. The Committee subsequently commenced its program of public hearings and found that validity of its opinion confirmed by the evidence given at the hearings. In addition, the officers of the Joint House Department, when giving evidence to the Committee, referred on a number of occasions to recommendations of the Urwick report.

After an exchange of correspondence with the Presiding Officers, the Committee as a last resort raised the matter in the Senate, and the President, at the direction of the Senate, transmitted to the Committee a copy of the Urwick report as an in camera document. Honourable senators will recall that I gave a full account of this matter to the Senate on 19 May 1982. During its examination , the Committee considered the specific recommendations of Urwick International Pty Ltd. However, these have not been listed in the Committee's report. The Committee, nevertheless, felt it necessary to draw on certain information in the Urwick report in the compilation of this report.

The Committee approached the inquiry on the basis that its task was to inform the Senate of any inadequacies and deficiencies in the Joint House Department and to recommend how such problems might best be overcome. It did not see as its role the review and check of detailed administrative procedures, but rather the identification of matters for decision.

The Committee was most disturbed by what the inquiry into the Joint House Department revealed. Despite a number of inquiries and reviews of the Department over the years, significant change seems to have passed by the Joint House Department. The Secretary of the Department told the Committee that the Joint House Department was badly structured and that it had been inefficient simply because of the organisational structure. However, the overall evidence suggests to the Committee a lack of leadership, and management inaction or inability to respond to changed circumstances and resultant problems.

For example, the Committee's inquiries reveal that the lack of action in response to recommendations for modernisation of the refreshment rooms accounting systems has denied information essential for good management. This finding is underlined by the realisation that the members' bar has made a profit on only two occasions in the last quarter of a century.

In another area, after a period of two years virtually nothing has been done to assess the desirability of contract cleaning for the Parliament, despite the probability that substantial savings of public funds-up to $200,000 per annum- may have been effected. In another area, the Committee found that an attempt to have a public relations position created was an example of unsatisfactory administrative practice, disappointing and misleading management, and a performance far less than that expected of a parliamentary department.

In relation to the Urwick report, what emerged from the Committee's inquiry is that there is considerable disquiet among certain of the parliamentary staff that its recommendations will be implemented without sufficient opportunity to comment. Rumour has fed upon rumour because the report has been treated as secret and has been dealt with in such a way that all sorts of fears and alarms have been aroused. The Committee now asks the Presiding Officers, one or both, to table the Urwick report to put an end to the unhealthy and damaging speculation that has been created.

The Committee noted that in recent years the number of meetings of the Joint House Committee has been reduced to a mere handful, thus reducing the opportunities that senators and members have for at least some input into matters that closely concern them. The Committee noted that although the Presiding Officers have statutory powers in relation to the staff of parliamentary departments, nothing has been done by the Senate and House of Representatives to delegate responsibility for policy in relation to the functions of the Joint House Department. Thus, by default and usage, the situation has developed whereby the Presiding Officers have taken the responsibility.

The Committee believes, therefore, that each House should resolve to empower their respective House Committees, when sitting together as the Joint House Committee, with the executive responsibility for policy in relation to the functions of the Joint House Department. For too long senators and members have been denied effective participation in decision-making in Parliament's domestic matters, perhaps to the cost of all concerned as aspects of the Committee's report indicates. I understand that the debate on this report will resume later today, and for this reason, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the Committee's report 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force', together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
This report is in response to the motion the Senate passed on 25 March 1982 that :
(a) the Senate refer to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, as a matter of urgency, the following matters:
(i) the relevance of an aircraft carrier to Australia's current and perceived strategic environment;
(ii) the role of an aircraft carrier in the defence force structure of Australia; and
(iii) the effects of the purchase of an aircraft carrier on the future defence procurement program; and
(b) the Committee be requested to report not later than 1 September 1982.

On 20 April 1982, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence passed a motion requesting its Sub-Committee 'C', the Sub-Committee on Defence Matters, chaired by my colleague in another place, the Honourable R. C. Katter, M.P., to conduct an inquiry leading to the preparation of this report. The reference has attracted considerable public interest, and a wide range of submissions was received. The Committee wishes to thank those people who, in many cases, took considerable trouble to assist it with this inquiry. Many conflicting claims were included in the written submissions and evidence gathered at the Sub- Committee hearings. The Committee has sifted that evidence carefully and, in the report, discusses the major issues which need to be considered to reach conclusions relating to the reference.

The Australian Government's offer to permit the British Government to withdraw from the sale of the HMS Invincible, which has been accepted, provides a fresh opportunity to review the value of an aircraft carrier to Australia's Defence Force structure, and the priority such a purchase should be accorded. Discussion on the purchase of the Invincible, has increased public awareness of the issues involved.

The Committee has noted statements by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) that all options, including a decision not to purchase a carrier, will be considered. The Committee acknowledges that an aircraft carrier can provide many functions which would be valuable in the Australian Defence Force. At the price at which HMS Invincible was to be made available, a credible case could be made for its purchase. However, at the full project cost which would be involved in the acquisition of a specially designed ship, in the context of present defence spending levels, it is harder to justify such a purchase. Other desirable acquisitions would have to be curtailed or delayed unacceptably for the Australian Government to purchase such an aircraft carrier.

In the 1982-83 Budget, 16.5 per cent of defence expenditure is allocated to capital equipment. This is still far short of the Government's target of 25 per cent in 1984-85, which was announced on 25 March 1980. Last year the proportion of defence expenditure on capital equipment was only 12.5 per cent, and the year before that it was 16 per cent. HMS Invincible, was to be acquired primarily for anti-submarine warfare. The Committee reached the conclusion, based on evidence received, that the most substantial requirement for anti-submarine warfare operations would be associated with the consequences of global war. However, the Committee received evidence that the contingency of anti-submarine warfare during prolonged global war, which is seen as remote, has not been a factor in recent or current planning of Australian Defence Force structure.

In view of the assessment that the contingency of general nuclear war is highly unlikely on all rational calculations, priority is not accorded to developing the capability of the Australian Defence Force in relation to nuclear conflagration. Current defence planning is based on the premise that, in circumstances of general conventional war, the objective would be to employ our forces in a complementary role with allied forces, especially in our own region. The contingency of global conventional war is not, therefore, seen as a specific factor determining the characteristics of the forces. An aircraft carrier could also be effective in the lower level contingency situations which are identified in the report. It is then a matter of judgment what priority should be accorded to the various situations in which it would be effective, and the extent to which it would be effective in those situations. It is a matter of fact, however , that, except in its command and control function, an aircraft carrier is a platform, rather than a weapons system. The weapons systems are its aircraft.

The Committee was presented with varying project costs for the aircraft complement of a carrier. It seems likely that this will cost in the range of $ 500m, if a STOVL capability and additional ASW helicopters are provided. The project cost of a platform required to make these weapons systems effective would range, now that Invincible is no longer available, up to $1,000m or more. It is this very high platform cost which caused the Committee considerable concern. In the discussion on disruption to our sea lanes, argument was presented to the Committee that the carrier could be useful in escorting important cargoes in prolonged global war, or in regional conflicts involving a notional enemy with a strong submarine capability. Scenarios for these threats were necessarily vague. The Committee noted the existence of other elements of our naval forces capable of performing an escort function.

In a regional context, we are confident that Australia would be able to internationalise a situation in which an enemy disrupted our sea lines of communication. We accepted that it could be done for a short period, but we did not accept that the enemy could sustain its action without attracting sharp responses from the owner states of affected ships. Moreover, the Australian response to such a situation need not be directly related to the enemy activity: for example, we could retaliate with attacks against the enemy bases. The Committee also considered the role of an aircraft carrier in relation to external aggression against a regional country, particularly in the Indonesian- Melanesian archipelago, and to New Zealand. This vast area, extending out to beyond 7,000 nautical miles from the Australian mainland, is of abiding and fundamental concern to Australia, and New Zealand, and of considerable strategic interest to the United States. The Soviet Union could be interested in improving its influence in and access to the area if this could be done without provoking too strong a reaction from Australia, New Zealand and the United States.

It must be said, however, that this consideration would not be of the same order of priority as that assigned to deterring an intermediate level of threat to Australian territory. The extent of concern, and Australia's ability to influence such events, would be determined by proximity-developments in New Guinea would be of more concern than those in Samoa or Tahiti-and by prevailing political circumstances. There ought to be no assumptions of any direct Australian involvement in difficult domestic political circumstances in the south west Pacific islands. The Santo rebellion, when Vanuatu became independent , is sometimes mentioned as an example of the kind of South Pacific situation in which an aircraft carrier could be useful. One should remember, however, that the Department of Defence and the Australian Government were very reluctant about Australian military involvement in that instance and, furthermore, that kind of situation is most unlikely to arise again in the South Pacific. There are problems as New Caledonia approaches independence, but it is unlikely that the French Government and people would tolerate a repetition of their North African or Indo-Chinese decolonisation experiences.

The Committee believes that the capability for power projection into the south west Pacific islands should not be regarded as having a higher priority than capabilities designed to deter or meet threats to Australian territory. During its inquiry, the Committee identified deficiencies in other elements of our Defence Force which, it believes, should have a higher priority in the Defence Force development program. For example, the existing F111 force, and the projected FA18 force have a potent strike, including maritime strike, potential. That potential would be considerably enhanced if they could carry out strikes to greater ranges than can be achieved with their present fuel capacities. This could be attained by the acquisition of an in-flight refueling capability. Converted Boeing 707 aircraft would be quite suitable for this purpose.

A further capability which would considerably enhance the existing capability of elements of the Defence Force, would be an airborne early warning system against aircraft and surface targets. Used in conjunction with the Jindalee over -the-horizon radar system, such a capability, provided for example by Grumman E2C aircraft, would greatly enhance the effectiveness of other land and sea based units of the Defence Force. Airborne early warning aircraft, such as the E2C, are expensive and four to six of them would be required but the multiplier effect they provide to other capabilities would far outweigh their costs.

The Committee noted large gaps in military capable airfields in the northern arc of Australia. The airfield under construction at Derby will improve the situation in the north-west, particularly if its development is advanced rather than retarded. A significant gap will remain in the north between Darwin-Tindal and Townsville. The Committee received evidence that Gove and Weipa are under consideration as military capable airfield sites. The Committee supports the construction of an airfield at one of these sites, from which land based operations in the Arafura Sea and Gulf of Carpentaria would be facilitated. In association with Jindalee and an airborne early warning capability, there is a further urgent need to provide land based microwave radars. In respect of air defence, a microwave radar system is required to provide the necessary information relevant for the command and control of air defence. It is the Committee's view that this capability should extend across the sensitive northern arc of Australia.

Defence planning in recent years has assumed that the defence budget would approach 3 per cent of gross domestic product per year. Such a level of spending can be expected to continue while the current relatively favourable strategic environment obtains. If no aircraft carrier purchase is made, other measures to retain fixed wing flying skills of the fleet air arm are available. The Committee has expressed concern in the report about the viability of the fleet air arm if it operates only ASW helicopters. It believes that the fleet air arm has special capabilities in maritime operations which would be important to maintain.

The Government should consider the possibility of some or all of the Orion PC3 long range maritime patrol aircraft being transferred to the fleet air arm, as part of a maritime command structure. It should also consider utilising the Trackers, for their remaining life, in coastal surveillance tasks as they have a special capability in this regard and would be operated by dedicated, highly skilled professionals. At present, this valuable capability is not being used because 13 of the existing 19 Tracker aircraft are in storage.

In addition, the A4 Skyhawks will remain for the rest of their operational life , invaluable in providing a ground attack and maritime strike capability. In these roles, they have useful training and combat functions. They should therefore be retained in service as land based strike aircraft. In this way, experience in operating in a surveillance and combat role with the fleet will not be lost. Also, arrangements should be made to ensure that some fleet air arm pilots are familiarised with other aircraft in service with the Australian armed forces, so that broad experience in all aspects of maritime strike tasks is maintained.

Prior to being given the reference to inquire into acquisition of an aircraft carrier, the Sub-Committee on Defence Matters was conducting an inquiry into the total Defence Force structure. This force structure inquiry followed on from the inqiury last year which resulted in the report which I tabled on 24 November 1981, 'Threats to Australia's Security: their nature and probability'. The Sub- Committee will now return to the inquiry into force structure, and will pay particular attention to the problems of naval force structure which have been revealed by its aircraft carrier inquiry.

I was criticised by some Government members when I moved the original motion that this matter go to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Some Government members pointed out to me that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence operates in a bipartisan way and that the matter should have been discussed with it first, particularly as it did involve an important Government policy decision. I take that criticism on board. If this situation arises in the future perhaps I will take that course of action. I must say, however, that I am particularly glad that I did move the reference and that it led to this excellent report. I should not conclude my statement without thanking the staff who assisted the Committee, particularly its secretary, Robert King, and also John Needham. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to be said about this Budget is that even the words of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) this time hold out little hope for the population of this country. Over the years we have become used to rosy predictions in Budget Speeches. However, in the opening words of the Budget Speech this year the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The international recession is now hitting us hard. Our overseas markets have shrunk. Economic growth has faltered. Unemployment is rising. Inflation remains far too high. Interest rates are hurting many of us.

That is surely one of the most gloomy openings to a Budget Speech that we have heard for a long time. The Treasurer went on in his Budget Speech to talk about, amongst other things, the place of the world recession and the fault, as he sees it, of the trade union movement in this country, in leading us to our present situation. In relation to the world recession, he stated:
Our economic policies and relative energy endowments created a more favourable investment climate in Australia than in most other countries. This sustained our economic growth beyond that of others.

The implication was that now, because of the international recession, we cannot sustain that growth. I would like to point out that this statement in the Budget Speech is not true. First of all, we really should look at what has happened to our country so far as economic growth is concerned in recent times. From 1972 to 1975 gross domestic product per head in Australia rose at an average annual rate of 1.9 per cent. This was higher than for the average of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, which was then 1.2 per cent per annum. Since 1975 this situation has in fact reversed. In the five years from 1976 to 1980, the latest years for which OECD figures are available, per capita growth in Australia averaged only 1.2 per cent compared with 2.7 per cent per annum for the OECD area as a whole.

This, I suggest, is a disastrous performance for Australia and one which underlines the lamentable failures of the economic policies of this Government. Australia now ranks eighteenth amongst OECD countries in terms of per capita output, compared with fifth in 1950. So much for the claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975 that only a Liberal Government could properly run the economy and produce economic growth. In a period in which we have had conservative governments for all but three years we have in fact gone downhill. We have gone down the scales of these OECD countries. What policies does the Government now offer? What solutions to its failures of the past seven years has it offered? What lessons has it learnt from its past mistakes? From this Budget, it seems that it has in fact learnt nothing. It has offered more of the same old , ineffective medicine-screw down the money supply, keep demand low and keep up employment. I suggest that that is no solution at all. This Budget in fact holds out the abysmal prospect of no real growth in 1982-1983 and unemployment rising above 8 per cent, on the Treasurer's own predictions. Those measures in social security are aimed at relief for some of the disadvantaged, which we welcome, are too little in some cases and in all cases in fact are too late.

But the medicine this year is dressed up in a new bottle. The trade unions are to be offered a dose of Dr Fraser's elixir and asked to be good boys. They are asked not to worry that when the promised benefits will be taken away next year, which is what has happened regularly in the past. They are asked not to worry that Mr Fraser is notoriously incapable of keeping his promises in any case. They are asked not to worry that the living standards for families have fallen for all, except those on the highest incomes, over the last seven years. The Prime Minister now suggests that this year's Budget is an appropriate basis for co-operation with the union movement in achieving pay restraint, after seven years of trying to wield the big stick.

The Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, has consistently advocated an equitable prices and incomes policy as the basis for re-establishing a sustained progress toward real growth. If one makes international comparisons one notices that those countries which have in fact used this sort of approach rather than a monetarist approach have done better than we have. I think it is fair to say that most economic commentators now concede that such a policy offers really the only chance of avoiding the excesses of recent years, whereby the only policy for reducing inflation has been higher unemployment. Any easing of monetary and fiscal policy which usually occurs just before an election, has led to a resurgence of inflation.

What does the Government offer as a solution to this sort of impasse. While Mr Fraser and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) make overtures to the union movement, the Budget Papers are in fact telling a quite different story. I ask honourable senators to consider Part II of Statement No. 2 in the Budget. This is where we find Mr Fraser's and Mr Howard's real approach-the approach being urged by their Treasury advisers. That view is a simple and simplistic one. Essentially, restrictive demand policy will suppress wage fixation process. There can be no role for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, for industry or even craft-based unions. In fact when one reads the statements one wonders whether there is any role for unions at all . Page 53 of Budget Statement No. 2 states:

While trade unions originally, established to serve social purposes, their ability within a highly industrialised economy to negotiate wage rates across whole sectors of industry and to seek to have them adopted as legally enforceable minima poses basic difficulties for the efficient functioning of labour markets and hence for the restoration of price stability and full employment.

I suggest that such a comment reflects a rather naive notion about how labour markets might work in the absence of centralised wage fixation and about the likelihood of the union movement in Australia being willing to tolerate the wage inequalities between people doing similar jobs that would inevitably be exacerbated by a policy of industrial devolution like this. The editor of the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 23 August, noted:

. . . a concerted attack on unions is simply not compatible with a democratic society. The weakness of monetarist approaches to the control of inflation and wages is that they abstract from the political complexities of a democratic system.

The Australian Financial Review is not known for its radical views, nor is it particularly known for its support of Labor's economic policies. We have a situation in which the Prime Minister and his Industrial Relations Minister are in fact making placatory noises to the unions. The Budget Papers tell us a different story.
Even the Treasury has some doubts about its own prescription for wage restraint because, at page 52 of Budget Paper No. 1, the following statement is made:
. . . if . . . weakening in activity brought greater restraint in wage claims . . . it is more likely merely to be a recipe for stagflation.

This is apparently to be resolved by 'economic policies that consistently bear down on inflationary expectations', whatever that means in this context. However , it seems clear that the economic screws are to be kept on irrespective of the economic and social cost, in order to pander to some half-baked rational expectations theory being used by the Treasury in its latest rationalisation for a policy of doing nothing about unemployment. So much for the Prime Minister's talk about co-operation with the union movement. The fact is that Australia must find a solution to the evils of inflation and unemployment. It must ease the onerous burden, on the welfare dollar and the economy in general, of high unemployment and re-direct expenditures to improving rates and conditions. But punishing the unemployed is no solution. In fact, the unemployed must be put into jobs if one is to succeed.

A measure of the Government's seven years of neglect in the social welfare area , which is my particular interest, and its continuing economic failures, is that even an 18 per cent rise in welfare expenditure-more than 7 per cent in real terms-in the Budget fails by a wide margin to restore real rates and conditions to those which prevailed when the Government took office. The Government does too little too late and, in the words of the Treasurer, the prospects are bleak. More than 30 per cent of the increase in spending will be attributable directly to the payment of unemployment benefits, due to the parlous state of the national economy. That is based on the estimates provided in the Budget Papers of an average of 395,000 beneficiaries in 1982-83. But, of course, there will be more than that. Already the figure, this July, stands at 405,000. Who can believe that the number will actually decline over the next 12 months? Certainly not the Treasurer. A more realistic estimate, based on projected growth in the labour force and labour shedding is that in 1983 unemployment will peak at 8 per cent or 9 per cent of the labour force so the number of beneficiaries is likely to exceed 500,000 and to average about 470,000 over the year. On that basis, expenditure will rise by $300m over that predicted in the Budget Papers.

The largest part of the increase in spending on welfare, or some 40 per cent, will flow from automatic adjustments to pensions and some benefit rates. That, too, is a measure of the Government's economic failure and inability to restrain inflation. These adjustments will not make pensioners any better off. They will only compensate them belatedly for price rises that have occurred some four to ten months previously. They will not restore pensioners to the parity with wage earners that they achieved in 1975. At present the single pension stands at less than 22 per cent of average weekly earnings, compared with 24.5 per cent in 1975 . Additional increases of $7 a week for a single person and $11 a week for a married couple would be needed to restore that relativity-even more if the Australian Labor Party's objective of raising pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings is to be achieved.

Finally, we come to the areas of expenditure in regard to which there have been at least some real attempts to restore previous standards. Family allowances for first and second children are to rise by 50 per cent. Pension and benefit-free limits are to rise, as are fringe benefit income levels. We certainly do not oppose-rather, we welcome-that belated action. Supplementary assistance for those who are lucky enough to get the full rate will be up slightly. The single unemployed benefit for those who are 18 and over is to enjoy quasi-indexation, and be restored to half the married rate before again falling behind for another year. Even the young unemployed are at last to be thrown a bone-a $4 a week increase. Of course, we do not oppose those measures either. We merely wish that they would go much further. But even these measures in no way adequately compensate for past neglect. The apparent impression of overall generosity is soon dispelled once one realises that it is only a reaction to past meanness.

I ask honourable senators to consider these facts: The increase in the family allowances has failed to restore their real values, to those which prevailed in 1976. A shortfall of 18 per cent remains-a significant cost, some $10 a month, for a two-child family. The increases in pension free areas to $30 and $50 still fall well short of the actual parity with pension rates achieved in 1972- implying amounts in November 1982 of $77.25 and $128.80. The new fringe benefit income limits of $56 and $90 still fail to catch up with their real value 10 years ago when they were set at a rate equal to the then pension plus the free area. The $10 a week free area for adult sickness and unemployment beneficiaries is still only half the real value of the $6 which was first set as long ago as 1969. The new rates of unemployment benefit for single beneficiaries, $40 and $ 64.40, go nowhere near the parity with pension rates originally set in March 1973.

The Government has also introduced two new provisions, a family income supplement for low income families and a special rebate to remove from the tax net pensioners with small incomes. The latter is a reflection of the way the Government has allowed the tax threshold to decline in real terms since 1975-76 by its policy of non or partial indexation. In that year the single pensioner could earn $11 a week before tax was payable. In real terms that would now be $ 21. Since the proposed increase in the general tax threshold and the special pensioner rebate will operate for only two-thirds of the year, in 1982-83 a single pensioner earning more than about $16 a week will be taxed. This amount represents only half of the new free area for pensioners.

That leads us to the deceptive and misleading nature of the tables which were put out by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his statement on Budget night. Ostensibly, they were tables to show increases in the disposable income flowing form the new tax and spending measures announced. Tax assessments are based on income earned during the financial year, that is, from 1 July 1982 to 30 June 1983 in this case. The impact on disposable income of a tax change has meaning only in relation to its full year effect. If the change operates for less than a full year it must be apportioned over a full year to enable us to calculate meaningfully the effective disposable incomes.

In the Budget Papers themselves the tax scales for 1982-83 are a composite of new and old. This means that Senator Chaney's tables are meaningless. Worse, they are deceitful because they are not properly qualified. All of the tax impacts are calculated as if they applied for a full year, whereas they apply for only two-thirds of the year. By the time they do have full effect in 1983-84 , inflation will again have raised the real tax burden on families so that they are likely to be worse off rather than better off. It is also worth noting that the increase in family allowances will apply for only two-thirds of 1982-83. Certainly, disposable incomes will rise in November but on an annual basis, which is the appropriate basis on which to consider family allowances as a form of tax cuts for families, which they are, the benefits are rather less. By 1983- 84 inflation will again have severely eroded the net gain.

Finally, the new family income supplement which is also included in the tables will apply for only two months of 1982-83. I suggest that if the Government and the Minister for Social Security were honest they would ask the Department to recalculate the disposable income tables in a meaningful manner. The tables should show tax, social security benefits and net benefits as a proportion of income for both 1981-82 and 1982-83. The income levels chosen should be adjusted so that they represent the same proportion of average weekly earnings in each year. Then we would see how much is really going to families and pensioners. We would also see how much pensioners are losing as their pensions continue to decline in relation to average weekly earnings.

The Minister has described the increases in welfare expenditure in this Budget as representing 'particularly good value for money' since the initiatives included 'are designed as incentives to welfare recipients to improve their own positions and so become less dependent on government for direct assistance'. This just has to be a sick joke. When on the Government's own admissions unemployment will top 8 per cent or worse in 1983, when wholesale layoffs are occurring throughout the country, what chance for pensioners and beneficiaries, or anyone else, to improve their own positions? The Opposition supports these measures to help those with modest non-pension incomes but to dress them up in this spurious rationale is rather unconvincing, to say the least. It is particularly objectionable if it is used as an excuse not to help those whose needs are greatest, those entirely dependent upon pensions and benefits.

What do these people entirely dependent on such assistance get? They get no family income supplement; pensioners and beneficiaries are excluded from that. There is to be no increase in the additional pension or benefit for children. That has not risen since November 1980 and will again fall in real terms. There is to be no increase in the mothers/guardians allowance for single parents. That is also unchanged since November 1980. The overall effect is virtually to cancel out the impact of the rise in family allowances. A sole parent with one child gains $1.75 a week from the increase, but will lose $3.78 a week on the other children's benefits by the time the higher rates of family allowances are introduced. A beneficiary with two children will suffer a net loss of $1.60 a week.

The only real benefit for base rate pensioners is an extra $2 a week for those private renters eligible for the higher rate of supplementary assistance. On the Budget estimates only half of those now receiving supplementary assistance, or one in eight of all pensioners, will benefit from this measure. This $2 a week compares with a new tax rebate of up to $35 a week for those buying houses, irrespective of income or need. Widows and those on the unemployment benefit who are in the process of buying houses, having entered into mortages before they became disadvantaged, get no benefit because they pay no tax. So much for Senator Chaney's oft-stated commitment to help those most in need. Apparently different criteria of need are to apply to those not numbered amongst the undeserving poor.

The sole manifestation of the need-based welfare philosophy so long and proudly proclaimed by the Minister is the new family income supplement. But of course these families are very different from the wealthy home owners in the community. Their test of need is to be rather more strict; so strict, in fact, that many families below the poverty line will receive only a partial benefit and only something like one in 40 of all families potentially eligible will receive any benefit at all. The total cost of the family income supplement, estimated at $3. 5m this year and $30m in a full year, is only 1.5 per cent of the cost of an equivalent benefit payable free of an income test. That is a measure of how tight the family income supplement guidelines are. Restricting a benefit to those in need is one thing but making it so restrictive that almost no one gets it is another.

The full rate of family incomes supplement will be payable only to families with joint parental incomes below $184 a week, irrespective of their family size . Beyond that income level the supplement will be reduced by $1 for every $2 of income. By the end of 1982 the poverty line for a married couple with a head in the work force and two children will be about $195 a week. This line rises by roughly $28 for each additional child. It follows that families with two or more children and incomes below the poverty line will receive a family income supplement sufficient to narrow only half that gap, if that much.

Many low income families with a head in the full time work force will receive no family income supplement at all. Average weekly earnings for males stood at about $330 a week in June 1982. That they will be about $370 a week by the time the family income supplement is introduced in May 1983. Only about 5 per cent of full time male employees currently earn less than $220 a week. In no industry is the average minimum award wage less than $200 a week. To suggest that the family income supplement is for the working poor is clearly ludicrous. Only a government whose concept of need is quite out of touch with the reality of living conditions for ordinary Australians could introduce such a rigid needs test. Only a government steeped in hypocrisy could accompany it with indiscriminate handouts to wealthy businessmen and others in the community.

Of course, the Government and the Minister in particular have an easy and frequent response to criticism of the Government's welfare system. We hear that each dollar rise in the pension costs $100m. They ask where the money is to come from and how anyone else can do better. Never mind that the Government has now miraculously found $700m over and above inflation for welfare expenditure this year; something which, if I had suggested it two months ago, would have been severely criticised by those on the opposite side of the chamber. Never mind that the Government has suddenly found another $800m from the anticipated success of its anti-avoidance and anti-evasion measures. Apparently these revenues are available only to Liberal governments, not to governments of any other persuasion.

But of course revenues are available to finance welfare spending to look after those who cannot help themselves; revenues which even now the Government is forgoing to placate its business friends. Of course wasted expenditure could be diverted into welfare expenditure for those who really need help; of course the annual growth in taxation receipts allows the real value of pensions and benefits to be maintained; and, of course, economic growth, when it occurs-it should occur with sensible economic policies-allows rising real incomes to be redistributed to pensioners, beneficiaries and families without any diminution of the real incomes of those in the work force. It is the failure to achieve meaningful economic growth which is perhaps the greatest failure of this Government and a major reason that the welfare sector has been so savagely pruned over the last seven years.

The economic ineptitude of the Government has hurt social welfare in several ways. It has directly contributed to the rising numbers on the unemployment benefit, from 184,500 in November 1975 to a disastrous 405,000 in July 1982. That figure is still rising and probably will rise to 500,000, not on my calculations but on the calculations of the Treasurer himself. This factor alone can be shown to have reduced by $850m, on the official figures, moneys available for other areas of welfare expenditure. Rising unemployment has had another less publicised effect on the welfare budget. It has caused many women and older workers to drop out of the labour force and join the ranks of the hidden unemployed. Many have been forced by lack of work to take up invalid pensions, service pensions and other benefits apart from the unemployment benefit. In a recent study entitled Hidden Unemployment: The Australian Experience, Stricker and Sheehan conclude that the official Australian Bureau of Statistics figures conceal nearly half the total unemployed; people who have dropped out of the labour force because they simply have no hope of finding a job. They also note:

. . . the unemployment problem among older males has been almost entirely disguised by their withdrawal from the workforce, but especially in view of the bleak job prospects which many of these men have, this is a problem of the most serious dimensions.

Stricker and Sheehan estimate that of 112,000 hidden unemployed amongst males 45 years of age and over, two-thirds were drawing some form of pension and would not have been doing so if it were not for the state of the labour market. Including other groups affected, the overall cost of the welfare budget is estimated to be about $400m. That was in 1979-80 figures; it would be much higher now. A third avenue by which this slow economic growth affects moneys available for welfare is via its impact on taxation revenue. Economic growth raises real incomes, profits and expenditure. It automatically raises revenue from the income tax and other taxes. I am not referring to inflationary effects; I am talking about the real rises in tax revenues.

So we have come the full cycle. The Government which promised to increase growth, reduce inflation, increase employment and reduce interest rates in 1975 with the slogan 'Turn on the Lights', presides over a Budget in 1982 in which the reverse of all these things has happened and, on the predictions of the Treasurer, will continue to happen. Economic growth is lower than it was in 1975 . By all the parameters the Government set in 1975, it has failed. Having failed so comprehensively, it has lost its right to govern. After seven years of this Government, no prediction the Prime Minister made, no prediction made for the Government in those heady days of 1975, has come to fruition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The lights are out.
—As Senator Sibraa says, the lights are rapidly dimming and will soon be turned out. I believe that the electors will come to see that that is so .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this Budget will come to be seen as an economically responsible Budget which has had particular regard for low income families and low income earners, a caring Budget that has particular regard for families. The help that has been given for families will be welcomed by them, especially those most in need and on the lower incomes. The family allowance for the first child has been increased to $22.80 a month, and for the second child to $32.55 a month. A family with two children gains $18.45 a month. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) indicated in his Budget Speech that about two million families in Australia would benefit from this.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that is not the only benefit. The family income supplement is to come into effect later in the financial year. It is an extremely unsatisfactory situation when people in employment choose to give up that employment because they see that they would be better off on the social welfare benefits they could then attract. Any system which allows that must be condemned. The allowance which is to be provided in this situation is very much a step which ought to be taken.

Similarly, I think that a situation in which pensions are taxed is a waste of resources. We need to see that the supplements and benefits paid do not then have to be paid back to the Government, so that the expense of paying money out, on the one hand, and collecting it again, on the other, is avoided. To assist those whose income is about $9,500, the rate of $10 per week per child tax free will give people in that situation who have a job the ability to remain in the job and retain their self-respect, rather than feeling that they are forced to go into the welfare system.

Families will also benefit by the personal tax cuts, and the tax free threshold is raised now to $4,595. As a result, about 300,000 Australians who it is estimated now are paying tax will no longer be paying tax. With the standard rate cut from 32c to 30c, for those on average weekly earnings this means an extra $7.65 a week. From those three things alone, on average weekly earnings a family with two children will be better off by about $19 a week.

There are benefits to families in the mortgage deductions for home loan interest rates. The proposal effectively cuts interest rates by about 2 per cent by giving a standard rate tax rebate on interest over 10 per cent on mortgages up to $60,000. A person with a $30,000 mortgage at 15 per cent benefits by about $8.65 per week. I welcomed the announcement that no tax will be payable on dividends up to $1,000. This is a significant step in the direction of abolishing double taxation on dividends and is a significant amount. It represents quite some savings for a number of people, not only families but also pensioners. It is particularly relevant in the area of the old age pension, where people have saved to have something for their old age. It is quite reasonable that such money should not be taxed and that they should be able to get the benefit of their thriftiness earlier in their lives.

There are benefits in the education budget to low income families through the increase in payments under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and secondary allowances. The means test will be liberalised for 1983, and the income on which the test will now be made has been increased by 11 per cent to $ 12,248. The amounts payable to the students who then qualify for the loans have also been increased, both in regard to TEAS and to the secondary allowance. The details, of course, have been given, but again it is a significant benefit to families on low incomes who wish their children to remain at school or go to university or college. There are benefits for the single income family through the increase in the dependent spouse rebate to the sum of $1,030 per annum, and benefits to families with only one parent, the sole parent, are raised by nearly 75 per cent, as far as the rebate is concerned.

There are many instances in the Budget where the Government has clearly demonstrated its concern for families and the place they hold in the community and the fact that they are regarded as being the basic social unit which provides the best environment for children to grow up in. At the same time, the children's services program has benefited. The Opposition has engaged in scare tactics from the beginning of this year about the children's services program. When it was announced that the program would be reviewed, the Opposition took that to mean that it would be cut out or cut back. There was a demonstration on the lawns outside Parliament House at which the Opposition did nothing to attempt to allay this fear, and in fact encouraged it. As recently as the week before the Budget, again the same sort of scare tactics were engaged in to try to make people think that we did not care about the standard of care for children that is provided so well by so many of the family day care programs. There are increases in several areas-I shall not go into them in detail-designed to provide quality care for children and to benefit the families who need it. There has been an increase in the rate of subsidy for either low income families or single parent families who rely on the family day care service to enable them to go to work and be a part of the work force.

The November and May pension indexations will continue, there have been extensions to the eligibility for fringe benefits, and there is the $1,000 tax free dividend benefit to which I have already referred. There has been an increase in supplementary rental assistance. The income that can be earned without reduction is increased, something that many people have been advocating. It has not been increased for some time, and it is an area in which there was room for improvement. I welcome the increase to $30 a week for single pensioners and $50 for couples, and more if they have children.

The limit for fringe benefits for medical and hospital treatment, pharmaceutical benefits and telephone rental concessions, has been increased, and a pensioner can earn $27.50 tax free on top of the pension without losing those benefits. It is without doubt in the area of losing benefits that so many pensioners have serious worries and concerns. I guess there has to be a cut-off point somewhere, unless one is able to provide a universal scheme, and of course there are always grey areas. Considerable hardship can be caused when someone goes over the limit by as little as a couple of dollars but is then faced with the enormous costs that follow. Perhaps there needs to be a sliding scale by which pensioners, if over the limit, can purchase the pensioner card at some rate. This would enable them to have the slightly higher income, which otherwise would have precluded them from the benefit, but still have adequate health care cover at a rate they can properly afford. I certainly hope that that is a scheme we will be able to work towards. Of course, many of the 300,000 people who will no longer be paying tax as a result of the increase in the threshhold to $4,595 per annum are in the pensioner group. As I said, it seems absurd, for the amount involved, for pensioners to have to be paying tax on pensions that they have received.

Those comments refer to a few of the items that relate to families. Of course, the people in the national capital benefit from this Budget in the same way as people in the rest of Australia benefit. But there are some matters in the Budget which relate specifically to the national capital to which I wish to refer in order to show that the Government does care for this place and does have some regard for the place it has in Australia. The national capital symbolises Federation, the coming together of the States. It is a place which belongs not just to the people who live here but to the whole of Australia. I think, as I have said previously, that those of us who live here certainly enjoy doing so. But I think all of us realise that although we have our homes here it is a place that belongs to the whole of Australia and should be regarded as such . I regard the new Parliament House very much as one of the symbols of that Federation. I was certainly disappointed to hear the Australian Democrats attacking it as they did recently. As I understand it, it is on target as far as cost is concerned and on time as far as construction is concerned. I hope it will stay that way as far as both are concerned. It is providing significant employment in this town and I regard the attack upon it by the Australian Democrats as showing a complete lack of concern for employment in the national capital. Any suggestion that its progress should be stopped would interfere seriously with employment in the construction industry.

The Government has responsibilities in Canberra not only as the federal Government but also as the State Government and municipal Government. The House of Assembly has no legislative powers and is, to a very large extent, an advisory body. I think the Government has shown that it accepts its responsibilities of a State and municipal nature by what it has done in this Budget.

There is another aspect of Canberra which needs to be pointed out. We are regarded generally as an affluent community. It is a new community and being new , it looks clean and spotless, and it is. But that tends to be confused with affluence. I would concede that the figures show that 24.6 per cent of the population have salaries over $26,000 per annum. But at the same time 12.7 per cent of the population are on incomes below $6,000, as was shown in the last census. So the benefits to families and students to which I have referred are of particular relevance to a number of families in this community. I think it is necessary to repeat these facts so that the general attitude of regarding Canberra as an affluent and pampered community can be put into its proper perspective.

I think the Budget this year with respect to the national capital reflects the effort that the private sector has put into preparing papers for the Government to read and to understand, and to learn about the position of the private sector here. There are no natural industry or natural resources here and it is difficult to attract any industry to Canberra that needs to bring raw material here and take them away again. So the areas of technology and tourism are particularly important and as the city grows, of course, so is the building industry. The private sector is quite small and has suffered from a number of government cut backs over the last couple of years. The Canberra Association for Regional Development has been formed. This Association has put a number of papers to the Government, in particular the one that has been accepted and presented in this Budget. It was prepared at the initiative of the association and relates to the matter of incentives to enable the Canberra Development Board to compete with other States and regions to attract to Canberra the sorts of tourist industries and technological industries which can provide jobs in this community.

It is jobs that we need in this community. The Public Service provides jobs, but those of us who live here and have children here, are all concerned to have a more diverse range of jobs available that children can enter into and embark upon as careers. I would like to see the situation where no young person would have to leave Canberra to find the sort of employment that he or she would wish. It is by developing the private sector that we will create a more interesting community for public servants and their children and for those in the private sector.

In this Budget the Commissioner for Housing has been allocated $27.8m to provide housing. I have no doubt that that allocation will be taken up during the year. It will provide jobs in the construction of houses and it will enable a number of people to go into their own homes. In addition, there is a program for the construction of 300 government houses during the next financial year. On a smaller note, but significant, and in order to provide some immediate housing, the Minister for Housing and Construction will be able to purchase 20 houses for the welfare housing scheme.

In this Budget the tourist area has been looked after in a way that I regard as satisfactory, given the importance of tourism to Canberra. We are not in any sense competing with the sort of money that Singapore spends on tourism and, given our population, perhaps we cannot. But I think the success of Singapore as a tourist centre indicates what can be done when money is put into tourism. An amount of $504,000 has been allocated for promotion of tourism and $214,000 has been allocated for the opening of the Melbourne office of the Australian Capital Territory Tourist Commission. This is something that we have been looking for for some time and I certainly hope that the money will be available soon so that the office may be opened and operating as soon as possible. About 70 per cent of Australian tourists to Canberra come from New South Wales and there is undoubtedly a job to be done in attracting Victorians here as well. Another $30, 000 has been allocated on a dollar for dollar basis to the Canberra Visitor and Convention Bureau.

I refer briefly to the public works program. The budget for the National Capital Development Commission has been maintained and even increased a little. The Australian Defence Force Academy has the allocation to enable it to continue . An amount of $47m has been allocated for the new Parliament House, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation headquarters and a number of smaller extensions and alterations, mainly to the national monuments that make up the national capital. I certainly welcome the size of that allocation because of the need to keep a balanced building program going. It is important that the building program be consistent, that it does not continue on a stop and start basis, so that we can have a stable work force living here and so that jobs are available which will enable skilled tradesmen to move from one job to the next and not find themselves in and out of work. I think the Budget for 1982 indicates that this position can be restored. I refer in this regard to the establishment of the Cabinet committee for the Australian Capital Territory. Many ministries are involved in the running of the Australian Capital Territory, the Department of the Capital Territory being just one of them, but certainly a larger one. I think the setting up of this committee is important so that Ministers can evaluate the whole of the Budget for the Australian Capital Territory and not merely look at it-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — When the Budget was brought down just nine days ago it was hailed by those opposite as a family Budget. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) set the stage early in his Budget Speech by virtually describing it as a 'family Budget'. The Australian Labor Party has no argument with measures that improve the lot of Australian families. In fact, in our 1980 policy speech we mentioned this in quite some detail. The matter of families and relief for families was emphasised. I wish to illustrate this by quoting from the 1980 policy speech by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Bill Hayden, in relation to two statements-there were many more-that he made about families. In the very early part of his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we have to ensure is the economic security of Australian families . . .
Later on he said:
I make no apology whatever for the fact that our basic economic strategy is a policy of six broad programs to reverse the decline in family living standards.
These programs concern taxes, housing, jobs, petrol and energy prices, family health care, and family allowances.

Just two years ago that was emphasised in the policy speech of the ALP. We certainly support any measures which would improve the lot of Australian families. Apparently our remarks and policies have made this Government come to a realisation that Australian families must be helped. We have now had almost seven years of a harsh Fraser government. During that time the Government's policies have left many families struggling. To illustrate this point I outline some of the economic statistics which were issued on the eve of the Budget. I quote from a document entitled 'Round-up of Economic Statistics' prepared by the Treasury which, among other things, stated:

Preliminary national accounts estimates . . . suggest that, in seasonally adjusted terms, real gross non-farm product declined by 0.7 per cent in the December quarter 1981 followed by a further decline of 0.3 per cent in the March quarter 1982.

In other words, when the Government prepared the Budget it had to work with an economy that was moving backwards. There was no expansion in the economy. There was an actual decline. This was suggested in statistics suplied by the Treasury. Later on the document stated:
Retail sales, seasonally adjusted, declined in value by 0.9 per cent in May . . .
Again, the Australian economy had moved backwards. The document also stated:
. . . new motor vehicle registrations remain buoyant.

Because they remain buoyant, I suppose extra sales taxes were placed on them to put the motor vehicle industry into a decline, as has occurred in other areas of the economy. The document of the Treasury further stated:
In May, the number of building approvals for new dwellings fell by 7.0 per cent ; for the March quarter new dwelling commencements declined in number by 20.4 per cent.

With the rises in interest rates over which this Government has presided, and for which it is totally responsible, these trends are understand- able. The document showed that housing was on a decline when we went into the Budget. The Treasury document also mentioned employment. It stated:
Employment, seasonally adjusted, appears to have peaked in March 1982 and has declined by 0.4 per cent between March and May.
Now that we are in August we have subsequent figures to show that that decline has been a steady decline and is getting worse. In relation to unemployment the paper stated:
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate increased in June 1982 to 6.7 per cent.

Apparently, unemployment is now a massive problem in the Australian economy. It is with this type of economy that we came into the Budget that was announced just nine days ago. On reading that document it seems to me a shocking record for a Government that has been in power for seven years. I have been a member of parliament for those seven years. In fact, I came here when this Government came to power. Every year since then we have had a Budget in which we have been promised that things will get right. But the economy has become so bad that in this Budget the Treasurer has had to admit that things are not good at all and they will probably not get better for some time.

This Government came to office with promises of lower inflation, lower interest rates and lower levels of unemployment. What we have had in 1982 is high inflation, record interest rates and disastrous levels of unemployment. Against this background of abject failures after about seven years in power the Treasurer brought down what the Government regarded as a family Budget. But is it really a Budget for Australian families or is it a sugar-coated document which the Government will use later this year if it loses its nerve and goes to the polls? I suspect it was designed for the latter.

I intend to examine some of the ostensibly more palatable aspects of the Budget before moving to that part which is laced with castor oil or lemon juice or both . First I deal with personal income tax. We are told that there will be reductions in personal income tax. Of course any reductions in personal income tax would be welcomed. But are the proposed reductions as attractive as they initially appear in the Budget? The short answer to that question is no. In fact , the section on personal income tax in the Treasurer's Budget Speech is disgustingly misleading. I would have expected a Treasurer to tell the truth in his Budget Speech. Unfortunately, in this section of his Speech on personal income tax the truth is glossed over. An attempt is made to make the Budget appear better than it actually is. I will illustrate that point. When the Budget Speech was delivered we were told that the threshold of $4,195, before which tax is payable for pensioners and low income earners, would be increased by $400 to $4,595. For those people who may read Hansard later, I would like to mention that by using 'threshold' in this context, we mean the level of income which must be earned before tax becomes payable. I quote the section of the Budget Speech which outlined this aspect of raising the threshold. The Treasurer said:

This means that no tax will be payable until a taxpayer's annual income exceeds $4,595. As a result of this change alone about 300,000 pensioners and low income earners who would otherwise pay tax in 1982-83 will not now do so.

If we turn to Budget Paper No. 1 we see that a different story is revealed. Again, for those who may read Hansard, I mention that a series of Budget Papers are produced and Budget Paper No. 1 contains detailed information on the Budget and expands on the broad announcements of the Treasurer. An examination of Budget Paper No. 1 reveals that those who will not pay income tax in the 1982-83 financial year are not those with incomes of $4,595 or less but rather those whose incomes are $4,462 or less. In fact, those earning $4,595-which the Treasurer said would be the threshold at which tax would become payable-in 1982- 83 will pay $40.79 tax; not zero as mentioned by the Treasurer. As honourable senators may recall, I have just quoted the Treasurer as saying:
. . . about 300,000 pensioners and low income earners who would otherwise pay tax in 1982-83 will not now do so.

If, on looking at the detailed figures in Budget Paper No. 1, the threshold is brought into question, it probably means that we must query the position of the 300,000 pensioners and low income earners who, according to the Treasurer, would have had to pay tax if it had not been for the increase in the threshold. I attempted to find out some information to check this figure of 300,000 but it seems that sufficient information is not available to do that. It is most likely that it was a figure plucked out of the air. It might be correct, but once one starts to find figures in Budget Paper No. 1 which contradict the bland figures given by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech, one starts to question whether other figures are accurate as well. The Treasurer goes on to state:
Secondly, the standard rate of tax is to be reduced from 32 per cent to 30 per cent.

The clear implication in that is that taxpayers this year who are paying the standard rate of tax will be paying at the rate of 30 per cent rather than 32 per cent. But if we refer to Budget Paper No. 1 we see that for this year the standard rate is not 30 per cent. Because reductions will not occur until 1 November, the standard rate of tax for this financial year will be 30.67 per cent. Admittedly it is only 0.67 per cent greater than the 30 per cent the Treasurer mentioned, but it is an extra amount that taxpayers will have to find.

I could make similiar comments in relation to the Treasurer's statement about the increase in the tax threshold for the 46 per cent rate. The figures in Budget Paper No. 1 just do not gell with the Treasurer's statement. If I may be blunt, that part of his Speech which dealt with income tax is quite misleading. If I were less charitable I would use much more harsh words about the accuracy of this section of the Treasurer's Speech. However, I ask this: Why did the Treasurer not let his Budget stand on its merits rather than try to represent it as something better than it is? Obviously he was not too pleased with it. He did not want the workers, who are already paying more for beer and cigarettes, to think that they were receiving tax cuts when they really were not. Did he not want the housewives, who are already paying additional sales tax on a wide variety of items, to think too badly of the Government? Did he not want motorists, who are now paying 3c a litre more for petrol in Brisbane this week than they were last week-one cent of that is due to the additional tax and the other 2c was added because there was an opportunity to add something when the one cent tax was added-to think that they were receiving some relief elsewhere? The fact is that Mr Howard's tax cuts are almost as illusory as that fistful of fivers which featured in the Liberal Party's 1977 election campaign.

Having had a look at what happens to the actual figures when the thresholds are moved, it is pertinent to examine them in more detail. Mr Howard stated that the tax-free threshold increased by $400; that is, it went from $4,195 to $4,595. This is an increase of 9.5 per cent. Earlier in his Speech he mentioned that inflation was running at a rate of 10.7 per cent and average weekly earnings over the same period had increased by 14 per cent. Therefore, even if this new threshold that he mentioned is correct, taxpayers have not been afforded full indexation in respect of income tax. As it is, the real threshold-that which is in Budget Paper No. 1 for this financial year-shows an increase of about only 6 per cent, which is far less than the inflation rate. Thus taxpayers are now worse off than they were 12 months ago. Similar comments could be made of the threshold mentioned by the Treasurer for the 46c in the dollar tax payment. A close examination indicates that his comments do not reveal the full picture.

I will summarise some of the points I have mentioned regarding personal income tax. Mr Howard said that the tax-free threshold would be $4,595. For the 1982-83 financial year that is not true. The actual figure will be $4,462. Mr Howard said that no tax will be payable until a taxpayer's income exceeds $4,595. For 1982-83, that is not true. An income of $4,595 will attract $40.79 tax. The Australian Treasurer told the nation that the standard rate of tax would be reduced from 32 per cent to 30 per cent. In reality, the standard rate will be 30.67 per cent for this financial year. Mr Howard implied-I concede that he did not say so directly, but he certainly implied-that the 46 per cent tax rate would be payable only after earnings reached $19,500. In other words, he implied that until a taxpayer earns $19,500 he will be paying the standard rate of tax. That is not the case. Those whose incomes are between $17,894 and $19,500 will in the 1982-83 year pay tax at the rate of 35.33 cents in the dollar not the standard rate of tax at the old rate of 32 cents in the dollar, or 30c in the dollar, as Mr Howard suggested, or the 30.67c which will really be the case. The more we dig into the Budget Papers the more we find that the Budget will disadvantage the taxpayer. Various rebates will no longer be at a rate of 32 per cent but rather at 30.67 per cent for the current financal year. Amongst those rebates are rebates for health insurance, for concessional expenditure, and for housing loans.

I should like at this stage to turn to sales tax. In the context of the label given to this Budget of a family Budget-the more I look at it the more I believe it is an erroneous label-I must mention the sales tax measures. In last year's Budget Speech Mr Howard spoke of 'small adjustments' to the sales tax structure. On that occasion two and a half percentage points were added to all rates of tax . Two and a half percentage points sounds a small amount but it effectively increased some sales taxes by 100 per cent. Now the family man and woman must wonder where Mr Howard's 'small adjustments' will end. We are again having a two and a half percentage point increase applied to the various rate. Will there be another 2 1/2 per cent increase next year and the next and so on?

The story does not end there. Last year the Government decided for the first time to tax a wide range of goods at 2 1/2 per cent. That move failed. Now it is proposed that some of those items will be taxed, not at 2 1/2 per cent but at 7 1/2 per cent. What will the family man who wants to do some odd jobs about the place think about a Budget that taxes hand tools at 7 1/2 per cent? What will the housewife say about a 7 1/2 per cent tax on drapery, soft furnishings, manchester and even cleaning cloths? These people are hardly likely to endorse the Budget as a family Budget; nor will the person whose drink of beer has risen by 4c a glass endorse it as a family Budget. A glass of beer has risen by that much because we now have an incredible excise of 60c a litre on beer. It is not often realised how much excise there is on beer, but the excise on a litre of beer is more than the price of a litre of petrol.

A family Budget will not be the term given to this Budget by a one-packet a day smoker, who will have to pay an additional $50 a year because of a 20 per cent increase in excise. It may be thought that I am exaggerating by saying a one- packet a day smoker will pay an extra $50 a year, but if we work it out at 14c a packet per day for 365 days we will find that the cost comes to about $51. This is the extra amount a smoker will have to pay. He will hardly call it a family Budget. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.
