SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier I was talking about sales taxes and I had just about finished my comments on them. But I just mention that a value added tax has the same bad features as sales tax. At least with value added tax one knows how much tax one is paying. Sales taxes are more sneaky and often people do not realise that they are paying them. However, I believe that Australians are becoming more aware of this Government's actions, and the presence of these new and increased sales taxes in this Budget will be recognised by Australian taxpayers and consumers. While mentioning taxes which increase the cost of goods, I mention a particular increase in excise which will have a major effect on the railways of the State that I represent. No doubt it will have similar effects in other States. Until Budget night there was no excise duty on diesel fuel which was used off public roads. This meant that diesel fuel used by the Queensland railways was free of excise. However, in this Budget a change was made to make all diesel fuel bear part of the full rate of excise. Of course, there are some exceptions where certain groups can apply for rebates, but that does not pertain to the Queensland railways. What it means is that an additional cost of $12m a year will be payable by the Queensland railways. Obviously this will be passed on in increased fares and increased rates and, I dare say, may even have some effect on our export earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to social security. In comparison with the past six Fraser Budgets, this Budget has been more generous to pensioners and beneficiaries, but the past actions of the Fraser Government are probably not a good base on which a comparison should be made. For example, I remember that shortly after I came to this place-I had probably been here about four months-the Government showed it was all heart by attempting to abolish pensioners' funeral benefits. The major thrust of the increase in social security expenditure is in two general areas. The first is the automatic six monthly indexaton. This merely allows pensioners to catch up with past increases in the cost of living. They are certainly not getting ahead; they are just catching up. The second factor is the enormous rise in the number of unemployment beneficiaries caused by the Fraser Government's economic mismanagement.

I would like to mention just a few social security areas where I consider greater effort could have been made. First, despite regular increases, the standard pension rate has decreased as a percentage of average weekly earnings from just over 24 per cent in 1975 to about 22 per cent now. This decline in real terms should be redressed. Secondly, I mention supplementary assistance which is paid to the poorest pensioners, pensioners with no other income and who are paying rent in the private accommodation market. Although the Budget will allow up to $10 to be payable from 1 March, $10 a week will not go far towards paying rent. Obviously we need more welfare housing and higher rates of supplementary assistance. Unemployment beneficiaries paying private rent are still ineligible for supplementary assistance even though they face the same costs as pensioners in private rental accommodation.

Thirdly, the increase of $4 a week to the under 18-year-old unemployed is a paltry amount. It is the first increase in seven years for this age group. Just how far will a total of $40 a week go for an unemployed young person, especially if that young person has to live away from home? Many must live away from home, especially those from country areas who know that work is not available locally and who therefore move to more settled areas to seek work. I remember seeing the Treasurer (Mr Howard) address the National Press Club. In his address even he said that perhaps an increase should have been made to the amount long before now. That extra $4 a week will do little to ease the plight of many of these young people.

I would be remiss if I did not make some comments on the Government's proposed new tax on bank transactions. We do not have the legislation for this before us yet but it was noted in the Budget Speech that it would be introduced. This new tax is likely to prove to be extremely unpopular. Of course, few taxes are popular, but some are more unpopular than others. Whilst the Government uses its bank tax to increase its tax take by $200m a year, which is about $13 or $14 a year for each man, woman and child in Australia, the anger of the depositors will rise. There is likely to be a greater reliance on cash transactions with all the associated dangers of loss of money. This tax is likely to get the Government into more trouble than it has anticipated.

This Government was elected on promises to lower inflation, lower interest rates and provide employment opportunities for all who want to work. Despite those promises, and despite almost seven years of this Government's being in power, inflation has shown no significant movement over the past three years, unemployment has soared to record levels and our interest rates are higher than those of our major trading partners. A recent survey showed that consumer confidence has dropped to its lowest level in nine years. I mentioned that unemployment has soared to record levels. We might think it is at a record level at the moment but, unfortunately, there is every prospect of its becoming worse. When he addressed the National Press Club luncheon the day after the Budget was brought down in this Parliament, Mr Howard said:
In my own view, the total level of unemployment by the early part of next year will probably approach about 8 per cent.

It is a shocking record to think that we have had seven years of this Government and now we are approaching a record level of unemployment-a record since the Great Depression of 8 per cent. Talking about the Great Depression, I remember how when I was a young lad my father used to tell me stories about the Great Depression. He was one of the ones right in the midst of it. On one occasion I remarked that I hoped that such a depression would not occur again in Australia. He said that it was unlikely because governments nowdays know far more about economic management than they did in the 1920s and 1930s. Unfortunately, he did not make allowances for a dismal government such as the one that we have now.
It is hard to see this Budget as an instrument which will bring sanity back to the Australian economy. If it does not, the days of the Fraser Government are surely numbered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to be given the liberty of explaining why I was caught unexpectedly by Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) coming on. It was not listed on the original business paper for today, which I had looked at. The original business paper stated that after 2.15 p.m. a supplementary paper would be issued. SPEECH.PARA: There are seven areas of the Income Tax Assessment Act which are being amended by this Bill. They cover a wide variety of amendments previously forecast by the Government. They relate to the continuing tax-free status of the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island, donations to charities, Division 7 operations and, probably most importantly, some loosening of the restrictions under section 16 of the Act on the disclosure of information-a question which, of course, is now recognised as being far more important following Tuesday's tabling of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

It is important, as Mr Costigan has noted and argued in that report, to distinguish between privacy and secrecy. Individual taxpayers should have the right to have privacy from prying neighbours, journalists or whoever about their taxation matters but there is not and ought not to be an unlimited right of secrecy, of the withholding information from law officers of either State or Commonwealth government who require that information for the enforcement of the law. The only additional comment the Australian Labor Party has to make is that the amendments made so far have not gone far enough. It is something to which the Government ought to give quick consideration.

The final question to which I would like to devote a few minutes is the exemption for most of the last financial year from assessment as taxable income of the capital gain on maturing government securities. Ralph Willis made the point in the House of Representatives that this has not been a particularly important matter in the past because the actual yield on government securities and the contemporary market rates were not far removed from each other. In the last five years or thereabouts a large and still widening gap has developed between the rate payable on long term government securities and the prevailing market rate. There appeared to be some confusion within the Australian Taxation Office and the accounting profession as to whether such gains were taxable. It appears that some accountants at least and perhaps some people in the Taxation Office gave advice which indicated that such gains were not assessable as income . That was not the case, of course. They always had been assessable but until quite recently the question was not one of great importance. As a result of that confusion-perhaps one might even say 'misinformation'-the Government decided that for last year it would amend the Acts so as to exempt those capital gains.

It has been argued on behalf of those who were seeking such an exemption that the expectation that the capital gain picked up when the securities matured would not be taxable and that allowance was made by those purchasers for that expectation when the securities were purchased. If that were correct-the yield, of course, is the rate of interest in combination with the market price and the face value; it is a product of those three factors-and if the capital appreciation were anticipated as being tax free, the yield on those old, relatively low interest securities ought to be higher than on current new government paper being issued to mature on the same date.

It is a fairly complex question. I hope I have made it clear. I should like to hypothesise in this way: Suppose that in March of this year government securities issued 10 years ago with a 12-year maturity and an interest rate of 7 per cent were being traded on the secondary market those securities would mature in March 1984, two years hence. Suppose that also in March new government paper, tap issue, was being sold with a yield of 16 per cent to mature in March 1984. Indeed, that is approximately what the situation was. In those circumstances, if it were anticipated that the capital gain, which partly determines the yield on the security, would be tax free, the market yield for the long term securities which would mature two years hence ought to be higher than for the new securities which would mature two years hence. If that is not the case, the argument put in favour of the people who sought exemption of the capital gain from assessable income falls to the ground.

I have not had time to dig up a great deal of information on yields. But in May of this year tap issues which mature in February 1984-it has been difficult to find securities that mature on exactly the same date-were yielding 16.4 per cent , which was a combination of a coupon rate and a very slight discount on issue. Long term securities bearing interest at rates between 4.625 per cent and 9.5 per cent which mature in May 1984-that is not exactly the same date but I do not think that matters for my purposes-were yielding between 14.73 per cent and 15. 65 per cent. In fact, this was below the yield on new tap issue securities which matured on approximately the same date. The point I make is that although the time of maturity does not exactly coincide, I do not think one can assert unequivocally that no yield premium was being paid by the market for the old securities which were being sold on the secondary market. One can go so far as to say that it would be wrong to conclude that the long term low interest paper was actually being sold at a yield discount. There is certainly no evidence to support the belief that a yield premium was being paid by the market in anticipation of part of the yield being taken as tax-free capital gain instead of taxable interest.

So it seems to me that the rationale put forward to the public by those who sought the exemption given in this Bill falls to the ground. In any event, it is an exemption which is to apply for this year only. It is unfortunate that the situation arose. It would seem logical to oppose that clause of the Bill, but in view of the fact that it appears that inadequate, if not inaccurate, advice was given to some people by officers of the Australian Taxation Office the Opposition has decided not to oppose that or any other clause.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to discuss the plight of small business. The Government, in its recently announced package to industry, has undertaken some very meaningful measures which will assist business, especially business investment, in this country. However, because of the importance of the small business sector-those companies which employ fewer than 100 people-I believe that the Government has a strong obligation to do more, especially in the prevailing economic circumstances. There are in Australia 747,000 businesses which employ between one and 99 people . They account for 61 per cent of total employment in the Australian community. Some 700,000 of these business establishments employ between one and nine people . Collectively, they account for 37.7 per cent of all employment in Australia. They are concentrated mainly, I might say, in the areas of agriculture, the wholesale and retail trades and the construction sector.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia today many small businesses stand on the edge of a precipice. In 1979-80 more than 2,500 small businesses became insolvent-some 25 per cent more than the previous year. Unfortunately, this was due in part to circumstances beyond Australia's control-contracting world markets for Australian goods, global inflationary pressures and increasingly competitive imported products. Also small business is partly the victim of circumstances which should be within the control of Australians-rising wages, shorter hours and industrial disputes. In fact, if there were to be a change of government small business would also be subjected to a punitive increase in tax. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden ) the then Treasurer, made that point abuntantly clear in his 1975-76 Budget Speech when he stated:
It is not possible to provide more and more government services . . . without ultimately having to pay for them through cutting back after tax earnings via increased taxes.

That is a fundamental truth that I believe even the Australian Labor Party recognised when it was in Government. Australians will be very wary if suddenly the Opposition claims that those circumstances no longer apply. In the present economic circumstances especially, it is apparent that the Government should make further moves to assist small businesses whenever possible.

I wish to refer briefly to Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which requires that private companies distribute 20 per cent of their after-tax trading profits in order to avoid the imposition of undistributed profits tax amounting to 50 per cent of the undistributed profits. That provision directly affects the ability of small business to retain internally generated funds. At a time when interest rates are at a high level, small businesses can ill afford such arbitrary control of their capital. Where the provisions of Division 7 do not apply, a company can retain 54 per cent of its after-tax earnings at the current company tax rate of 46 per cent, but where those provisions are brought into play the proportion falls to 43.2 per cent. In effect, an additional 10.8 per cent of pre-tax profits is lost to the company when Division 7 applies.

The effects of this are graphically illustrated by a survey conducted by the University of Newcastle of 1,071 small manufacturing companies and 548 small non -manufacturing companies. Interestingly enough, 62.1 per cent of the manufacturing companies and 59.9 per cent of the non-manufacturing companies responded that the Division 7 requirement did not permit them to retain sufficient profits to finance their growth adequately. In the present economic circumstances I believe, irrespective of fears that companies may be able to use tax shelters, that it is essential for the Government to act to encourage investment by small businesses which will generate productive capacity and employment. I believe that it is not beyond the wit of governments then to legislate to ensure effectively that these concessions are not misinterpreted but are directed towards the purposes for which they are basically intended. Moreover, while I am on the subject of taxation I point out that the Government' s assistance package to industry, which I mentioned earlier, was well received in business circles inasfar as it went. But a survey by the Australian Industries Development Association made what is for the small businessman the following fundamental point:
Companies would not undertake major investment projects solely on the basis of taxation incentives unless they were fundamentally sound from other points of view.

The gross operating surplus of Australian companies during the March quarter of this year was only 12.3 per cent of non-farm gross domestic product-well below normal levels. In the last year wages, as measured by average weekly earnings, have outpaced prices. In 1981-82 average weekly earnings for males increased by 14.8 per cent while the consumer price index, which reflects not only prices but also the effects of government measures such as the recent health rearrangements , increased by 10.4 per cent. Clearly, the present economic recession is being borne by profits and not by wages. Therefore to expand, businesses, especially small businesses which have less capacity to generage investment capital, are forced into the capital market as funds dry up because of the profits squeeze. Of course once small businesses are forced on to the capital market they must face higher interest rates which act as a disincentive to borrow for expansion purposes. To that extent the Government must pursue for the sake of small businesses a policy aimed at curbing trade union demands for more wages and shorter hours and thus reverse the trend in declining profitability which producers in this country are currently experiencing.

One other aspect of taxation policy in respect of investment requires comment at this point, and that is the investment allowance. The investment allowance is due to terminate in 1986, following an inquiry into the matter. Of course its value has already been reduced. I do not suggest that we should go so far as following the example of the United Kingdom, where the entire cost of capital equipment can be deducted from taxable profits in the first year of purchase but I argue very strongly that some type of realistic investment allowance, as distinct from depreciation provisions, is essential to small business in Australia. It is one thing to allow depreciation over five years but in terms of encouraging small businesses with limited investment capital to make the initial purchase of new equipment, the investment allowance must be retained.

The last comment I want to make about taxation relates to provisional tax. I understand and accept the need for provisional tax and I would not go so far as to argue for its abolition in any way. On the other hand, there is no doubt that the present system makes heavy demands on small businesses, especially those in their first year of life. In that first year it really amounts to double taxation. In order to lessen the crippling effect which this has on developing businesses and to reduce the effects of removing potential investment funds from established businesses which have a successful year, the Government should immediately examine the idea of paying provisional tax in instalments during the year. That would reduce the debilitating sessional effects of provisional tax. It would reduce the need for small businesses to go into the capital market to meet their tax liabilities, thus releasing resources for investment in plant and equipment. In the final outcome government revenue would not be affected. Indeed , it could even act to even out the current flow of taxation into the Federal Treasury. I have no doubt that such taxation measures as I have outlined would be welcomed by small businesses throughout Australia. I have also no doubt that positive action by the Government to curb the new wages boom would be of vital encouragement to business. In the long run, action by the Government in both these areas would act decisively on unemployment and for those reasons it deserves real consideration by the Government.

Another area in which the Government can render substantial assistance to small businesses is in providing training and management courses which would be suitable for small businesses of various types. According to a report by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on small business bankruptcies, of the 2,408 cases of business failure in 1981, in 664 cases lack of business ability, acumen , training or experience was cited as the major cause. In other words, in more than 27 per cent of the business failures in 1980-81 it might have been possible for the Government to render assistance had it co-ordinated a national education program for small businessmen which was responsive to their needs.

Honourable senators will no doubt be aware that many of Australia's tertiary institutions do offer small business courses but they are in a generalised form and are not adequate or responsive to the needs of individual industry groups. It has been plausibly argued by Professor Meredith of the Financial Management Research Centre at the University of New England that such programs have little impact on small businessmen because they are generalities aimed at composite audiences of retailers, wholesalers, manufacturers, and primary producers, each of whom has quite distinct problems as well as general concerns which might affect them all. Part of the problem is that the Australian Government, unlike several other governments around the world, does not have the necessary mechanisms available to it to appreciate fully the problems of the small business sector. Japan, for example, has an annual review-an equivalent to the Australian Government's White Paper-of small enterprise development. The Small Business Administration in the United States of America performs a very similar function. The effect of that sort of arrangement is to formalise and regularise the works of committees of inquiry such as the Wiltshire and Ralph committees which occasionally inquire into aspects affecting small business.

Whilst not wishing to denigrate in any way the valuable work which these committees have done and will continue to do, I believe that there is a very strong case to argue that an area so important to the economy should receive inputs which are updated at least annually and can thereby enable more effective responses to small business problems. To revert to the example of education, which I mentioned earlier, it is reasonable to believe that such an annual review would have analysed the degree to which business failures are attributable to a lack of acumen and training, and could have recommended appropriate corrective measures. Using the research facilities which such a review group would necessarily have available to it, it could operate in an advisory capacity to small businesses, relating information on appropriate targets, performance figures and margins for the type of business being undertaken.

The Government might consider one other matter directly in relation to small business. It recently announced a strengthening of the Export Market Development Grants Scheme-a move which I commend wholeheartedly-to give greater encouragement to Australian industry to seek overseas markets. Naturally the scheme is highly beneficial for those small businesses which have a product appropriate for export since it encourages companies to consider exporting in the knowledge that some assistance towards defraying costs will be forthcoming. However, it must be acknowledged that a large number of Australian firms either do not have appropriate products for export or, for considerations of management or capacity, they are just not geared to export. In other words, these firms are locked exclusively into the domestic market. In this case the Government could well give some consideration to more definition in its procurement policies and practices, again in consultation with small business research groups of the type I mentioned earlier. At one level this could lead to a commitment by the Government to seek out suppliers from amongst small businesses wherever possible . At another level it may be possible actually to define a proportion of the overall amount of goods and services which the Government draws from the private sector and stipulate, in general terms or in more formalised terms, that Commonwealth departments should meet that figure, perhaps partly from small businesses, in their procurement programs. Small businesses would then stand to benefit by increased sales. I believe it would be especially significant for businesses which are located outside the major cities of Australia.

A final area of concern to small businesses throughout Australia involves those in areas outside major cities and ports. The problem involves sales tax on freight. Because of its sheer size, Western Australia is particularly disadvantaged in this respect and in the developing Pilbara and Kimberley regions it is a clear impediment to the development of warehousing businesses. The fact is that under the present sales tax legislation tax is calculated on the value of the article at the point at which it leaves the warehouse. Therefore, there is a difference in the price of an article leaving a warehouse in Perth and one in, say, Port Hedland. The difference is equal to freight and the tax on freight combined. Even assuming that the article is shipped from Perth to Port Hedland, the difference remains the tax on the freight component because tax is not charged on the freight involved in shipping after it leaves the warehouse. The operation of the Sales Tax Assessment Acts in this way reduces the ability of small businesses involved in warehousing in isolated areas to compete by creating an artificial price differential between goods shipped from Perth and those warehoused elsewhere. It can often be a very significant amount, especially given the high freight costs which are prevalent in remote areas. I therefore urge the Government to give this matter its most urgent consideration.

Small business is a major issue today in the sense that it is a most significant employer of labour and resources and must therefore be fostered. In some instances, in a sense, it can be fostered by government inaction, but not by pursuing policies in respect of public spending which will impinge on small businesses by necessitating increases in tax collections. However, I have outlined areas in which I believe the Government can make a meaningful contribution by its action, and I urge that these areas be given careful consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1982-83 Budget shows that the Fraser Government is on the run, scared, confused and seeking a somewhat cheap and easy way to try to win back some support amongst Australian voters. It must be said, a little over a week after the Budget was announced with a great fanfare, that the Budget has received a very unfavourable reaction. Some persons in a position to make judgments have said that it is too good to be true, subsequently saying that the Budget is not able to do what is needed in the Australian economy. Others have described it as rudderless, leaderless, disgraceful. I think the most famous statement that has been made in respect to the Budget was by Mr Risstrom: Whatever Canberra giveth, Canberra taketh away. That is clearly what this Budget does. It is a Budget that does nothing to assist the Australian people or the Australian economy to get back to a decent growth pattern.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when the Federal Government needs to confront the ever-worsening economy on the brink of both a national and an international recession, when it needs to promote balanced and broad economic growth, and when it needs to develop a co-operative and productive relationship with the trade union movement and the employers, Government has failed on all fronts. Furthermore, it has neglected the main victims of the Australian economic malaise-the poor, the young, and the unemployed.

Looking at this so-called parcel of goodies, let us see what the reaction has been. The business community has made it clear that it is not impressed. The wage and salary earners, through the national leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, are not impressed. The pensioners have indicated that they are not impressed. Certainly those on the poverty line and those who speak on their behalf have said that they are not impressed. The media, almost universally, have said that they are not impressed. The economists have said that they are not impressed. The banks are not impressed with the latest attempt to impose indirect taxes via the banking system. Certainly the State governments are not impressed, because they are not receiving adequate funds to carry out their public works responsibilities. Yet this Government has had seven years in which to take the essential steps to maintain living standards and a pattern of economic growth.

It is clear, from the Budget and from the discussions that have taken place, that this Government is on the run from the current economic situation. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) cries that he and his Government can do nothing about it, blaming it all on international circumstances-a factor that they were not prepared to acknowledge in 1973 when the first portents of the economic downturn on an international scale were visible. The Government is scared by the prospect that voters, the Australian people, will reject it. It is doubly scared by the coherent and committed alternative that the Labor Party offers. The Government is therefore confused. All it can offer is this mishmash of handouts and deception, while having no economic strategy whatsoever.

I stress that the Fraser Government has no economic strategy. Even Mr Fraser's mentors in the Treasury disapprove of his current approach, as a reading of the Treasury's statement in Budget Paper No. 1 shows. Its carping, critical tone makes clear the Treasury view that the Government has abandoned hard-bitten monetarism for confusion and, perhaps, electioneering. We must remember that when the Budget was framed there is no doubt that the Government had in mind a September election, but that has faded not only because of the Budget's unacceptability but also because of the grave crisis in which this Government has found itself as a result of the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Costigan report . Worse is to come for the Government when reports Nos 2 and 3, dealing with gun -running, the Nugan Hand Bank and organised white-collar crime, hit the light of day. The ACTU, which Mr Fraser has sought to buy off with this Budget, has summed up the situation well. When it met last week, its Executive stated:
If the Budget is mainly designed as a bribe to electors with a view to an early election then it is not just economically bankrupt but morally bankrupt.

Looking at the Budget in detail, we find that Budget outlays have increased by 13.9 per cent over those of 1981-82, which represents about 3 per cent in real terms; but Budget receipts show an increase of 11.3 per cent, or 0.55 per cent in real terms. If the outlay figures for 1981-82 are adjusted to remove the costs of the additional pay day last year, the rate of growth of outlays in 1982 -83 rises to some 15 per cent, and that for 1981-82 becomes 12.8 per cent. So in real terms the increases on this basis are 3.6 per cent in 1982-83 and 1.1 per cent in 1981-82. As a proportion of gross domestic product, the Budget outlays are projected to increase from 27.9 per cent in 1981-82 to 28.7 per cent in 1982 -83, reflecting the real growth in outlays combined with the expectation of no real growth in GDP. Receipts, as a proportion of GDP, are up too-to 27.7 per cent.

It is no wonder we find this confusion in the community and this criticism and non-acceptability of the Budget by an ever-widening group of people. The economy is on a downturn. Over the last month or six weeks we find retrenchments of a nature that one would not have believed possible. Interest rates in Australia are among the highest in the Western world. Consumer confidence is at its lowest point for many years. There are two million people in poverty. There is a crisis in housing. Generally, there is a lack of business confidence throughout the whole community, whether in the corporate sector or the small business sector. Even Senator Crichton-Browne has to concede that the small business sector is concerned about its future.

As the Treasurer notes, the deficit, while well above the 1981-82 figure of $ 549m, is still quite low by international standards. The Government's fetish with the deficit has fooled many. Many could easily be tricked into believing that this new Budget is stimulatory. It is not, as a look at the expectations for growth, employment and the distribution of extra funds quickly shows. For example, income tax receipts are up. Quite contrary to what the Government has tried to sell to the electorate, PAYE receipts are higher than they have ever been in Australia's history. As to sales tax, there has been an increase in the whole range of goods which are produced and sold to the average citizen. We now find that sales tax on some items is up to 32.5 per cent, 30 per cent, 27.5 per cent and 25 per cent, an increase that will bring in to the Government something in excess of $400m. While this is happening, company tax is expected, according to the Budget documents, to drop by one per cent.

Under this Government, which claims to be a low tax government, taxation revenue as a whole will rise by 10.7 per cent. Whilst this may be considered to be the smallest rise in four years, again one must be careful in analysing this, for it is principally as a result of economic stagnation and not the Government' s generosity that this position is arrived at. Let us look at the so-called hand -outs that we were led to believe on Budget night represented generosity. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have attempted to paint the 1982-83 Budget as a generous and indeed compassionate one. In the words of Mr Howard:

It was necessary to recognise that present economic conditions cause real hardship to many Australians . . . we have done all we can to provide relief, assistance and incentive within the confines of a responsible economic policy.

I suggest that he tell that to the two million people living on or below the poverty line, to the pensioners, to the unemployed, and to those people who find , when they go to work on Friday, that they receive a retrenchment notice dismissing them from a job that they have held in many cases for 20 or 30 years. The Government's figureheads have promoted the Budget as one of tax cuts, housing assistance, family welfare asistance and help to pensioners. If in fact the Government were really concerned about these matters it would have been prepared to accept what we have been saying about housing, which has been robbed of something like $1.5 billion in the seven years that this Government has been in office in respect of housing assistance to those on low incomes. So while the Government may have given a few more dollars to the States in respect of low income housing, look at the years of neglect and what that means in terms of providing for the needs of the Australian people. It has forced up rents, it has forced a housing crisis and it has forced even this Government, this measley- minded Government, to accept that something needs to be done in this area.

The Budget has the sort of promotion that can only be described as deceptive and dishonest. Observers out in the field have seen this; they have been quickly on the scene. They have noted that the hand outs are principally designed to win votes and that they are cancelled out by the increases in sales tax and extra charges and the effects of inflation. It is no good the Federal Government saying it is doing this in such a way as to give more money to the average citizen if in fact the very policies it is pursuing are forcing not only State governments but also semi-government authorities to increase charges, thereby depressing the living standards of the average person. Many of the so called hand-outs are inequitable in their effect. They benefit the middle to high income groups while doing precious little for the poor, and allow the tried and true formula of the Fraser Government's redistribution away from those in need to continue. As Senator Button pointed out yesterday, the Government's own adviser, Professor Mathews, has pointed consistently to the failure of this Government to understand and appreciate the need to distribute from the rich to the poor and not from the poor to the rich. This Budget of course continues exactly the same strategy in that respect, something which has been a feature of this Government's Budgets over the last seven years.

What is worse, underlining all of this, is the acceptance in this Budget of a no-growth economy and a no-growth concept. I cannot stress this too greatly. No growth in the economy will benefit no one, least of all the poor and unemployed, because no growth means no jobs. That is what it means, in practice and in theory. Yet it is not growth, stagnation, that is accepted as the very basis of this Budget for the year ahead. As the Australian Financial Review stated, it is a Budget of 'handouts, but no real aid for the economy' and that means no real aid at all.

Let us turn to the income tax changes. Welcome as they may be in some respects, and we do not criticise the fact that there have been some income tax changes, in many respects they are inadequate. Those who benefit most are those earning between $340 and $460 per week. But is that the real group which needs assistance? Whilst we do not criticise that they are getting assistance, it is clear that those on average weekly earnings of about $330 per week and the 60 per cent of the people who get less than the average, are the ones who need this sort of assistance. They are the people that this Budget does not give any consideration to. Just in case people might think they are getting off easy this year, let us remember that income tax receipts from individuals now amount to 14 .3 per cent of gross domestic product, which is up nearly 5 per cent on the 1972 -73 Budget figure. In that same period, company tax as a proportion of GDP has declined. As we have seen over these last few days, as we look at the major tax avoidance industry, the growth industry in this country, largely aided and abetted by the indefference of this Government, company taxation, as a percentage of both GDP and federal revenue, has declined, whereas pay-as-you- earn tax, which taxes the average person, has increased considerably. Income tax from individuals now amounts to about 52 per cent of all receipts, while in the last Labor Budget of 1975-76, that figure was 45 per cent. So let us not have any illusions at all that the Liberal Party is not the high tax party, Under the Liberals it is the ordinary individual who has been forced to tighten his or her belt and contribute, whereas corporations have got off much more lightly. When we add to that the increase in indirect taxation, the fuel tax, the tax from beer and cigarettes and the sales tax to which I have already referred, we can see that there will be an absolute confirmation of the survey carried out over the last few months into why consumer demand is at an all time low. The general 2 1/2 per cent sales tax rise will increase the cost of thousands of items, most of which are used in every day life and consumers therefore will be paying in addition to the higher proportion of PAYE tax an extra $400m in sales tax charges.

New taxes have been introduced by this Government. There is a new tax on bank transactions which will hit cheque account users and small businesses in particular. One can imagine what that will do to small business and the ever increasing number of ordinary citizens who have the use of cheque accounts through their trading banks. In addition the big changes in excise rates for beer, tobacco and petrol will add many dollars a week to household costs.

It has been said by the spokesman for the Government that the 1982 Budget will help the housing sector. We say that it fails to provide the housing sector with the stability it requires to achieve an adequate supply of housing to meet social needs, to contribute to employment growth and to assist economic recovery . Housing inequalities obviously will be widened. Housing finance will be dearer and more volatile, rents will rise, housing insecurity will increase and suffering will increase accordingly. Labor has grave concerns about the equity and effectiveness of the rebate. Any person buying a home to live in can now obtain a rebate of 30c in the dollar on his or her interest payments over a rate of 10 per cent of loans to $60,000, no matter what the income or the source of loan. The rebate will be a hand out to many who do not necessarily need the sort of assistance which has been given at the expense of taxpayers in general. The rebate will encourage the growth of fringe lending institutions charging exorbitant rates of interest to people desperate for a home, and who have been rejected by banks and buiding societies. More people will be put at risk, we believe, because there is no way in which the Government can monitor those organisations and the rates of interest charged by them to those seeking a loan. Housing initiatives in this Budget are a good example of the ad hoc and electorally opportunist way in which the Government has approached things. The problems of interest rates is not addressed seriously and in fact the Government has no policy to contain interest rates. Just a one per cent increase in interest rates can easily wipe out the benefit of the rebate to most of those who would recieve it. Of course, the Budget ignores completely the problem of the renters. Renting costs are a major problem in our capital cities and in my own city of Sydney. Rentals, which are currently rising at an annual rate of about $10 per week at the lower end of the market, will continue to rise and continue to cause hardship. The crisis of homelessness which is now recognised by everybody associated with welfare and the housing industry will remain with us and sub-standard housing will continue to be one of the alternatives. Advances to the States for housing are estimated to be $290m-less than one-third of the amount provided in the 1974-75 Labor Budget when we sought to redress the grave difficulties of housing that faced us then. Today, eight or nine years later, the situation is many times worse.

Let us look at family allowances, which are supposed to be one of the goodies in this package. The raising of the family allowance for the first and second child is welcome. The last change was in 1976, which is six years ago. However, the failure to alter these allowances adequately through indexation means that since 1976 the Government has withdrawn from the family $396m. The Government is only paying back in one short year a small part of the great amount of money that has been withdrawn from the families which need it. Furthermore, the special family income supplement for low income families is to be extended to only a very few, unfortunately, also on a very restrictive basis. This compares unfavourably with the handouts that are clearly in the Budget for the more well off.

Those on the unemployment benefit will receive increases, but the most helpful assistance they could get would be a job. There is absolutely no hope in this Budget for those who want to work. The Government has indicated that it does not see any possibility of any improvement in the employment position. The Treasurer expects that well over half a million people will be unemployed in the coming year. The Department of the Treasury has said:
There is unlikely to be any growth in employment.

The future of those people looks bleak. That is a state of affairs which the Opposition finds completely unacceptable. The health budget is up by some 16 per cent. This disguises the marked reduction in health advances by the Commonwealth to the States. Advances to the States for health are down by $153m, or 20 per cent, in real terms. What are the States being forced to do? They are being forced to increase their charges in the whole area of hospital care. As a result the hospital contribution funds, such as Medibank, are being forced to increase their fees. It was reported in the newspapers either yesterday or today that they will have to increase their fees by something in excess of $2 to $3 a week. Mr Howard suggested that this was a family improvement Budget, but when one examines the figures, one discovers that nobody will be any better off.

In the other areas the allocation story is much the same-steady allocations with marginal benefit and some redistribution away from those in need. For example, there will be greater funds for private schools in that the Commonwealth Government allocation per private school pupil equals $596 a year and per government school pupil $261 a year. This Government defends that inequality.

Beneath the surface of the few goodies which are dished out in the Budget there is a confused and essentially abstentionist approach to economic policy. The approach is abstentionist because it avoids the major problem facing the Australian economy. It seeks to place the blame and the responsibility elsewhere -on the international economy and the wage and salary earners-while doing nothing about the problem.

The Budget is based upon the assumption that unemployment will increase in the coming year, that there will be a major slowdown in the economy and that inflation will continue to run at least in double figures. Yet nothing is proposed to redress these problems. In the Treasurer's Budget Speech one will find nothing except a call for wage restraint which is repeated ad nauseam. That is what Government speakers say whenever they talk about the Budget. Beneath the vacancy of Mr Howard's contribution, the Treasury, no doubt through the agency of its boss, Mr Stone, keeps peddling the same old nonsense. Yet now even its contractionary monetarism is wearing thin.

The Treasury offers a formula, once again, of restrictive fiscal and monetary policies combined with wage reductions. The Treasury praises the contractionary policies of the United States of America and United Kingdom governments, yet at the same time blames the international recession, which is evident in these countries, for our domestic problems. It does not make sense. If the restrictive policies being employed in the United States and United Kingdom are working, why are their economies not emerging from recession? Of course, the Treasury as always, stumbles past this lapse in logic. Neither does the Treasury provide any evidence to support its assertion that our wage levels, labour costs and prices are making our exports unacceptable. It states this as a bald fact in the Budget Papers. Yet it produces no evidence at all to support the claim that this is the reason for the downturn in export prices.

The facts of the matter are that the restrictive policies being employed abroad are choking off growth, thus prolonging and deepening the recession. To pursue a similar approach here, as the Treasury would want, in our view would be pure disaster. For the moment, as we have seen, the Government has backed off from harshly restricted policies. It has made some handouts to ease the burden for some. Yet it has done this in such an ad hoc way that the overall benefit to the economy will be minimal. Further, when its period of electoral flirtation has passed, and we believe it has passed, the Liberal-National Country Party Government-if it is still in office-will be forced to take back what it has offered, as it has done in other pre-election and post-election periods. Whatever remains of the tax cuts, the rebates and the concessions will be swept away. I am convinced that the Treasury line will prevail. We get a glimpse of this with the Government's current wages policy. When the smokescreen of the small '1' liberal approach of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Macphee, clears away, one will see the Treasury line through and through.

If there is any strategy at all in this Budget it is an industrial strategy. This strategy is a direct response to the very positive and responsible initiative of Labor's prices and incomes agreement with the trade union movement . The Liberal Budget strategy revolves around wages. Here the Government and the Treasury agree. They believe that so-called wages growth is the key problem of the economy; therefore, in their estimation, cutting wages is essential. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, makes this point over and over again in his Budget Speech. The basis of the Government's position was summed up early in the Budget Speech made last Tuesday week as follows:

Adverse international influences were compounded by a significant worsening on the domestic wages front. The need for maximum wage restraint has therefore been much in the Government's mind in framing this Budget.

Treasury's contribution adds to this in detail with a long diatribe about labour costs and the need for decentralised wage determination. The Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, fleshed out of the Government's approach still further in the days following the Budget. He explained that he believed the Budget contained very substantial assistance to families. He said:
It is reasonable to expect that these things will be taken into account.
Further he said:
It would be reasonable to expect a degree of wage restraint.

The approach of the Government is confused and contradictory, but in essence the Budget seems to be to limit Budget handouts, especially in the form of income tax cuts and increased family allowances in return for union agreement for wage restraint. Secondly, underlying that 'sweets from a stranger' approach is the view that record unemployment will force the trade unions into a corner. Thirdly , there is a fragmenting and breaking down of Australian industrial relations to the point where, in John Howard's words 'there is a more market responsive system of wage determination which could help produce wage outcomes closer to that of individual firms'.

In short the Government wants created a situation in which it can cut wages and reduce the living standards of the bulk of the people. That is not what is required in the context of the Australian economy. We want to boost growth and consumer demand. We want to see increasing living standards. I believe the Budget fails dismally to produce that sort of economic environment in Australia.
