DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke on this report on Tuesday I pointed out that I thought the events that were occurring in Namibia were linked with those in Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. I said that all of the countries in that region were involved in a power play between the super- powers -the United States of America on the one hand and the Soviet Union on the other hand-and also that the policies of South Africa itself were playing a very important role in that area. It is unfortunate that when we, in Australia, get reports of southern Africa they tend to be bad news; whether they are from people like Peter Younghusband in Cape Town, who reports in the Sydney Morning Herald, I think, Newsweek and other magazines or whether they are like the recent article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph on Zimbabwe. The Press reporting in Australia of events in southern Africa tends to be very bad indeed. I certainly do not want to play down the situation of some Australian tourists in Zimbabwe. Unfortunately, these tourists are still missing and I certainly hope that the army and the police there are able to secure their release in the near future.
—Senator, the newspapers here will not print articles favourable to Zimbabwe. I found that out to my cost.

—I am glad to hear Senator Missen say that some newspapers here will not even print articles on Zimbabwe if they contain good news. That does not surprise me at all, because one has only to look through the Australian Press any day of the week to see stories about riots in Bombay-where thousands of people have been injured-about the 200 killed the other day in riots in Lima or about tourists in trouble everywhere. Yet if anything happens in southern Africa or to any Australians in that area, the reports appear on the front pages day after day. We even had the situation here recently where one honourable senator by way of a question, said in this place that there was a North Korean brigade in Zimbabwe and that it was about to move on the capital Harare. In fact , a number of members of parliament who have recently been in Zimbabwe were able to check this out. The truth is that North Korean military instructors were instructing the fifth brigade in the Zimbabwean Army. The country is non-aligned . I do not think there is anything wrong with it inviting North Korean military instructors because it in fact invited Australian and British military instructors too. We were told there recently that in fact there are about 12 North Korean military instructors left in the whole country. There would be equally that many Australians and, in fact, there are 90 British military instructors still taking part in the integration of the armed forces in Zimbabwe . I think it is extremely unfortunate that none of the countries in southern Africa, with the exception of South Africa, have high commissions in Australia. Because countries like Kenya, Zimbabwe and Zambia do not have high commissions or diplomatic representatives here, I think the information that we get is very sketchy and very poor indeed. I hope that this will be remedied in the near future. Apparently Zimbabwe will open at least a Press office in Australia and the Zambians have said that they will have a high commission here within the next 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: There are worrying signs in Zimbabwe at present. Curfews have been imposed. Banditry has increased in some sections of the country. Very worrying claims have been made by Prime Minister Mugabe to members of this Parliament that South African military subversion has taken place in his country. It did not suprise me at all to learn this week that he claimed that three South African troops had been killed about 40 kilometres inside Zimbabwe. There has certainly been subversion in his own security forces and in his own air force with the recent blowing up of four aeroplanes near the capital, Harare. Also 1,200 to 2,000 of Nkomo's troops, who were integrated into the army, have left with their arms. Quite obviously they are involved in some of the civil disturbances and unrest that is taking place in that country today.

I think that we in the West have no option at the moment but to continue our aid and assistance. I think that given the problems that that country has faced since independence, Mr Mugabe has done a marvellous job. One does not have to be there very long to realise the tremendous problems that he has faced. The people 's expectations, for a start, were tremendously high. Like all of us, Mr Mugabe is a politician. He realised that the people expected schools to be built, roads to be made and the standard of living to increase dramatically. Of course, that is not always easy. The white community in Zimbabwe expected the very worst to happen, and that has not happened either. As I said, I am concerned about the future because I believe that before things get better in that country, Mr Mugabe will have to crack down harder, especially on Nkomo and his people, than has already taken place.

Perhaps the country with the most important role to play in the whole area is South Africa. Some helpful signs have come out of that country. President Kaunda has held talks with South African Prime Minister Botha recently. Obviously they were discussing Namibia and a settlement there. I believe there will be a peaceful settlement in Namibia. It could lead to better economic conditions in Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. If we can get a peaceful settlement in Namibia it will go a long way to solving the economic problems of those countries and a long way to solving the transport problems of the area. This will be just a start.

The economic conditions that these countries find themselves in at the moment are very worrying indeed. The price of fuel is horrendous. A lot of the countries do not have any oil reserves at all. A country like Kenya, for example , last year spent 65 per cent of its foreign currency earnings on buying oil and oil-related products. The price of copper is down. It is now costing a country like Zambia more to produce the copper than the copper is worth on the world market. The countries in the area are facing horrendous economic problems. They can be helped only by a peaceful settlement in Namibia.

I have used up practically all my time on this debate. I did not want to pre- empt the debate of the parliamentary delegation that has recently been in southern Africa, so I confined my remarks to Namibia and countries that have a bearing on it. Australia does have a large involvement in the area. We played a leading role in bringing about a peaceful settlement in Zimbabwe. We stand prepared to play a similar role in Namibia and I would hope that in the near future, within this chamber, we will be able to have a full debate not only on our parliamentary delegation's report on southern Africa but also on the problems of southern Africa generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a short contribution to this debate in the time available, partly as a member of the Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs and Defence which produced the report on Namibia and also as a member of the parliamentary delegation to which Senator Sibraa referred, it having just recently visited some of the front line states and held some discussions there on the subject of Namibia. The report traces the history of South West Africa, or Namibia, from pre-World War I to today and traces its tortuous path towards independence-what some might call liberation. The report brings those who read it up to date on such developments. It also traces the role that Australia has played and details our current position and policies on Namibia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's role was to monitor and report, and this is what it has done. It does not reach profound conclusions; rather it finds itself generally confirming the Australian Government's policy and our contribution in the region . It is important to appreciate that we are not the principal player on this particular stage. It would be impossible for us to play a mediating role in view of our relationship with South Africa. The principal players are rather the Republic of South Africa, the South West Africa People's Organisation, the Group of Five, the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, and the frontline states. Nevertheless, we do have a significant responsibility.

We were pleased in Africa, when speaking to people such as Prime Minister Mugabe, President Kaunda, and President Moi of Kenya, to hear the laudatory terms in which Australia is spoken of and particularly the high praise that is given to our Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). How has this come about? It has come about, firstly, because of the role we have been prepared to play in seeking independence for colonised peoples throughout the world, particularly in Africa, evidenced by the contribution of our Prime Minister at the 1979 Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Lusaka in relation to the Rhodesian problem. Secondly, it has come about because of our attitude in relation to the North-South dialogue, the transfer of resources from rich to poor countries, that is, from the developed to the developing and undeveloped. That has given us a particular responsibility.

How does that apply to the particular problem of Namibia? It means that we have a role to play, firstly, in bringing Namibia to independence. That is now inevitable and has been accepted by all countries, even by South Africa since about 1977. This acceptance has come about, and I think has escalated in recent times, partly, as Senator Sibraa mentioned, because of the economic consequences to the frontline states of a continuation of the dispute and fighting, and partly because South Africa is now finally counting the cost of its involvement in Namibia. So we have that role to play in bringing the country to independence . Even more importantly, we have a role when Namibia is brought to independence of assisting it in its formative years. I suspect this will be a period of great strain, particularly in view of the general economic strife, evidenced by record low commodity prices, with which the whole of southern Africa is presently faced .

I would like to deal briefly with those two points. Firstly, let me deal with our role in the independence process. Our policy, which has been applied consistently, supports efforts to achieve a peaceful transition to independence. In May 1978 Mr Peacock, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, said:
We support all attempts to find peaceful solutions based on the principle of majority rule and human rights for all.

Basically, that remains our policy today. Although we were a party to General Assembly Resolution 31/146 of December 1976, we have since then not supported United Nations statements which accept SWAPO as the sole and authentic representation of the Namibian people. We have, and I would submit realistically , accepted SWAPO as a major and authentic representation of Namibian opinion. I think this highlights the fact that there has been some intransigence by South Africa, but the intransigence of the United Nations has not helped in some areas . Clearly, SWAPO is not the sole representative of the views of the Namibian people.

We have also not been prepared to agree to United Nations resolutions which have supported the armed struggle of the Namibian people. I applaud that. We are opposed to the use of force in resolving international conflicts. Again, it does the United Nations no credit when it advocates forceful resolution of internatioanl situations. We, of course, are not prepared to contribute militarily to liberation organisations. We have accepted the opinions of the International Court of Justice and therefore see South Africa's occupation of Namibia as illegal. At the same time, we support the United Nations settlement proposals that are contained in Resolution 435 and the work being done by the body described as the Group of Five, or the Western Contract Group. As such we have indicated that we would be willing to contribute to UNTAG, the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group, and I applaud that statement. I have said before in the Senate that I believe Australia must be prepared to meet its international responsibilities and play a part in United Nations monitoring, peacekeeping or transition forces, as we did in Zimbabwe and for which we received considerable credit, and as we are prepared to do in Namibia.

There remain several other hurdles in achieving independence. Walvis Bay is one . It is unrealistic to treat the one deep port in Namibia, 600 miles from South Africa, as remaining part of the Republic of South Africa. Australia should stand by the statement it made in the past, and I believe repeated, that because of moral and pragmatic considerations Walvis Bay should form part of a united and independent Namibia. It will otherwise simply remain a festering sore that, after independence, must lead to further destabilisation.

There is also the hurdle of the method of election. Although I can understand South Africa and the USA looking at ways to attempt to protect minority interests within Namibia, it is nevertheless impossible to attempt to do that by methods of voting and methods of election which as the one man-two votes or the one vote counted twice methods, which simply are going to be beyond the comprehension of the people of Namibia. Therefore, I cannot see that security can be offered by any more than that which SWAPO is prepared to accept, and that is a proportional system of voting. The other matter that is of so much importance is the problem of Cuban troops in Angola. I believe that, to be consistent with the principle for which we strive with respect to independent countries, that is, their complete sovereignty, we cannot maintain that troops in one independent country can be a limiting factor to the independence of a third country. Therefore, I support the Committee's view that this should not be a prerequisite to independence of Namibia.

I would like to deal very briefly with the second area, and I refer to our responsibility for post-independence in Namibia. It is interesting that Marxist states such as Angola and Mozambique are finally making overtures to the West. They are being let down by the Soviets in the area of economic development, which they regard as critically important, I think this gives a tremendous opportunity to the West to develop these countries in a way that will lead to the stabilisation of the whole region. The economic position in southern Africa is going to be most difficult. It is going to be a time of great trauma for Namibia when it finally becomes independent. Therefore, I believe that Australia must accept its responsibility to give aid, which will result in greater stabilisation of the whole area and therefore be a further small contribution towards world peace.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon I tabled the report of the Senate House Committee in relation to the Joint House Department and gave a tabling statement on behalf of the Committee. At that time I sought leave to continue my remarks. The remarks I now wish to address to the Senate are opinions of my own. I indicate that they are not necessarily the opinions of other members of the Committee. I seek the opportunity to give my own individual opinion on the matters raised in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say first of all that there was some controversy relating to whether a Senate committee ought to undertake this inquiry, and suggestions have been made that there is somehow some lack of legitimacy to the inquiry because only a Senate committee was looking at this matter and not a House of Representatives committee. I totally reject that point of view. In the tabling statement and in the report the Committee gives its view in relation to its right to undertake an inquiry which is of interest to members of the House of Representatives and to senators. In that regard I point out very briefly that a House of Representatives committee is currently looking at the issue of whether Ministers from one chamber ought to appear before the other chamber in order to answer questions at Question Time. That House of Representatives committee invited submissions from senators as well as members of the House of Representatives because that is an issue which would interest members of both chambers. I believe that at least one senator has made a submission to that House of Representatives committee on that matter of common interest.

There is no reason that one chamber cannot carry out inquiries which are relevant to the interests of members of both chambers. Nevertheless, I am disappointed that a number of members of the House of Representatives took this point of view and were encouraged to take this point of view. I do not think that the inquiry of the Senate House Committee was diminished. A number of members of the House of Representatives, as well as individual senators, sought to meet with the Committee and to express an opinion in relation to the Joint House Department. Nevertheless it would have been useful if those members who wrote to me as Chairman of the Committee indicating that they had points of view , that they would put to a joint committee, had in fact put them to the Senate Committee. I hope that the fact that their points of view were not put, will not in any way diminish the conclusions of the report.

An issue to which I would particularly like to refer is the question of the role of the Presiding Officers. The Committee recommends that the Joint House Committee ought to be given some executive power in relation to policy. I am aware that that is an opinion which will be rather strongly disputed by some people. I think it relevant that I point out some sections of the report that might clarify matters which have already been confused. It has been already claimed that to give executive power to a body such as the Joint House Committee is in some way a challenge to Westminster traditions in relation to Presiding Officers. Certain powers are conferred on the Presiding Officers of this Parliament, the Speaker of the House of Represenatives and the President of the Senate, under the Public Service Act 1922. The relevant section is section 9 and the appropriate sub-sections, in relation to the Joint House Department, are sub -sections (1) (c), (2) and (2AB) (e). This Act describes matters in relation to the Presiding Officers' rights for the appointment of staff. That is the only prescription of rights that Parliament has ever given.

Presiding officers are, of course, part of the Parliament and, in a sense, the creation of the Parliament. Any powers they have are either powers that have been specifically ascribed to them by parliament through an Act, as in the case of the Public Service Act, or powers that parliament has allowed them to have. It is always open to parliament to indicate otherwise to the Presiding Officers. The Presiding Officers are elected by the members of the chambers, the House of Representatives and the Senate, and are subject to their direction. Therefore, I do not think there can be any doubt that parliament has the power to direct certain things to take place in relation to the present powers of the Presiding Officers. If the House of Representatives and the Senate chose by resolution to give executive power to the Joint House Committee, without doubt the principle behind that choice is intact.

Senators and members might like to debate how far that conferring of power to a parliamentary committee ought to go; whether it should be detailed or whether it should happen at all. To my mind there is no doubt that it has to happen. One of the things that this Senate inquiry has indicated, to me at least, is that there are areas of responsibility which this Parliament ought to take a little more seriously than it does. Money that is spent at Parliament House, whether it is in relation the the Parliamentary Library, the Joint House Department or any other parliamentary department, derives from the public purse and we have no less responsibility, as representatives of the people, to oversight the actual expenditure of that money and to make sure that we keep a check on how decision- making processes in relation to those departments operate and what the effects of them are.

Of course, this inquiry arose out of the questions and frustrations that arose in an Estimates committee which was attempting to exercise that oversight. Estimates committees try to give effect to the principle of parliamentary oversight of public funds. Estimates Committee A attempted that in relation to the Joint House Department, was frustrated in its questions, was not very pleased with the answers it was given in relation to some priorities, and decided that a special investigation should be carried out. One of the things that were mentioned was the fact that the Parliamentary Library, whose funds had been quite dramaticaly cut, was apparently accorded less priority than the subject of the purchase of some sporting equipment. The question of who makes a decision as to whether there should be sufficient materials in the Library, which are very important to members of parliament in the conduct of their duties and in carrying out their responsibilities, as against the purchase of sporting equipment for I know not whom-probably it is available to members of parliament; I do not know because I do not use these sporting facilities-and what priorities are exercised in such decisions are matters that ought to concern us. They should concern us in the first instance because it is expenditure of public money and, in the second instance because it is parliament that is being affected and we ought to have some expertise in that, and I believe we ought to have some input.

The present situation in relation to the Joint House Committee and its powerlessness is one that has evolved through custom. The control of policy in those areas as it ascribes to the Presiding Officers is a control that has been allowed to happen; it is not statutorily conferred. There is no law of this land that confers that power. The Houses of Parliament, both the House of Representatives and the Senate, have laid down that these committees in relation to the Joint House Department will exist. The Houses have never indicated what powers those individual committees, or those sitting together as a joint committee, ought to have. I suggest that it is open to the Houses to do that.

It is probably also open to the Joint House Committee to be a little more assertive than it is at the moment. If it is claimed that because the Joint House Committee has operated in this way in the past without ever an indication from parliament on whether that is the way parliament wanted it to operate, I suggest that by a line of logic it is therefore open to the Joint House Committee to change its practice. If the present authority is claimed to be based on the practice of the Joint House Committee then authority can change through changed practice of the Joint House Committee. But it probably would be preferable that the Houses of Parliament address themselves specifically to it. Odgers refers to the position of the Joint House Committee in Australian Senate Practice. Pettifer refers to it in the House of Representatives Practice. Pettifer refers to it rather more absolutely than does Odgers and I would question really whether a statement made by Pettifer such as 'Executive responsibility lies with the Speaker and the President, who are not bound by the decisions of the Committees' is really a statement of fact. It may be a statement of usage but it may not necessarily be a statement of absolute fact.
I refer briefly to some evidence that was given in this regard to the Committee by the Secretary of the Joint House Department when he said:

. . . there have been a number of practices that have arisen which could give Members and Senators a different approach according to who the authorities were. For example, it depends very much on the Presiding Officers at the time, and particularly the Chairman, just what attitude is adopted. The current Speaker has indicated, I think categorically, that the Presiding Officers have the authority in relation to matters that come up before the Joint House Committee. He regards the Committee as an advisory body and decisions will be made by the Presiding Officers. Looking over the history of the Joint House Committee, we see that quite obviously from time to time the Joint House Committee has itself made decisions and has given directions for things to be done . . . But at present, as I understand it, the Presiding Officers and particularly the Chairman of the Joint House Committee believe that that Joint House Committee is an advisory body and that all decisions are made by the Presiding Officers.
The current Speaker's attitude contrasts with that of one of his predecessors, the Honourable Sir Littleton Groom, who said in the House of Representatives in 1927:

. . . the President and the Speaker, in the matter of appointments and promotions, are bound by definite provision in the Public Service Act . . . parliament itself is responsible for the determination of the functions and duties of its committees.
That includes the Joint House Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a brief contribution to this debate to add to some of the comments that have been made by the Chairman of the Senate House Committee, Senator Martin. I was a member of the Committee for the bulk of the inquiry, joining it a little after it started. I commend the Secretary of the Committee for the contribution he made, and also the Secretariat and the Committee staff. I would like also to thank those who came before us and indicate that most of those who came before us attempted to provide a good deal of material to us and to answer frankly and openly the questions put to them. There was some reticence on the part of one or two witnesses which, while understandable, was regrettable, I feel-a sort of sense of misplaced loyalty perhaps.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting that during the currency of this inquiry I was also sitting on the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. It was interesting to notice that both committees were looking basically at the same thing. Both were attempting to find ways and means of giving more responsibility to the senators who sit in this place.

Of course, it is quite clear, if one gives it a moment's thought, that the senators who sit here see their needs most clearly, whether it be in the way of services provided to them, staff provided to them or ways in which money might be spent. Senators are the ones who are able to indicate clearly how the money might best be spent. The Senate House Committee put forward strongly in its report the recommendation that senators should have a greater involvement in the decision-making on conditions at all levels. Surely this is not much to ask. This feeling amongst members of the Committee led to our first two recommendations. Since the Chairman of the Committee did not read them I will read them to the Senate. The first recommendation states:

The Committee recommends that each House resolve to empower their respective House Committees, when sitting together as the Joint House Committee, with the executive responsibility for policy in relation to the functions of the Joint House Department . . .
The second recommendation states:
The Committee recommends that there be a determination of policy by the Joint House Committee covering the nature and level of services to be provided by the Refreshment Rooms . . .

It is completely inappropriate, as the Chairman mentioned, that the Joint House Committee should be only an advisory body. Members of the Committee give their time usually when they have other things to do but they have been told that the Committee is only an advisory body and the advice which it gives can be rejected . We have the farcical situation in which senators in this place and members of the other place are entrusted with the mangement of the affairs of the country. Yet, there is some suggestion that they are not able to manage the minor affairs , shall we say, of their own conditions. I found this-I know that all members of the Committee did-to be a deplorable paternalistic attitude and one which we certainly could not accept. Simply to say that this is the way in which things have been done or that this is the way in which the practice has arisen is not enough. We need to challenge it at this stage.

Recommendations 3 and 4 recommend the desirability of certain investigations. Let me stress that point. The two matters mentioned were the contracting out of all or part of the refreshment room services and all or part of the cleaning functions. I make the point again that the Committee asks that this matter be looked into. There may well be some reason why we should not let out the cleaning function, perhaps reasons of security. There may be some reasons why we should not let out some aspects of the services offered by the refreshment rooms . The Committee wishes to be informed of any such reasons. It seems to me ridiculous to have people and committees giving advice-I refer to the report of Urwick International Pty Ltd, Estimates Committee A and other groups that have given advice in this matter-if it is going to be ignored. I suggest that the members of the committee which we propose would not reject that advice and would give it some consideration.

I would also like to make another very strong point. Members of the Senate House Committee were very conscious of the need to protect the livelihood of the present staff in both the cleaning area and in the refreshment rooms area. Let no one think that the Committee suggested that there should be wholesale sackings from those areas. Let no one suggest that in its considerations the Committee did not have the livelihood of the present employees in the front of its mind. As a matter of fact during the hearings of the Committee one of the witnesses was asked whether the present cleaning staff would be retained if the cleaning was let out to contract. The suggestion was made that this was very likely-that this is the sort of practice that probably would be followed and that there would not be wholesale sackings and an entirely new group moved in. The Committee stresses that it is only asking that this matter be properly considered, not ignored.

I find this situation rather similar to the Commonwealth car situation. There are many on this side of the chamber-Senator McLaren in particular-who believe that Commonwealth cars should not be replaced by hire cars or taxis. I will not canvass the arguments here because Senator McLaren has put them very well on previous occasions. Nevertheless, this is a situation in which, on economic grounds-I am not saying that it would be so-we might consider using taxis or hire cars but we might reject it and retain the Commonwealth cars on other very valid grounds. The same situation might apply to the current technical staff. This is dealt with in recommendation 11. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

It should be tabled in the Parliament so that every member has access to it and can make up his or her own mind as to whether the amount of money that it cost was justified and the expenditure worth while. Finally, I again express my thanks to the staff who were associated with this report. I hope their work is rewarded in the proper manner.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are glad that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has come forward with such a sane and practical viewpoint, as read out to the Senate earlier today by Senator Sibraa. We, as a group, maintain our long held opposition to the purchase of a short deck aircraft carrier for the Royal Australian Navy. We hope the Government will now put that idea into permanent cold storage. I think the Government would make a sensible contribution towards the defence debate in Australia from now on if it said one way or another whether it has decided that the force of evidence brought forward to it, including this unanimous decision from one of its own committees, is to the effect that now the Invincible is not available, to purchase a new aircraft carrier would be prohibitive even from the point of view of the cost of the platform, to say nothing of the cost of the aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that arises from that, and to which I would like to address myself briefly, is whether we should seek any alternative naval strength. The view has been put that we should not do so, that we should simply increase our reliance on aircraft as the most effective and fastest missile platforms. I would like to take mild issue with that view. I do not agree with it because I think a stationary platform or a seaborne platform is essential in certain circumstances . When one recalls that the Israeli destroyer Elath was sunk by Styx missiles fired by Egytian patrol boats, quite small ships which actually were at anchor in Port Said Harbour, one can see that a seaborne vessel, even if it is completely quiescent, playing a lying-in-wait role, can be of considerable value .

I am impelled to put in a word to honourable senators at this stage for one of the more modern missile ships of small size, high strike power and relatively small manning. I am not particularly pushing any particular one although I have personal experience of the Boeing Marine company's patrol hydrofoil vessel, a modern weapon available at relatively low cost and requiring relatively low crewing levels. The United states Navy already has a squadron in operation and it will probably also build for the navies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. With the co-operation of the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair)-I thank him for that-I was able to be present on the sea trials of USS Taurus, the last of the Pegasus class of hydrofoil to be delivered to the United States Navy in Seattle in June. I must say I was impressed with the obvious capability of this class of ship, especially as a missile launcher. The Pegasus class of vessel is quite small, being of only 243 tonnes displacement. However, each mounts no fewer than eight Harpoon missiles on lightweight launchers and all eight missiles can be delivered in 13 to 20 seconds. Boeing Marine told me that this was a better performance than that of our much more expensive and larger FFG frigates, which can launch four Harpoon missiles in 40 seconds.

Hence we have a small and inexpensive ship which, because of modern technology and development, can mount this enormous clout, probably the most of any small warship in history. The PHMs also mount on the foredeck a completely computerised self-laying 76mm Oto Melara gun which can fire at a rate of 80 rounds a minute. The ship is also very effectively fitted with defensive radar and six electronic chaff launchers as missile decoys. The top speed of the ships is classified information but I tried to use my eyes and ears while I was aboard the Taurus during her trials and, without saying anything wrong, an informed guess would be that the ship can actually attack and cruise at speeds in excess of 50 knots. That is a very considerable speed when the manoeuvrability of this type of hydrofoil is considered. Range is 1,000 kilometres, although that can be increased with extra tankage. The ship can refuel at sea, even in high weather. It requires a crew of only 21 men.

Boeing Marine told me that for a reasonable production run of six to 10 ships-I gather the US Navy is interested in more-the all-up cost including weapons and the eight Harpoon missiles, which are important, would be some $75m a ship. I believe that this type of weapon ought to be considered by our country because of its suitability for our defence in certain situations. Certainly the value of modern missile strike was demonstrated in the Falklands war. Is the PHM an effective missile platform? It seems to me to be better than most because it is not a hydrofoil in the usual sense; the feeling aboard it is more like flying than being in a ship because it virtually flies on a submerged wing with an aerofoil section. The significance of this is that the hull is held well out of the water with the foil under water so that even in large waves-under tests as high as 22 feet, remembering that this is only a 250-tonne ship-it remains quite steady and level and can launch missiles effectively.

Its speed and manoeuvreability are obvious pluses and I was also very impressed with the great rapidity at which the ship could approach its top speed while foil-borne and with its immense manoeuvreability. There was none of the overrun or stern-swinging effect such as with an ordinary displacement hull. Rather, the ship responds immediately to command. A less obvious plus is its low profile. I gather from the makers that torpedo attack on these ships is rather pointless when they are foil-borne since there is only a very small target in the water to attack. USS Taurus was fitted with six electronic foil launchers. These throw a cloud of metallic foil into the air to confuse approaching missiles. The significance of the hydrofoil is, however, that, because of its great speed it can be away from the scene before the missile reaches the foil and explodes. Other ships with smaller displacement hulls inevitably would incur damage, even under those circumstances.

On present costing, 10 of these highly potent weapons carrying a total of 80 Harpoon missiles, which of course are very much compatible with our own Service needs, could be deployed in Australia for half the cost of a single aircraft carrier and its aircraft. I believe that in combination with our F18 aircraft the hydrofoil attack craft would make an invasion attempt of Australia quite unlikely to succeed because of the damage to the enemy's surface vessels, including troopships, that would quite inevitably ensue. I do believe we should take this step, as all countries in the world have done, towards the fast missile attack ship. We have here the advantage of modern technology in that the hydrofoil is a very modern concept. It has been developed at the expense of another country and is available for us at least to consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate directs that except in respect to second reading speeches introducing Bills, statements made by senators when tabling reports, statements by chairmen on behalf of committees, and other speeches, explanations or statements where leave of the Senate is specifically given, the Presiding Officer in the Senate hereafter shall strictly enforce Standing Order 406 to ensure that no senator shall read his speech, so that proper and effective debate will be maintained in this chamber.

I move the motion because I think it is high time that we took this matter in hand. I regret that I shall not be here in the course of this debate because of long standing commitments, nor shall I be here to vote on my own motion or to reply to it; but I trust that other senators will handle the matter effectively. Standing Order 406 is very simple. It states:
No Senator shall read his speech.

I do not go as far as to say that it is honoured more in the breach than in the observance. However, it is very often dishonoured, and I have noted it on many occasions in recent months. I understand the situation when honourable senators come first into this place and do not find it easy to take part in debate, or are put off by interjections. It is a matter of obtaining skill in this area. But after 18 months in this Parliament, it is high time that the rising number of honourable senators who are reading their speeches, and reading them very obviously, should not be permitted to continue to do so.

The problem is, of course, that this Senate has for years been noted for the debate that takes place here, unlike the House of Representatives, which for some time has abandoned this practice and allowed the reading of speeches. The result is that so many people come in, make their speeches and leave. They do not wait to hear what is said. Unfortunately, that is what I shall be doing today, so that may be taken as a particularly bad example. This is what happens constantly in the House of Representatives. Therefore, there is not the interchange of someone being present before he starts his speech, questioning the other speaker, trying to flush out the argument that is developing and likewise being prepared to answer when he has sat down. That has been the difference between debate in the House of Representatives and debate in this chamber. I believe there is great danger if we do not enforce Standing Order 406 .

We well know that persons who from time to time are in the chair have had complaints made to them about the reading of speeches. One remembers so many occasions when there was a grin on the face of the presiding officer, who said: 'You are perhaps using too copious notes, senator'. We all know that what is being read is word for word the speech that appears in Hansard the next day. We know this also because of the tabling of those speeches which has occurred from time to time.

Not only is there the problem that we do not have an interchange in debate, which was the glory of this Senate, but also there is the opportunity for staff to engage themselves in preparing speeches which perhaps represent their ideas rather than the senator's. Though the speech may be well directed and well prepared, it is not therefore the argument which the senator would himself or herself put before the chamber. I remind the Senate that in the better Parliaments overseas there is no doubt about the reading of speeches. I quote from page 413 of the nineteenth edition of Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice in regard to the United Kingdom:

In the House of Lords the reading of speeches is alien to the custom of the House. It is recognised, however, that in certain circumstances, such as when a Ministerial Statement is being made, it is necessary for a Lord to read from a prepared text. In practice speakers often have recourse to 'extended notes', but it is considered contrary to the interests of good debate that they should follow them too closely.

In the House of Commons a Member is not permitted to read his speech, but may refresh his memory by reference to notes. A Member may read extracts from documents, but his own language must be delivered bona fide in the form of an unwritten composition. The purpose of this rule is primarily to maintain the cut and thrust of debate, which depends upon successive speakers meeting in their speeches to some extent the arguments of earlier speeches; debate decays under a regime of set speeches prepared beforehand without reference to each other.

That is a very significant factor in this debate. Likewise, in Canada one finds that the same rules apply. In both chambers it is required that there should not be reading of speeches. Indeed, Sir John Bourinot, who has written the authoritative book on the parliamentary procedure and practice, had this to say:

Written speeches not permissible-It is a rule in both Houses of Parliament that a member must address the House orally, and not read from a written, previously prepared speech; for the reasons stated by Mr Fox in 1806 that 'if the practice of reading written speeches-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, may I draw your attention to Standing Order 406?
—I shall leave the chamber if I am to be interrupted in the midst of a quotation.
—There is no point of order. Senator Missen is obviously quoting; that is quite in order.
—I am reading from an authoritative text. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: -if the practice of reading written speeches should prevail, members might read speeches that were written by other people, and the time of the House be taken up in considering arguments of persons who were not deserving of their attention .

I have had a paper prepared on this matter, which is available for any honourable senator to look at. One finds that in the better Houses of Parliament in the world there is a prohibition against the reading of speeches and it is enforced, but in the Communist parliaments one finds generally that the reading of speeches is permitted. I invite honourable senators to draw their own conclusions as to why that may be so in Communist countries.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not engage in argument, for the reasons I have already given. However, others in the chamber will be able to engage in debate on this matter. In this motion I recognise the exceptions which ought properly to be made and which have been suggested to me by other senators, including Senator Chipp. I have incorporated in the motion the worthy cases where it ought to be allowed. In addition, of course, anything can be done by leave. Where a senator in this chamber has matters of detail, of statistics, or of argument need it, he can always obtain leave, and then we should know what he is doing. What is objected to is the fact that people are reading speeches as though they are verbatim, and they are not. It is for these reasons that it is important in the interests of the preservation of debate in this chamber that we carry the motion and that it be enforced in the future. I hope that it will be so carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the sentiments expressed by Senator Missen. I do so, perhaps, on a different basis. We all come to this chamber from various occupations; in my own case, it was from the workshop floor . In shop committees one had five minutes to put an argument. Perhaps a longer period is available for people to put their arguments in legal circles, or for councillors and such people. But the character of a speech is destroyed when it is a written speech. On many occasions it is the character of the research officer that comes through and not that of the individual making the speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Without giving away any secrets, I remember one Tasmanian colleague who, when we were in power, had a speech prepared by a research officer. He advocated a policy which would have been detrimental to the apple crops of Tasmania. I do not think my colleague took much notice of his written speeches thereafter. Let me tell a story which epitomises the way in which people's characters go overboard when they have too many speech writers. There was a prominent Sydney footballer who subsequently became a fairly good commentator. The chap in question had all the briefings available on how to conduct himself. When somebody fumbled a ball he would say: 'Oh, butter fingers'. Anyone knowing that man would know that he would not have used the words 'butter fingers' if a ball was dropped. At a later stage Senator Douglas McClelland could probably tell the Senate who I am thinking about. That person is not calling sport now. To me that indicated the futility of being too conditioned with instructions.

It may be true that not everybody in the Senate can emulate the oratory of John Wheeldon. Anybody who heard John Wheeldon at his best heard a super performer. But I think when we get up to say our piece we should not be tied down too much. Of course if we have a quotation or a list of figures, as Senator Missen said, we can have it incorporated in Hansard, and we can have it incorporated in normal size type-we can do a host of things. But I think our normal fluency is stilted and jarred when we read a speech which does not express our own thoughts or reactions.

I think what Senator Missen said is true. For the first 12 months in this place people have a running in period. But I think most of us would find, accepting the idea of copious notes, that the important thing is that we express our own views. Whether one is full of fire or cynical does not matter, as long as one is expressing one's own thoughts. I think far too often we hear these sombre sorts of phrases and when we meet the senator outside in the corridor, he never uses those expressions. They are simply not him.

With regard to the point that Senator Missen has made, many of us who serve in the position of Acting Deputy President are always afraid that someone will take a point of order on the matter that has now been raised. We all know that, to say the least, the words 'copious notes' have been prostituted. I think what Senator Missen is getting at is that if we speed up the play and get a fiery speech from the belly and not a speech from someone outside who has written it in a cold fashion, it would put more vigour into the debate, although I know that in the last 48 hours that characteristic has been present in abundance. I agree with Senator Missen. I think this matter should be looked at. It is something about which a senator could boast in this chamber-that when he spoke, they were his own thoughts, not the grafted on thoughts of someone else who had spent hours in the Library getting his thoughts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene only briefly to indicate on behalf of the Government that this is, of course, an issue affecting Standing Orders. Therefore the Government would not want to take a view and would understand that honourable senators would vote each one according to his or her own perception of this particular problem. Having said that, might I indicate--
—It is very generous of you to say that.
—I think it is worth putting on record.
—You will have the usual dozen follow you over.

—I am trying to be helpful. I do not know how Ministers will vote but I want to indicate now how I will vote. I will vote to support Senator Missen and the proposition that he has put for the reasons which he has laid down. If one spends much time in this chamber, the pleasure is in hearing speeches which are delivered and not read and to have to endure speeches which are in fact set pieces, some of them released to the Press and presented in this place simply to give them the imprimatur of going in the Hansard is an agony from which senators should be protected. Having said that, I indicate that I will be supporting Senator Missen. I hope that the Senate will see its way clear to support his proposition. As I say the Government would not attempt to indicate a view to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am suprised that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has indicated that he will support Senator Missen, because my reading of Standing Order 406 is that no senator shall read his speech, and that would include Ministers, chairmen of committees and everyone else.
—There are normal courtesies.

—I am not talking about normal practice, I am talking about what is said in the Standing Orders. The Minister would agree with the Standing Orders. I hope, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you will allow me to move an amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the matter of reading of speeches and the application of Standing Order 406 be referred to the Standing Orders Committee'

I do this because as I have said in my opening comments, Senator Missen in his motion seems to suggest some variation to what the actual Standing Order says. I am not talking about practices, I am talking about the Standing Order. It would seem, according to the reading, unless I am wrong in this, that Ministers and the chairmen of committees and some others are being delinquent also. But there are many factors involved here and certainly I think that this is a matter which ought rightly to be referred to the Standing Orders Committee.
