It may well be that the Committee will decide that a number of people ought to be allowed to read their speeches. It may well be that the Committee will come back to the Senate with a recommendation that certain people, such as Ministers and chairmen of committees and so on, do so.

I do raise one point, though. Who will challenge when a person is alleged to be reading his speech? I can envisage a situation where this would devolve on one or two people in the chamber. It may well be the Whips who have to make the decision. I can see a lot of bad feeling being developed if a Whip has to stand up every so often and say, 'I claim that Senator so and so is reading his speech ' and then we get an indulgent smile and someone says he is reading from copious notes. The copious notes that I have noted as I have walked around the chamber include comments such as 'pause'. I would suggest that a lot of time could be wasted if we try to debate this particular matter here. We have a propensity for spending a lot of time on matters which perhaps could be dealt with more expeditiously by being referred to the appropriate committee. I would hope that we would refrain from debate on the original motion and go to a vote on this motion immediately and refer this matter to the Standing Orders Committee, see what it has to recommend and perhaps have a debate when that recommendation from the Standing Orders Committee comes back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — This is the second time, to my knowledge, in my 11 years here, that this matter has been debated. On the last occasion I spoke strongly against the type of thing that my colleague Senator Missen is trying to do now. A while ago, the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) I think it was, said that some of the speeches which are read are boring and people in this chamber should not be subjected to them. I would say that for many speeches that people make off the top of their heads. I have been bored stiff with them too. So I think it cuts both ways. I think we should have consideration for people who perhaps cannot do something off the top of their heads. They need to prepare something. They prepare it and they read it. There are many people who can read a speech. I have watched people around this chamber who read a speech but unless one was watching them one would never know that they were reading it. Now what is the difference between someone doing that and someone deliberately and openly reading a speech in this chamber? I see nothing wrong with it. I think it is important that allowances be made for those of us who feel that we just cannot stand up here and speak for 25 or 30 minutes on a subject just off the top of our heads. I think that we have to make allowances for people who cannot do that. It is all very well for those honourable senators here who are competent enough to stand up and do it. But let us have some compassion and understanding for those people who may not have that capacity. They are the people that we will victimise. We are going to say: 'You can't do that; you are not allowed to do that'.
—Who do you have in mind?
—Oh, come on! I will not point people out. I have seen the honourable senator looking down at the table quite a lot when he is making a speech. I might even be talking about him.
—I wonder who wrote his speech?

—I am quite sure that he is capable of writing his own speeches and so are other honourable senators in this chamber. It is a lot of nonsense to say that they are all someone else's words, that someone else is writing their speeches and they are only mouthing what someone else has written. That is not true. It could happen, of course it could happen. When a Minister stands at the table and puts down his second reading speech, I am pretty certain that he does not write that speech. His staff does it for him and he comes into the chamber and delivers it. All Ministers have that opportunity. Shadow Ministers have that opportunity. It is the poor old backbencher who is the one who has to suffer all the time. He cannot have any consideration at all. I think that we are taking a bad step as we did on the last occasion when we debated this particular Standing Order.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Senator Missen. I know other people here who can stand up and talk for an hour. Sometimes I think 'Oh, my gosh; that speech is really dragging on my patience'. But those people have the capacity to make a speech off the top of their head. Good luck to them; God bless them. I believe it would be wrong of us to say that people who feel they need to have a prepared speech should not be allowed to read it. Why should they not do that? If they are going to make a better contribution to debate in this place by doing that, they should be entitled to do so. That is what this is all about. If they are going to make a better contribution in this chamber on behalf of the people they represent they should have the right to do it in the way that is best and suited and helpful to them. I hope that finally sanity will prevail and this motion will be defeated overwhelmingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a violently strong view about this matter, but my inclination is to oppose the motion. Much of what I intended to say has been said by Senator Bonner. People are elected as members of this chamber not because they are State debating champions from Victoria, as Senator Missen is, but because they are-
—That is not the only reason he was elected.

—Senator Missen may well have got here because he was able to persuade his pre-selection committee that he was the smartest guy available. There are those who are selected first and then elected, not because of the capacity of their mouth but because of how they feel in their heart and how they think in their mind.
—What about good lungs?

—Perhaps that helps occasionally in union meetings. I believe some people are being badly disadvantaged. We all know that some men and women have made speeches for years and they never get any better. That is an affliction, an asset or a virtue which, by the grace of God, is cast upon some people. It would be a very sad day for those people to find themselves in a position in which they are not able precisely to articulate themselves to convey how they feel and think. I believe the community as a whole is entitled to receive a man's best thoughts-not necessarily the words that come scrambling into his mind as he desperately searches for an appropriate phrase at the last moment while he is on his feet. The people are entitled to hear what he is trying to say in the most concise and precise way.

SPEECH.PARA: There are occasions on which all of us, when we make speeches, want to be so precise and so definitive in how we put our arguments that it may well be better to have a prepared speech. It does not have to be written word for word. I do not know the distinction between copious notes and a written speech. There may be an occasion on which an honourable senator wants to deliver a speech in a quite precise way so that it reflects exactly what he is thinking and there is no misunderstanding in the minds of the public and those to whom he distributes his speech. For those reasons we ought to oppose this proposition.

Quite frankly, I am disappointed that we are debating this matter. I do not know the reason that it was raised on the Notice Paper. It seems to me that we ought to be contemplating other matters first. If I had my way I would be debating today the provisions of Standing Order 418. Last night in this place, in the space of three pages of Hansard, there were 16 gross breaches of Standing Order 418. If we are concerned about our conduct, our presentation to the public and our performance, we should concern ourselves with those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would not have people like you in here if we were concerned about that.
—I take strong exception to that remark by Senator Walsh.
—I did not say anything about you.
—I know that he did not say anything about me but he said something about one of my colleagues and I wish to defend him.
—Senator Lewis, do you have a point of order?
—Yes. I ask that Senator Walsh withdraw the imputation against my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne.
—What imputation?
—He said: 'We would not have people like you in here'. Hansard will show that to be the case.
—There is no point of order.

—There may be no definitive point of order but, with respect, it demonstrates the point I was making. I conclude by saying that the majority of honourable senators coming into this chamber come in with a fixed view. I do not want to be critical of one or other political party's style of conduct, but the Australian Labor Party is committed by caucus and when members of the ALP enter this chamber they know how they will vote. I believe one can reasonably assume and presume that on most occasions one will know how the Liberals intend to vote. Very rarely is one persuaded by an articulate speaker on the other side. One might be a bit more concerned and have some apprehension about one's course of direction, but invariably when someone comes into the chamber he knows how he will vote. I do not think it is a bad thing for honourable senators to be able to articulate and to reflect in the written word precisely what they think. If any honourable senator has a research officer who writes speeches that do not accord with what he would want reflected in a speech , obviously he has the wrong man on his staff. I would have thought that the average research officer would be philosophically compatible with his senator. I do not think there is any concern about that unless the research officer's communication with his senator is a bit out of touch or he is trying to slot in a speech which would either sabotage him or set him in the wrong direction.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not fair and it is grossly unkind to those who do not have a capacity to be able to reflect their views in a precise fashion to not be allowed no longer to refer to notes and speeches. I am much more interested in hearing what a man has to say-whether it be the written word or not-if it is accurate, precise and a reflection of his thinking, than I am in hearing him bumbling and stumbling, nervous and apprehensive, and unable to say what he is thinking. I get a great deal more satisfaction, knowledge and occasionally wisdom from hearing people read speeches which they have deliberated over for some time and which reflect what they are trying to say. For those people who are unable to articulate what they would like to say and for all of us who, on occasions, want to say something in a very tight, precise fashion, we ought to be able to read our speeches.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can by leave.
—One would never get leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Crichton-Browne has proved one thing in his speech, he has proved that he is a very quick learner. He has not been a member of this place for very long but he has quickly learned-I was very pleased to hear him admit it today-that this is not a House of review; it is a House of politics.
—I did not say that.

—The honourable senator as good as said that the Senate is not a House of review. I have said that ever since I have been a member of this place. The Senate is a party political chamber. As the honourable senator said, the Australian Labor Party is bound by caucus. We freely admit that; we do not deny it. Members of the Government parties go out on the hustings and say that they are free agents. But never yet has any member on that side crossed the floor to bring about the defeat of their Government. Members of the Government side have never come over to this side to vote against their government to bring it down.
—You have never done it under any circumstances.

—We do not claim to do that. We are honest with the electors. We are elected on party policy and when we come in here we stick to it. We do not say to people that we are free agents and that if we do not agree with what the Government is doing we will bring it down.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that Senator Missen's motion asks the Presiding Officer to enforce Standing Order 406; that is, the Standing Order that provides that no senator may read his speech. That Standing Order should be amended to read that no back bencher may read his speech. Every Minister, every Opposition shadow Minister and honourable senators presenting reports are entitled, under Standing Order 406, to read a prepared speech. So the only people which Standing Order 406 affects are back benchers. Back benchers have very limited staff to write speeches for them. But if they have the capability to write a speech for themselves, in my view-as Senator Crichton-Browne has said-they should be able to read it. Of course, we may then find senators coming in here with written speeches, as Ministers do, and seeking leave to have them incorporated. Then we would not have to listen to them. Nobody listens to our speeches on Tuesdays and Thursdays. The only time honourable senators would read the speeches would be on Wednesdays. This would save a lot of time in this Parliament. Senators could come in with a written speech, as the Ministers do, and seek leave to have it incorporated. No doubt on some occasions they would be refused leave.

I want to recount a little episode. It happened in this Parliament some years ago when former Senator Kane was here. He repeatedly read speeches until my colleague, Senator Cavanagh, realised that those speeches were written by a person by the name of Santamaria, the head man of the National Civic Council. One night Senator Cavanagh asked that the speech be tabled. Of course, as soon as it was tabled, he was able to get hold of it and later during the night he read the speech. If honourable senators look at the Hansard they will see the two identical speeches. Senator Gair, who was at the time Leader of the Democratric Labor Party, went to Senator Cavanagh and said: 'You have destroyed Kane. He will never make another speech'. While he was here he never did make a speech consisting of anything more than two or three paragraphs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he?
—It was because he was not allowed to read them and he could not write his own.
—Does that not prove the point?

—It might prove the honourable senator's point, but I am one of those people who came under a lot of attack when I first came in here. It was claimed that I was reading speeches. The President at the time, Magnus Cormack, took me to task every time. But then he would fall back on the observation that perhaps the honourable senator was using copious notes. They were copious. They were all over the place. When an honourable senator gets into a bit of a flurry, as Senator Crichton-Browne says some honourable senators do, if there are interjections, and if an honourable senator does not have a prepared speech, that honourable senator probably does not say the things that he or she wanted to or give the true meaning in the speech being delivered.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no objection to honourable senators reading their speeches. It is the people outside the chamber who will judge whether we are sincere in our speeches that are recorded or in the speeches that are broadcast on Wednesdays. That is where honourable senators are judged, not here.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't read your speeches. You show remarkable spontaneity.

—Sometimes, perhaps; but there are many times, Senator Chipp, when I would like to be able to read my speeches. They might read a little better and it might be much easier for the Hansard staff if I had a prepared speech. If honourable senators were allowed to read their speeches, as is the case in the House of Representatives, the Hansard staff would have a much easier task to perform. They would not have to try to make sense out of a lot of speeches by putting them together in a coherent fashion. There is no objection to honourable members in the other place reading speeches. When I came here and inquired why we were not allowed to do the same in the Senate, I was told that this Standing Order was brought into being because lazy honourable senators were just getting hold of the House of Representatives Hansard and re-reading speeches that someone had made in the other place. The members of the public are not stupid. They can see that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed to this motion and I am also opposed to the amendment which my party colleague and our Whip has moved that the matter ought to be sent to the Standing Orders Committee. Based on some of the things that that Committee has brought back to the Senate for consideration in the last 12 months, I cannot believe that it even gave due consideration to some of them. We had some of our own colleagues-
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot, because some of the things that have been changed by the Standing Orders Committee are, in my view, absolutely stupid. I would be prepared-
—Better the devil you know.

—That is right. But if an amendment were moved to this motion-I will not move it-that we delete Standing Order 406 from the Standing Orders, I would be happy to support it. But I cannot see myself at this stage supporting the motion moved by Senator Missen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was relaxed and felt easy enough about this idea of Senator Missen until this morning I heard Senator Georges make the remark that interjections added spice and interest to debate in this chamber. They certainly do. I agree with that in every way. Yet I find, when I look at the Standing Orders, that interjections are strictly disorderly. Apparently there should be no interjections at all in this chamber.
—It would be a pretty dull place without them.

—Yes. Perhaps I am sorry for what I said last night, even to Senator Walsh; never mind about that. The point is that if we are going to absolutely prohibit honourable senators from making speeches in this chamber, most of which are read, we should completely stop the practice of interjections. I would not ask that that practice be stopped and I am sure that there are no honourable senators who would want it stopped, even though the Standing Orders say there should not be any. I feel the same way about this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: My friend Senator Missen is not here. He is probably listening to the debate and he will prob- ably rush back into the chamber to deal with me before he has to leave. He used words like 'flush out the argument' and 'exchange of ideas'. What a starry conception of this chamber. We all know that sometimes this does happen, but it is a rarity. As Senators McLaren, Crichton-Browne and Bonner say, this is a chamber mainly of political argument. But occasionally there will be that spontaneous reaction to an honourable senator's very good argument. Sometimes those very good arguments have been read from a piece of paper, but they are somebody's thoughts. I am interested in the character and experience of honourable senators opposite and on this side of the chamber. Sometimes, as Senator Crichton-Browne said, that can come out only when they put down their thoughts carefully, distil them and read the speech; and if they read their speeches with feeling, they will be better than if they do not. It seems to me that Senator Missen is living in the age of ancient Rome or Greece. This is what he has in mind-a time before pencils and paper were invented. It is a wonderful and a starry idea but it is not practical.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was wrong with ancient Rome?

—It is not here any more, is it? Senator Chipp reminds me that some other practices are conducted in this chamber that go back to ancient Rome. The colour of the carpet in this chamber reminds me of how some of those arguments ended. I support Senator McLaren. I think his idea is very good. We ought seriously to consider removing that Standing Order altogether. I have prepared no motion or amendment but if an honourable senator has prepared one along those lines I would certainly support it, because it seems to me that that Standing Order, as it is now, has no real place here. I do not think that the Standing Order has been outraged and I do not see why people of Senator Missen's debating capacity-honourable senators should remember that he was a debating champion of, I think, Victoria and maybe of Australia--
—It is intellectual arrogance.
—I hope Senator Missen heard Senator Hill say that and not me.
—Do you know his wife is better than he is?

—I would not be surprised. I know that she must have more patience than I have. I have to sit with him here; she has to-yes. I think that we have given this motion fair consideration. I do feel that if honourable senators want to read speeches or quote from copious notes, they should be allowed to do so. The practice has been prevalent in the House of Representatives for a long time and I see no reason why we should not follow the same practice in this chamber.

—I will be brief. I was trying to do a little constructive work in my office when I heard all this argument running. I thought, obviously the wrong people are speaking to the motion. I heard an endless chain of honourable senators with some new-found literacy saying that they should be able to read their speeches. It is not easy to come into the Senate chamber as a new senator and make speeches off the cuff. But our business is communication and with the greatest of respect, Senator Crichton-Browne, we have to be able to marshal arguments lucidly, concisely and cogently. If we sit down, ponder it out, put it on bits of paper and laboriously read it over, we never get those skills. One just has to be thrown into the water and has to learn to swim. That is all I would like to say on this matter, apart from the--
—Your defence speeches.

—There are not many things that I do not have right at my fingertips. If honourable senators would like me to embark on a dissertation on any element, I will at the present time, but there are some highly technical subjects where headings are needed, but I never use a full text.
—You would be much better if you did.

—I could not accept that because I would lose my natural fluency, rhythm and spontaneity. In conclusion, I state that I think that if an honourable senator, after being here for six months, cannot make a speech without having it written out, the Chief Electoral Officer ought to declare that honourable senator's election null and void.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not feel very strongly about the motion. I suspect that Senator Martyr may have spent too much time in the other place and that some of his views were swayed by that experience. On balance, I will be supporting this motion. I want to respond mainly to the amendment moved by Senator Robertson. I suspect he had not read the motion properly when he first stood, but he repaired that deficiency as he was speaking. I think the fact that this requirement is already in our Standing Orders makes its referral to the Standing Orders Committee totally unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robertson raised another point concerned with the enforcement of this Standing Order, and he canvassed the possibility that the Whips may have to carry out this function. I do not think that is necessary. It can be dealt with as it is dealt with now. Any honourable senator in this place may take a point of order drawing the attention of the Chair to what is happening. On balance, I support the motion. I have a great deal of sympathy for the points of view of Senator Bonner and Senator Crichton-Browne. I have heard and observed in the time I have been here many honourable senators new to this place responding in a very lucid and fluent way during debate to points that have been put. However, when they have returned to their 'copious notes' their speeches have become boring and almost impossible to listen to.

This chamber is a far more entertaining chamber than the other place, mainly because very few speeches in this place are read. I think that the repartee, the response, the interjections and, I hope, mostly well meaning responses across the chamber add greatly to this place. In most cases this is lacking in the other chamber. As I said, I will be supporting the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment put forward by the Opposition Whip, Senator Robertson. The reason we are debating this motion this afternoon is that the Standing Order has come completely into disrepute. Senator Missen spoke about the number of reasons for which people already are allowed to read their speeches in this place. In addition, Ministers and shadow Ministers can read their speeches, as well as the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats. I think it is quite right that as the leaders of a third party they should be able to read their speeches when they are responding to a major measure such as the Budget. So under the present practices at any time on any one day at least one-third of the senators can read their speeches. I think that is the reason why we are talking about Standing Order 406 at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: A particular member of the Senate, who is not on the Government side, on many occasions in my opinon reads his speeches. He happens to be one of the best speed readers I have ever heard, but that does not take anything at all away from the speeches he delivers. Senator MacGibbon amazes me. I would not accuse him of reading his speeches, but he makes some very entertaining speeches on highly technical defence matters. He has page after page of figures. While it could not be said that he reads his whole speech-he does not-when he makes a speech such as the one he made here on the F18A aircraft somebody on this side could get up and take a point of order. If the President took Standing Order 406 as it is written at the moment he would have to say that Senator MacGibbon was reading his speech. At any one time Senator MacGibbon would probably read three or four minutes of matter concerning technical details. That does not mean that he will not then speak without notes for four or five minutes.

Standing Order 406 has become virtually unenforceable in that one-third of the members of the Senate are able to get away with the fact that they are reading their speeches. For that reason I think some good arguments have been put up this afternoon on both sides of the Senate. As Senator Robertson said, this matter should be sent back to the Standing Orders Committee. It could examine what we have said-the sort of things that I have mentioned here this afternoon, including the role of the Democrats. The Democrats have shadow portfolios. If our shadow ministers are allowed to read their speeches does this mean that all the Democrats, if they are discussing an important matter, can read their speeches? I think those are the things the Standing Orders Committee has to consider and on which it should make recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose both the amendment and the motion. I do not know whether I am able to foreshadow a motion that Standing Order 406 be deleted completely. It seems to me that that would be by far the best arrangement. Whilst I can appreciate the sentiments of Senator Sibraa, and I support substantially what he is saying, if this matter goes back to the Standing Orders Committee, having debated it today it will come back to us in a month or so and we will have a rehash of the whole debate. If the majority view is that the motion will be defeated, it seems to me we are taking a back route way of getting the matter back to the Standing Orders Committee. The practice has developed, whether we like it or not, of honourable senators being obliged to talk on a wide variety of issues which are becoming more and more complex. Speeches on these issues require not only spontaneity but also a great deal of detail. In the 11 years I have been in this place I have seen how difficult it has become for ordinary members of the Senate to debate the complex subjects that have become part of the legislative process.

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers in this place who have to present a case for the Government often represent another Minister and therefore they are forced to rely upon a prepared text. Similarly, as Senator Sibraa said, honourable senators on the Opposition front bench have to rely on a great deal of prepared material. It is conceded that the more one can make a spontaneous contribution the better it is. To suggest that every honourable senator should be put in the position of having to be completely spontaneous when making a speech makes a mockery of the whole principle of rational debate. And surely what we are all about is rational debate. We have to make sure that the contributions by honourable senators show an understanding of the issues under consideration. We have to make sure that a speech which is read by other people or listened to by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber makes sense and is relevant to the issues being debated.

Senator Sibraa very correctly pointed to the fact that about one-third of honourable senators are already able to rely upon a prepared text, or copious notes, as they used to be called when points of order were taken five, six, seven or eight years ago. I think society has become a lot more complex in that period. One only has to look at the type of legislation with which we are dealing to see how difficult it is for the average member of parliament to be completely au fait with the complexities of all the matters debated within the Parliament. I think we can make a more important and rational contribution if we are able to rely upon some assistance. After all, that is our purpose.

I was one of those in my party who fought for the principle the Labor Government introduced in those terribly infamous years from 1972 to 1975 that every member of parliament should have a research officer. We did not have that assistance then. It was essential to have this assistance if we were to be able to make a contribution within the Parliament. Having got that assistance, honourable senators cannot tell me that their helpers, their assistants, their researchers can impart to them orally all that they need to know to enable them to make a speech. One needs that additive to set out one's party or personal or philosophical or ideological position when making a contribution to a debate. I believe that this makes for better government and for a better Parliament. After all, our friends in the Press Gallery base their decisions on whether to publish a speech on what one is able to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to re-write that half the time.

—Yes, that is right. I think the time has arrived when Standing Order 406 ought to be taken out of Standing Orders completely. I think that would be part of the evolution of this place. Of course, we will lose the effectiveness of debate if honourable senators rely completely upon reading their speeches. I think we should get to the position where we are assisted-to use a phrase which was used in my early days in this place-by the use of copious notes. I think the standard of debate has improved immeasurably as a result of the use of copious notes and assistance through the extra resources that have been given to members of parliament. Rather than keeping Standing Order 406-that is where I have a minor disagreement with Senator Sibraa; I am sure he agrees substantially with what I am saying-I am sure the time has arrived when we can make a mature decision and take it out completely.

—The question I want to raise is really the status of the motion moved by Senator Missen in relation to the Standing Orders. It seems to me that it is for the Presiding Officer to maintain order in the chamber and it is up to him to exercise that authority, even though I agree that Standing Order 406 is in absolute terms. I suppose it is up to the Presiding Officer from time to time to exercise some discretion. Indeed, it is incumbent on the senator who is challenged to indicate to the chamber whether he or she is indeed reading a speech. Normally the reply of the senator is taken to be definitive. If it is not taken to be definitive, and if the Chair wishes to enforce Standing Order 406 against the senator, I guess that is up to the Presiding Officer. It seems to me that, if order is to be maintained by the President, it is hardly proper for the Senate in this motion to direct the President as to how he shall enforce the Standing Order from time to time.
—But is not that precisely wrong? Isn't that going 180 degrees-the President is the servant of the Senate?

—No. If the Presiding Officer makes a ruling that the Senate disagrees with, of course the Senate can express itself in an appropriate way. But to direct the Presiding Officer as to how he shall exercise his function seems to me to be perhaps beyond the capacity of the chamber.
—Senator Tate, if you are asking for a ruling on whether the motion is in order, I rule that it is in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not seeking any special privilege of the Senate this afternoon but some honourable senators will be aware that Senator Missen had to leave the Parliament early and therefore was not able to be here, apart from to move the motion. He asked me if I would perform a function in relation to reply. I think all honourable senators know the reason that Senator Missen was unable to be here this afternoon. Those reasons were genuine and legitimate and no aspersions should be cast upon him because he is not here to reply on the subject of his motion. He has asked me to perform the function of reply. I would have spoken on this motion in any event. I realise I cannot claim the privilege of closing the debate but I indicate to honourable senators that Senator Missen hoped that I might be able to do that on his behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I would like to reply to the extraordinary proposition just put by Senator Tate, that there is some impertinence involved in the Senate's directing the Presiding Officer in some way. This is an issue which has recently come to the Senate, the issue of whether the Presiding Officer is the servant or the master of the chamber. There is absolutely no doubt that the Presiding Officer is the servant of the chamber. In that context I should like to refer briefly to Odgers's Australian Senate Practice in that section on rules and orders where he discusses the nature of Standing Orders, and the statement that a President's ruling which has not been dissented from is equivalent to a resolution of the Senate. So the President can give a ruling. If the Senate does not dissent it is then equivalent to a ruling of the Senate. However, it is always within the Senate's power to overturn that ruling, to come back to it and say: 'The Senate now wishes to proceed in a different way'. That is the position .

I should like also to respond very briefly to an extraordinary proposition put to the Senate by Senator Gietzelt. As I understood what Senator Gietzelt was saying, he said that a research assistant could prepare a document for us on a subject. Therefore, because the research assistant had done a very good job, or understood it well, or perhaps understood it better than the honourable senator, that was some sort of justification for a senator coming in and reading that document as though it was the senator's own. That is a very dangerous proposition. It is also an extraordinary one. The obvious question comes to mind immediately: If that is so, the research assistant should be sitting in the chamber, not the senator. If a senator is not capable of reading some sort of briefing material prepared for him by a member of staff or some other person, understanding it and then coming in and expressing perhaps the identical point of view-it does not really matter whether it is identical; but expressing it himself and showing a comprehension of it-he has no place in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not your prerogative to decide. That is for the electors to decide.

—Senator Gietzelt was suggesting that it is acceptable for somebody to come in here and read a speech because it has been written by someone else. I suggest that it is utterly against the principles of parliament and what a parliamentary chamber is about that a senator should be able to come in here and claim as a justification for reading the speech the fact that it is not his own. We are supposed to be here--
—What do you think Ministers do?

—Ministers have to abide by every part of it. It is a separate proposition altogether. People hold strong views on this. The reason they hold strong views is that they either object to what happens to debate when it is allowable for speeches to be read or else they are frightened of not being able to read their speeches in the future. We have all been through that last syndrome and nobody suggests that it is easy. I still think that probably my most traumatic experience in this chamber was my maiden speech-which I did not read-but nevertheless it is something which lives very vividly in my mind as something that I do not want to go through again. There is a certain amount of nervousness and, in some cases, even trauma in settling down to this forum. I had a great deal of experience as a public speaker before I came into the Senate but I had had no experience which equated with speaking in this chamber. It was as though I had not spoken publicly before, to come in here, to fit in with the forms of the chamber and so on. As a consequence, the Senate has traditionally been fairly lenient on new senators. It has allowed them a lot of leeway until they settle down, find their feet and find what the chamber is all about. What the chamber is not at all about, as was pointed out very well I thought by Senator Missen, is reading set pieces at one another. It is about debate of issues. It is about an interchange of ideas.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sad that some honourable senators-and relatively new senators-have this afternoon taken it upon themselves to say that debate here does not matter, that it contributes not to the development of ideas or, indeed, the persuasion of other senators. Some of those very senators have gone so far as to suggest that debate somehow is enhanced by reading set pieces. I find that a sad proposition because there are a number of issues which have been debated in the Senate which have been what we could call running debates over a period of months or years. Senators have taken an opportunity on certain sets of Bills-the education Bills are one set of Bills that Senator Teague would agree with me on- to pick up a theme about, for example, what we should expect from education in Australia. There is a certain amount of party politics in any debate. There has been a certain amount of party politics in that education debate. But a great part of that education debate has been a genuine contribution of ideas from senators who cared about the issue, who have put it on the record, who have put forward an idea for debate-debate by their colleagues, by senators on the opposite side and by people outside this chamber who have fed back their ideas on those issues. I instance education as just one such issue. I think defence is probably another debate which has progressed very satisfactorily in those terms in this chamber. It will not progress at all if, when sitting here, we have some sort of set piece read at us which we know has been handed to the Press Gallery- handed to the Press Gallery for the reason of reporting, not for the reason of any sort of interchange or exchange of ideas or advancement of the actual issue.

There is real debate in this chamber and I will go so far as to say that one of the reasons there is more real debate of that nature in this chamber than in the House of Representatives is that there they read their speeches and the whole business of giving speeches there is just a matter of standing one's feet, talking to an allotted Bill for an allotted length of time and reciting what the member or someone else has written on this subject at some other time. It has its effect. Senator Haines does not have any colleagues in the House of Representatives. I do not say that in an insulting way, but our colleagues have been discussing this issue with us in the past few days and everybody who has discussed it with me has said: 'I wish we did not read speeches in our House. But it is a case of one in, all in'. Apart from the exceptions that Senator Missen has given, if honourable senators generally can read their speeches then everyone will do it because, first, it is the only way they are going to be reported correctly and, secondly, it becomes a superior way or gives people an edge in terms of circulating their points of view because others do not have to find the page in Hansard to read what they said.

It is unfortunate but it is true. Human nature is weak, which brings me to the issue of the motion and the issue of Senator Robertson's amendment. I am going to vote against the amendment and for the motion. I want to say to Senator Robertson that there is nothing inconsistent between Senator Missen's motion and what Senator Robertson would like to achieve. Aspersions have been cast on whether this should be regarded as a genuine motion because it seems somehow to be at variance with the Standing Orders. In fact Presidents and honourable senators who have been in the chair have ruled in relation to points of order being raised under Standing Order 406, or, alternatively the Senate has allowed a certain practice to develop here. A practice we have allowed to develop is that Ministers read their second reading speeches and that a shadow Minister may read a response--

TALK.START.PARA: —But in summing up Ministers speak extemporaneously.

—I will finish dealing with those who read speeches. Honourable senators who are presenting reports and tabling statements on behalf of a committee and in the case of some personal explanations we have accepted that it is reasonable to allow speeches to be read, for very good reasons. We have never accepted that it is reasonable to allow other speeches to be read. Senator Robertson's objective could indeed be achieved by his moving, subsequent to a vote on Senator Missen's motion, a motion that the Standing Orders be looked at to see whether they should be redrafted specifically as Senator Missen's motion would have the Senate behave, which is a summary of how the Senate does behave.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that through practice the Senate has allowed this situation to exist under Standing Order 406. Senator Missen, by drawing attention to the non- enforcement of Standing Order 406 was not aiming at these sorts of conditions which the Senate has accepted as reasonable practices. Senator Missen was saying that apart from those instances, however, the debate in this chamber has been downgraded by what has become a virtual ignoring of Standing Order 406. Senator Gietzelt put a case that Standing Order 406 should go. I am sure there are other honourable senators who agree with him. If the amendment moved by Senator Robertson is not successful-I hope it is not successful for a reason I will outline in a moment-and if he were to move his amendment as a motion some time in the future then I think the Senate probably would happily send that to the Standing Orders Committee to allow his point of view to be considered, to allow Senator Gietzelt's point of view to be considered and to allow a whole lot of other points of view that have been canvassed here this afternoon to be considered.

I am saying to the Senate that there is no conflict in that sense. However, I think it is important that since the amendment has been moved as such it should be defeated. The effect of not defeating it would be this: A situation has evolved here, to which no one has taken exception except for the occasional raising of Standing Order 406, of many honourable senators reading their speeches under circumstances which one would not consider to be acceptable. If Senator Robertson's amendment is carried all we are going to do is send the issue raised by Senator Missen to the Standing Orders Committee. We all know that we do not get speedy results from the Standing Orders Committee. It could well be, on experience, up to 12 months before we hear--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, longer.

—I am sorry; I was being too charitable. Senator Robert Ray points out that it could be longer than that. For instance, it could well be 12 months before the Committee reported to the Senate. The effect of that would be that the Chair would have to consider that the Senate had rejected what Senator Missen wanted us to do and that the Senate did not want this ruling. Senator Robertson shakes his head but that would be the effect because if we pass his amendment we then delete an instruction to the Presiding Officer that this Standing Order be enforced in a particular way. I reiterate what Odgers said: In the absence of that resolution the President's rulings will stand.

SPEECH.PARA: I mean no offence to the incumbent of the chair but in recent months some extraordinary situations have arisen in this chamber in relation to the reading of speeches. There was an occasion when a number of honourable senators raised points of order against an honourable senator for blatant reading of a speech. The reason it was raised was that he was mispronouncing words in the speech. Under those circumstances, one could reasonably conclude that he did not write the speech, that they were not his words. That is offensive. That particular honourable senator came in here and read somebody's speech, presenting it as his own ideas and expected us to debate seriously what he was putting forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers do it.

—The Minister is bound utterly by what is in that speech. The Government is bound utterly by what the Ministers have in their second reading speeches. There is a very good reason for second reading speeches being read. I point out that in reply Ministers do not read their speeches. The second reading speech is written and it is incorporated.
—They get a whole lot of notes handed to them by the advisers.

—We are all allowed to use notes as a prompt to our memory. That is different from what Senator McLaren is suggesting. He is suggesting that Ministers in the second reading of a Bill are taking advantage of a situation where they are putting someone else's ideas into the Hansard record under their own name. Ministers, the Government and the Cabinet are bound by what appears in second reading speeches. It is a useful device that second reading speeches from Ministers are written because that gives to us, as honourable senators, a good explanation of the technicalities of the Bill and what is the intention of the Bill. I reiterate that in reply, which is the debating part of a Minister's role in the second reading debate, Ministers do not read their speeches. They debate from notes given.
—When the second speech is incorporated-

—Senator McLaren has had his turn and he does go on forever. There are certain things that I would like to say to do justice to Senator Missen's case. One of the things I would like to do is quote from Odgers's Australian Senate Practice because I think it is something the Senate should be taking into consideration in its deliberation on this important issue. On the subject of reading speeches and quotations, Odgers states:

SPEECH.PARA: While holding that it is not in order for a Senator to read his speech without leave of the Senate, President Brown ruled that copious notes may be referred to .
It is that initial ruling that is responsible for our being able to use copious notes when they are genuinely copious notes. Odgers continues:
On 21 August 1969 . . . President Sir Alister McMullin ruled:
Senate practice is to allow a Minister to read his second reading speech. But it is recognised that, where an honourable senator is dealing with an intricate matter and where he wishes to be-

I really do not want to sound too school-masterly but Senator Crichton-Browne, who is a relatively new senator was lecturing us earlier on what the practice of the Senate is or ought to be but now he does not want to hear--

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I will listen to anything you say that is intelligent.

—I am reading Odgers. Nothing could be more intelligent on the subject than that. I was quoting from the Australian Senate Practice and what Sir Alister McMullin, a former President of the Senate, who ruled:

SPEECH.PARA: Senate practice is to allow a Minister to read his second reading speech. But it is recognised that, when an honourable senator is dealing with an intricate matter and where he wishes to be quite sure of his facts and wishes to pay reasonable attention to the subject, he may use what can be referred to as copious notes.

That is the basis on which the use of copious notes is supposed to apply. I referred earlier to an example of an honourable senator clearly reading a speech prepared by someone else. The person in the chair ruled that the honourable senator concerned was reading from copious notes. That led to a situation in which the senator in question was asked to table the copious notes. It turned out to be a written speech. That was clear to the Senate. Further on this subject, Odgers states:

On 10 March 1943, the Standing Orders Committee considered the application of S .O. 406 dealing with the reading of speeches in the Senate, and the Committee decided that it was not advisable to amend the standing order, but agreed that if a senator desired, for special reasons, to read his speech, he should be able to do so by leave (i.e. unanimous leave) of the Senate. The President ruled accordingly.

Senator Crichton-Browne saw fit to draw me up when I suggested that leave could be used while he was speaking. He made the assertion that it is hardly ever granted, I wish to point out that that is not so. Only last Thursday night I was given leave to read a statement to the Senate. Odgers continues:
When this standing order was considered and adopted in 1903 the Chairman of Committees . . . stated that the true reason for the existence-

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty years ago.
—The reason that I am about to give is just as valid today, and relates to what Senator Gietzelt was saying. I repeat:

SPEECH.PARA: When this standing order was considered and adopted in 1903, the Chairman of Committees (Senator Best) stated that the true reason for the existence of the standing order was that the Senate should have some guarantee that the speech delivered by an honourable Senator had been prepared by himself. The President ( Senator Sir Richard Baker), speaking in Committee, related the following anecdote in support of the standing order:

In America, at one time, Congress had no such standing order as this. The consequence was that there grew up in Washington a class of gentlemen who lived by writing speeches for members of both Houses. While this practice prevailed, a practical joker, who had been offended in some way, wrote the same speech for no less than three honourable Senators, who delivered or attempted to deliver it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had that happen here.

—I would like the honourable senator to point it out. That was a little bit of entertainment on which I missed out. There is the risk that people will present as their own ideas the ideas of someone else. I wish to refer briefly to some of the arguments used. Senator Martyr said that Standing Order 406 was an absolute prohibition on the reading of speeches. In fact, Odgers points out that the Senate has allowed some relaxation of that in very particular ways. Senator Missen's motion merely seeks to reaffirm a relaxation that has been allowed through practice of the Senate, one which, as Odgers points out, has as a result of rulings of the President the force of a resolution of the Senate itself. In the same context, Senator Sibraa said that the Standing Order had fallen into complete disrepute. I refer him also to Odgers and say that the Standing Order has not fallen into disrepute. Reasonable practices-the practices outlined in Senator Missen's motion-have evolved in this place and become part of the practice of the Senate. They could become part of the Standing Order, if Senator Robertson chose to move a motion to that effect after Senator Missen's motion had been dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, people have strong feelings about whether speeches should or should not be read. We all have our views. I would not want it suggested that those who have voted in the past, as I have, for the retention of Standing Order 406-the retention of the practice of not reading speeches-are in any way inconsiderate or heartless in regard to their colleagues. We have had some excellent speeches in the debate this afternoon. It has been one of the most entertaining debates that I can recall. None of those speeches has been read. Certain quotations have been made but the speeches have not been read. Senator Bonner gave an outstanding speech, albeit an impassioned plea, for being able to read his speech-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not mine, actually; I was not asking that I be allowed to read my own speeches.

—I beg the honourable senator's pardon-he was referring to being able to read speeches. He said that we need to show consideration for those who cannot do it off the top of their heads. I do not believe that is true of any senator. We have seen all honourable senators speak one way or another, be it in committee, during second reading debates, the Committee of the Whole or Estimates committees. All senators are capable of doing so; there can be no question that they cannot. They should not be here if they cannot. The purpose of debate is to present an argument. The purpose of sitting and listening to a debate is to analyse the validity of that argument, to understand it and, through understanding it, to be able to communicate a contrary point of view in reply. If we are not capable of that, we should not be here. Senator Crichton- Browne made some rather unkind references in this context to Senator Missen and suggested that the reason he is in the Senate is that he was a debater of some note in Victoria.
—No. I didn't say-
—The honourable senator should not be so touchy. I am trying to do him justice.
—You have got it wrong.
—I will try again. He said that one of the reasons Senator Missen obtained pre-selection was that he is a good public speaker.
—I did not say that, either. I said that it might be because of his power of persuasion; through use of the oral word, he may have convinced them. Perhaps that was part of the reason he was endorsed.

—The honourable senator has expressed it much better than I have it in my notes. Now that we have it straight, I say that I am sure there are many reasons why Senator Missen was selected, and continues to be selected by the Liberal Party to run for the Senate in Victoria. But there is one thing of which I am quite sure: When Senator Crichton-Browne presented himself to a pre- selection council in Western Australia he would not have read his speech. I have attended a large number of pre-selection councils of the Liberal Party. I have yet to see anyone who read his speech endorsed in a contest of any merit. Of course, it was also Senator Crichton-Browne who said that we come into the Senate with a fixed idea and the debate is really not persuasive. On that point I conclude by saying that debate in this place is persuasive and important. We ought to be able to give our own points of view. If we cannot, if we are giving a point of view that is someone else's and presenting it as our own, we have no business being in this chamber.
—Nonsense!

—That is a possibility, Senator. Therefore, on behalf of Senator Missen I indicate that I believe the amendment should be defeated. However, if Senator Robertson were to raise as a separate issue his suggestion to refer this matter to the Standing Orders Committee, I am sure that the Senate would acquiesce. Nevertheless, I hope the Senate will accept that we ought to indicate to the Presiding Officers and those who occupy the chair from time to time that the Senate expects that its Standing Order and a practice that it has accepted through trial in the past, and which has worked so very well, will be re- endorsed and enforced in full.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your ruling as to whether, if the motion put by Senator Missen is defeated, it amounts to an expunging of Standing Order 406.
—No, Standing Order 406 stands until the Senate changes it.
—It amounts to an indication to the President that we do not want Standing Order 406 enforced in the way in which it has been.
—I rule that until the Senate changes Standing Order 406 it remains in force and will be enforced at the discretion of the President in the way in which it has been traditionally.

—I have a question on which I seek clarification. Will the Chair allow those honourable senators who already are able to read speeches to take part in this division or will only those who would be deprived of reading speeches vote?
—All honourable senators may take part in the division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'Standing Order 406 be deleted'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second that amendment.

—This amendment is, of course, the precise opposite of the motion proposed by Senator Missen. I want honourable senators to comprehend that. What concerns me is that I do not believe this is the appropriate way by which the Senate should change the Standing Orders in a significant way. I do not believe this is the appropriate way to delete a Standing Order. I believe, at the very least, that if honourable senators wish to delete Standing Order 406 they should proceed by giving notice to the Senate of their intention so to do, or should follow the course of action suggested by Senator Martin a few moments ago and take the opportunity later to have the question referred to the Standing Orders Committee. We voted against Senator Robertson's motion because to have agreed to it would have prevented Senator Missen's motion being put to a vote. We want Senator Missen's motion to be put. I believe it would be very unfortunate if we proceeded now to strike out a Standing Order, as it were, on the run. If Senator Gietzelt wants the Senate seriously to give consideration to the abolition of Standing Order 406, that is fine, but I suggest to him that this is not the most appropriate way by which that should be done. I would invite him to do it either by giving notice for consideration at a later date or preferably by a separate reference to the Standing Orders Committee after this debate has concluded.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I know that the Senate is governed essentially by the Standing Orders but surely where the Standing Orders are silent on a subject the rules of debate apply. I do not know of any discussion between human beings that is regularised in any way where a direct negative is received by the Chair to a motion that is put.
—It is not a direct negative.
—It is a direct negative.
—I will rule on this when Senator Chipp has completed taking his point of order.

—I normally respect Senator Tate's interjections but to say that Senator Gietzelt's proposed amendment is not a direct negative of the original proposition put by Senator Missen is one of the most remarkable points of view I have ever heard him express. I would have thought that not only is it a direct negative which flies in the face of all the rules of debate accepted by civilised people, but also it would be grossly unfair to a senator such as Senator Missen who should at least be paid the courtesy of having his motion voted on by the Senate and not summarily dismissed by a direct negative of an amendment such as that proposed.

—I have had to give consideration to whether Senator Gietzelt's proposed amendment is a direct negative. As the direct negative is defined, it is not so, the reason being that the direct negative is one where the same effect could be achieved by voting against the motion. In this case that is not so. Senator Gietzelt has moved both an amendment in regard to Senator Missen's motion and also a supplementary amendment amending Standing Orders. I should draw it to the attention of the Senate that although this is in order, it is a very unusual way of amending Standing Orders. The Senate should think very carefully about whether it wishes to amend Standing Orders in this somewhat cavalier fashion. Nevertheless, the amendment is in order.

—I suggest that we decide whether we should divide this matter into two parts and, firstly, consider and decide on Senator Missen's motion and then, secondly, proceed to Senator Gietzelt's amendment, because they are different. It is up to the Senate to distinguish between the two. It should be done on a progressive basis because some honourable senators might like to go half-way.
—That is not a practical procedure, Senator Watson. We have to deal with the amendment before the motion, so it cannot be done that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McLAREN
TALKER.TIME.STAMP: (5.53-As the seconder of Senator Gietzelt's amendment I wish to speak briefly to it. I do not accept the argument put forward by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume)

TALK.START.PARA: , who has now left the chamber-
—Careful, Senator.

—I am sorry; the Minister is not in his place. He is one of the people in this place who, if the motion of Senator Missen is carried, will still be able to read his speeches. But, as I said earlier, members of the back bench will not be able to do that. If the motion as moved by Senator Missen is carried and Senator Gietzelt's amendment is defeated, it will mean that we will revert to the status quo except that the onus will be put upon the Chair to be very eagle-eyed all the time and to be watching every person.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable senators have their own little habits when reading speeches. I have noticed that some run a finger along every line; we can sit here and see it . As Senator Martin mentioned, others read speeches which are not their own. That is evidenced by the fact that they cannot pronounce the words. If the motion is carried these people will be in further trouble and the place will revert to absolute chaos because if Senator Missen's motion is carried I will be one of those who will insist that it is applied to the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —To everyone.

—To everyone. That will mean that no leave will be given to Ministers to incorporate speeches and we will have a great lot of fun in this place. Senator Gietzelt's amendment overcomes all of that and if honourable senators make a mistake when reading their speeches they will have to live with it. If they cannot read a speech or pronounce the words which somebody has written for them, too bad; they will have to cop it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt's amendment ought to be carried. It is quite stupid for it to be said that we ought to vote upon Senator Missen's motion, then put the amendment of Senator Gietzelt in the form of a motion to do the very thing to which the Senate has been asked to agree-that is, to enforce Standing Order 406- and then in the next breath ask the Senate to direct that it be deleted from the Standing Orders. In my view the amendment is a good amendment which will overcome many of the problems which we now face in this place. It saves the problems which we would face if Senator Missen's motion were carried. I therefore ask the Senate to agree to the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Gietzelt's amendment because it summarises the feeling of all of those who want to put a point of view and want it to go over accurately. Honourable senators who cannot articulate like Senator Missen or Senator Martin ought to have the chance to be able to tell the Senate accurately how they feel about various matters. I do not see why those of us who are capable of delivering a speech on the mussels under the Port Melbourne pier at no notice whatsoever should have an advantage over those whose thoughts are equally profound but who may have difficulty in articulating them while on their feet.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter was well settled in the House of Representatives a long time ago. I do not see that there should be any difference in the way we conduct our business here. I repeat that some of the ideas of Senator Martin and particularly of Senator Missen are starry-eyed when compared to the reality of debate in this chamber. I am saying this mainly for the benefit of those Australian Democrat senators who have just arrived in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hey!

—I am sorry; Senator Haines has been here. I am after her rather large colleague. I would like him to vote for Senator Gietzelt's amendment. That is why I am saying this. I saw somebody else trying to convince him that we were wrong. It is important for the Senate to accept Senator Gietzelt's amendment because it will eliminate the sort of drivel that has been going on in this chamber since I have been a senator. When honourable senators have a bit of a pet on, they tend to say that somebody is reading his speech, and then there is a great argument and row about it. If people want to read their speeches, let them do it. We are getting their thoughts. I entirely disagree with what was said by Senator Martin. She implied that all of our thoughts are entirely our own. We are influenced by everything that happens in here, by what happens outside and by what we read in the newspapers. Our minds are composites of everything that affects us, which touches and rubs off on us. That is what we articulate in the Senate. If there are views and thoughts in a research officer' s suggestions or even a speech, we make up our own minds as to whether we use them or not. Once we express them in here they are ours, no one else's. Senator Martin's suggestion that honourable senators deliver speeches that are entirely the thoughts of others is quite incorrect. Everybody in this chamber knows it.
—I did not suggest that in relation to you, Senator.

—I think the honourable senator treats unfairly those people who bring in suggestions. The important thing is that if any one of us brings a speech in here and articulates that speech, it becomes ours even though suggestions can be made about where it came from. In reference to something said before, what was wrong with Mr Santamaria's thoughts being articulated by Senator Kane? There was nothing wrong with it? They were good thoughts. I am quite prepared to listen to what any honourable senators on the other side have to say. They are their speeches as far as I am concerned, not those of anybody from outside. I think Senator Gietzelt's amendment ought to be supported.

—I do not want to rehash the merits or otherwise of Senator Gietzelt's amendment but I think it is grossly improper that under such circumstances the Senate should consider voting upon a motion to delete a Standing Order. Bearing in mind particularly Standing Order 448-under which the suspension of Standing Orders requires an absolute majority-and Standing Orders 449 and 450, it seems very odd indeed that we can now delete a Standing Order without giving notice of motion that that is proposed, and by simple majority. Regardless of the merits of the matter, it is a quite improper way of going about changing Standing Orders.
—Senator Macklin and Senator Baume have summed up the matter on which I wanted to comment.
—Good. Then sit down and shut up.

—Before I do sit down and shut up, as my colleague Senator Chaney advises me, I just want to say that it would be foolish of this chamber to adopt Senator Gietzelt's amendment, because I believe that we would be transgressing good procedures in handling Standing Orders in this place. The negativing of Senator Gietzelt's amendment will allow us then properly to divide upon Senator Missen's original motion. There have already been more than a dozen speeches about it. There are views for and against Senator Missen's original proposition. I believe that is the matter on which we should properly divide. I appeal to honourable senators to reject thoroughly Senator Gietzelt's amendment.

—I do not know why there is haste for a division on this important motion and, in fact, more important amendment. I have some views on the matter. I shall use the age old practice of recalling experience. It is a Chinese term. I know that honourable senators are a little confused about what I am saying, but I am going to draw upon my experience and offer the Senate some advice. My advice is that if honourable senators want this place to deteriorate into a duller chamber than it is at present, by all means delete Standing Order 406.
—It is not possible.
—It is dull enough to listen to a speech that Senator Chaney reads. He is a better reader than most, but some cannot read.
—They can have speeches incorporated.
—That is a device that we have been using in this place in order to save time.
—We should all incorporate our speeches in Hansard all the time.

—That would be a good idea. I could walk in here and say: 'I have a speech prepared and I should like to save the time of the Senate. It will read better in Hansard. No one here is really very interested in it. May I incorporate this speech?' By taking it to that sublime-ridiculous position, that proves my point.
—Post it.

—I could post it from Brisbane. I could vote by telephone. I could incorporate my speeches. All right; that is taking it to the ridiculous; but in a way that is the end of the process that is being initiated now. I would hate to hear Senator Tate read a prepared speech. I do not think that he would do it because his capacity to deliver a speech effectively, based on certain notes he has in his hand, makes his speeches worthwhile listening to. Similarly, that applies to many people in this place, although the number of such people is becoming fewer and fewer. Whatever the talent with which a person comes into this place-I put a question mark over the word 'talent'-if we allow this practice to develop we will fall for the very easy trap of having our research people prepare the material, and we shall just read it. We shall pick it up while racing on our way in here, saying: 'How many pages is it?', and so on--
—Speak for yourself.
—That is the abuse that is likely to occur.
—It is occurring now under the Standing Orders. The Senate can do it now.

—Yes, but let us take a look at that. That is no reason why the whole Senate should be able to do it. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is a better speaker in this place now than she was on the first day she came here and attempted to read a speech. This place is more than a reporting shop. It is a forum. Sometimes it might not live up to the electorate's expectations. After all, though, it is a town moot. I suggest that the best idea would be to-

—No, but that would be opening the way to a practice under which all honourable senators would read their speeches, and that is what I am trying to avoid. I suggest that if there is a problem, we ought to look at some way of limiting the abuse that has crept into our procedures. Admittedly we have now another shadow executive on this side of the chamber. The Democrats have a shadow executive, and we really have three now-a ministry and two executives. That is something that may be just a temporary aberration. I have a view that the Democrats have passed their peak of attraction to the electorate, and I feel that they will begin to disintegrate and that some will go to the other side and an odd one might stay on this side. —Let us have the vote and get on with it.

—Senator McLaren is eager to get to the vote. How many times has Senator McLaren spoken at length in order to prevent the vote? I know what he is trying to accuse me of now-trying to talk out time-but I am not prepared to do that. I just could not do that.
—I want to raise issues on other subjects, so let us get on with this nonsense.

—If that is so, I make just one more point. There is a real problem in dealing with the Standing Orders in the way in which we deal with them. Firstly, we send them to the Standing Orders Committee. My view is that we have a rather half-hearted, half-baked, limited discussion on the Standing Orders Committee, a recommendation comes in here, and bang, we change the Standing Orders, and the sitting hours, sometimes to our regret.
—How right you are.
—Hooray! I have Senator McLaren's support again. This is too important a matter to be so dealt with. I am not to have--
—If you had been in the House when the matter was first debated , you would have had an opportunity to do that. You came in at the end of it.
—I had other responsibilities and the honourable senator knows what other responsibilities entail in this place. There was a Public Accounts Committee meeting and some other meeting, and so it went.
—Order!
—Mr President, are you endeavouring to deny me the right to debate even at this late stage this very important matter?
—The Chair is not denying it, Senator. Carry on.
—The Left are like that.
—I have got myself in enough trouble today without getting into any further trouble.
—You have squared yourself off with Florence. That is an important plus. You did very well there.

—I had forgotten the honourable senator was present. I might have tried to pick her up in a debate. But Senator Missen's motion is lacking in that it does not accept the reality that there is a shadow ministry in this place and he does not include shadow ministers. However, in order to deal with Senator Missen's proposition, I think it too far to go to accept Senator Gietzelt's amendment. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I think there is a little bit of confusion about whether we have amendments or motions before us. As I understand it, we have defeated the amendment moved by Senator Robertson and we now have another amendment before us.

I suggest that Senator Gietzelt ought to withdraw his amendment, and, at some subsequent time, go through the motions that we are all expected to go through if we want to vary the procedures of the Senate, that is, give notice of the motion and move it.
