SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not speak at length when I initially raised this matter. I rather hoped that by being brief perhaps we might have got on with the subject set down for today, which is fairly important . We have had a fair range of debate today. It seems that the precept I put forward is just as effective as most precepts and examples. Nobody took any notice of it whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very difficult here to speak against a colleague, but I would have to speak against Sentor Gietzelt on this occasion. I am encouraged a little by the fact that Senator Georges has done so. I hope the Press has not noticed this and there is not any sort of flurry in the newspapers tomorrow. But if he can do it, then so can I. I support what has been said around the chamber, that it is most unwise to change Standing Orders on the run. I am not very encouraged by the fact that in 1903 certain decisions were made and we have looked at them ever since. I am sure that we ought to be giving this matter a lot more serious consideration than some honourable senators are giving it at the moment. I will heed the advice of the Acting Deputy President who was sitting in your place at the time, Sir, and who cautioned us that changing Standing Orders on the run is a very dangerous proposition. At present we have the extraordinary situation before us that if we accept the Missen proposition and vote for it, virtually the status quo will remain. If we reject the Missen proposition, the status quo will remain also, because that is what we are doing at present. I cannot see any great changes there. Odgers said-and I rasied this in my initial discussions- that the Standing Order says that no senator shall read his speech. Senator Martin has quoted Odgers, who is perhaps not as well accepted on some sides of the chamber as others, to say that certain practices have been established, therefore it is all right if we carry on like this.

May I make the point that the committee system is effective. It is one of the things that we ought to be proud of in the Senate. The many committees of the Senate operate very effectively and I am suggesting that the Standing Orders Committee operates just as effectively. I reject the proposition made by Senator Martin that we might get something back in 12 months. We are speaking of the Standing Orders Committee that is operating at the present time and I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there have been a number of innovations in the last 12 months. They have not been completely accepted. We have had two people speak this afternoon at some length on how they do not accept certain of the propositions that have been put forward by the Standing Orders Commitee. But it cannot be said that the Standing Orders Committee has not been working and has not brought forward some suggestions for the better running of the Senate. We made the point when we brought forward a suggestion about the change in times that they had existed for quite a long time and they related back to a British system which did not seem appropriate. It is nonsense to talk about there being the right hours for the Senate to sit. We set our own hours and we operate under them. If we find that they are not effective then, of course, because it was a sessional order, we will try something else. That may well be a reversal of what we did before. I mention that only in passing in order to show that the Committee has been effective.

I had rather hoped, when I moved the original amendment that we would see the need to refer back to the Standing Orders Committee something which is very important. I would have thought that the normal way to operate would be to raise something as a reference to a committee and then ask that committee to look at it. The same practice applies with the Standing Orders Committee as with any other committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —They knocked that over.

—That is right. As my colleague says, they knocked that over. I do not quite know why, because we have had recommendations of the Standing Orders Committee presented here and the standard practice seems to be to refer matters back all the time. Here is something which came out of the blue and yet that is not to be referred to the appropriate committee for discussion. We have put forward propositions before in reaction to what people have said and they have been sent back to be looked at again after debate. But here we have something which, with due respect, has been plucked out of the air and brought to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us remember that the Missen suggestion was that we 'instruct'-and I dislike that word-the President to do certain things, to take notice of certain Standing Orders. I do not believe that that is the way it ought to operate. I believe we ought to look at a Standing Order if it is not appearing to be effective and ask the Committee to say why it is not effective, why it is not working in the way that it was meant to work. Then the Standing Orders Committee, which is composed , as Senator Georges indicated earlier, of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition, the Whips and other people who have a particular interest in this subject, can give it quite a deal of time and consideration. I would suggest that the consideration which is given to the proposition that has come forward be given in a slightly less emotive atmosphere than that which has prevailed this afternoon.

I am encouraged by Senator Martin's comments that if, in light of the rejection of my amendment, I come back later with a proposition that this matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee, it will receive support. I suggest that we reject that proposition. It does not matter whether we reject or accept the Missen proposition because the status quo will remain. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report 'Preparation for the Workforce': Government Response-Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not having copious notes. I hope that I might be able to make do with the few that I have. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts brought down the report entitled ' Preparation for the Workforce' quite some time ago. Unfortunately, due to a series of events, we have been unable to have a general debate on this subject. The next major event, after the tabling of this report, was the Government's reply to it. As I remember, it was almost a year ago-at the beginning of the Budget session last year-that that report was tabled.
—June.

—It was tabled in June. At that time I thought it was a relatively poor report, and upon reading it again, as well as the Government's reply, that opinion has been confirmed. That is a pity because the subject matter of the report on preparation for the workforce is probably one of the most vital educational issues that faces this country today. It seems to me to be a pity that the chance was lost at that time to have a thorough, in-depth and hard hitting report instead of the one we received. I think, as a consequence, the ministerial statement-the Government's response to the report-also failed to find much meat in the report. The responses tended to be along the lines of, ' This is a good idea' or 'This is a good idea and it is a matter for the States to look at'.

SPEECH.PARA: The education area is extremely important and it is one in which this Parliament has a constitutional role. The States, quite rightly under the Constitution, have control of education, but education cannot be divorced from the total direction of the nation. Therefore, I think this Parliament has a role , not so much in the nitty-gritty, not in the running of schools-except in the Australian Capital Territory-but rather in a much wider sense of giving a broad national plan where education fits in with the other important national considerations. It is not possible for individual States to undertake that role. They have their own specific responsibilities and rarely, if ever, are able to give consideration to that totality of direction that is needed.

It is therefore with increasing disappointment that I realise that the Government has failed in many areas to grasp the types of advances that have been made in the past. The last time I spoke on the subject of education was in relation to the Curriculum Development Centre, which I thought was an extremely worthwhile and important educational innovation in this country from the point of view of a national look at that vital issue in terms of where we are going as a country. Without some type of national plan, some forethought or some reaching into the future, we will end up with a hotch-potch of educational responses to the problems that constantly arise. In its report the Committee emphasised that aspect. I believe that part of the report focussed directly on the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting a unitary response, Senator?

—No, I am not suggesting a unitary response. What I am suggesting is that the Commonwealth Government, in terms of its economic planning, its industrial planning for new industries and in terms of how it views the problem of finding work for its citizens into the year 2000, must pay attention to the educational development of those citizens. It is not constitutionally proper for this Government to be conerned with the nitty-gritty . I believe quite firmly that the devolution and dispersa of that type of power is to the advantage of education. I am talking about the vision that is necessary at a national level to provide the broad scope, the forward thinking plans, such as were provided with the Curriculum Development Centre. In the short time that that Centre was in operation it gained an international reputation for its work. I think educationalists overseas were shocked and dismayed when they heard it was to be disbanded. Apart from giving that broad national response, the Curriculum Development Centre was probably one of the first attempts by the Commonwealth and the States to work together. The unfortunate part about it was that the Commonwealth gave an ultimatum concerning finances which were really quite peripheral to the whole issue. The States did not pick it up. That only reinforces the point that I have been making; the States do have a much more parochial view of education. That is not a criticism of them. I am merely saying that that is their area of legitimate concern. But the area of legitimate concern for the Commonwealth Government is much broader.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the report which, on page 13, mentions the class size. Unfortunately it is clear that time has rapidly caught up with the Committee's work, because the report states;
The Committee is not aware of any significant research findings in Australia that would lead to any firm conclusions on what optimal size classes should be.

It then refers to Professor Glass's work which was really only a reworking of the findings of a large number of individual research projects. Of course, since that time Professor Campbell of the University of Queensland has done some excellent pathfinding work in this regard. He has put up, I believe, conclusive evidence on class size in relation to educational outcomes. I believe he has been able to show quite conclusively that the gut feeling, as it were, that teachers have always had about class sizes can be empirically verified, and that I believe is extremely important work. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) in his ministerial statement said:
. . . the Commonwealth accepts the merit of the objective that class sizes be as small as practicable for teaching and learning, consistent with available resources . . .

Here, unfortunately, we get back to the interaction between the Commonwealth's overall role in national planning and its financial obligations. Here again I believe that, as we can see by looking at the grants given by the Commonwealth to the States over the last four or five years, the actual diminution in the amounts going to the States has made it extremely difficult for the States to pursue what might be now regarded by all unbiased commentators as legitimate concerns for reduced class sizes-not only legitimate but absolutely necessary-if we are to get any advance in the more complicated and complex areas that are being addressed at the school level.
I turn now to what I believe is one of the most unfortunate elements in the report, and I am not necessarily being critical of the Committee. The Committee points out:

Apart from the occasional reference by a witness to some educational problem that was thought to warrant research attention, the role of educational research and development did not emerge as a significant issue in the inquiry.
I think that is a most extraordinary admission. However, as I say, it may not be a criticism of the Committee itself; it may be more a criticism of the educational community.

I find it very hard to believe that witnesses of the calibre of those who appeared before the Committee would not have had an enormous concern for educational research and development. The list of witnesses who appeared before the Committee reads like a Who's Who of educational research. All I can conclude , therefore, is that in the hearings of the Committee this aspect did not exercise the minds of the members of the Committee overmuch and therefore perhaps they failed to draw out from those expert witnesses detailed information and comments on that central issue of educational research. If we are to do anything constructive and useful for preparation for the work force, we must not simply do what is often done in a State where, for instance, if a lot of advertisements appear in the newspapers for shorthand typists they rush into a course in shorthand typing. That type of reactive response is not what is needed in terms of a national plan.
If the Committee was somewhat dilatory in its obligations in relation to this, I would point now to the Minister's response to the following recommendation:
Priority for educational research should be directed towards solving practical problems and findings translated into statements for policy development . . .
The Minister in his response stated:

The Commonwealth accepts this recommendation and will continue to encourage the co-ordination of research through the Australian Education Council, and meetings of State and Commonwealth education researchers.

Frankly, that is being a little devious. This Government has been responsible for the destruction of the co-ordinating body for educational research and development in this country-the Education Research and Development Committee. This was the Committee empowered actually to bring some co-ordinating function to that very real and difficult problem.

Honourable senators, except for those who have personal experience of putting in an application for funding to the Education Research Development Committee, may not be aware of the type of information that the Committee required. The Committee required that information specifically so that it could fulfil its charter of co-ordination. It often turned down research on worthwhile educational projects on the basis that this work was being adequately carried out in other educational institutions in other States and that the normal dissemination of that information through educational journals and conferences would be sufficient in that area. It thus advised the researcher to direct his attention to other matters. In addition, the Education Research and Development Committee at the beginning of every year put out a list of what it felt might be some of the major areas which were being under-studied or under-researched and some of the areas to which researchers in various institutions might direct their attention.

It seems to me that it is not possible for the Government to say: 'The Commonwealth accepts this recommendation and will continue to encourage the co- ordination of research through the Australian Education Council', because the Australian Education Council is a totally ineffective body in relation to educational research. It consists of education Ministers. With all due respect to the Federal Minister for Education, who I believe probably does know a fair amount about education, many of the education Ministers may follow in the tradition of the first Federal Minister for Education in this country, who could not read or write. Those education Ministers may not be intimately aware of matters of educational research and development and that is not a criticism of them. It is not possible for a person to enter into a portfolio as a Minister and gain that type of intimate acquaintance with a research area, which after all involves a person in a great deal of time, study and effort in his chosen profession.

Surely the Australian Education Council is a policy development body, not a body to look at the co-ordination of research. It does not have that capacity. Even if one wants to draw into that Education Council the advisers that all the Ministers bring with them-that is generally their director-generals of education -those people are also not the most capable people to be carrying out this task. If they were, presumably directors of research and development would not be employed within their departments. Surely the body which had been established and which worked most effectively for years was the best body to continue. Unfortunately, the Government has felt it necessary to argue for its demise on the basis of an ill-informed and, I believe, ill-considered judgment of the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions-the so-called razor gang.

I believe that if we are to fulfil any of the types of things to which the Committee on Education and the Arts directed its attention-the very real problem of coming up with some type of reasonable transition programs, transitions which will not look specifically at the development of very narrow skills but will look also at the development of those broader capacities which will be necessary in the changing world in which we live-and if that type of far-sighted work is to be done in this country, unfortunately we need the development of a committee such as the Education Research and Development Committee. We need to put in place a new educational research and development committee. It does not matter what it is called as long as the function is taken over by an expert body.

The last point I wish to make concerns the developing technological revolution. Unfortunately, when one reviews the transition programs which have been put in place already around this country one is not given a great deal of satisfaction or confidence. The emphasis is often on one of two areas. Either it is to compromise the student and suggest that he may learn a whole range of skills which are not necessarily directed towards employment but will make that person happy in later life and better able to live with his unemployment, which I believe is a defeatist approach in a country such as ours, or else there is a tendency to focus very heavily on skill development, and low level skill development at that. Let us consider a very simple point, which I think makes telling the type of change that we are engaged in. Alvin Toffler published a book in 1970 called Future Shock which doubtless almost everybody has now read, at least in part.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least once.
—At least once. Future Shock was criticised.
—Every trendy worth his salt has read it.

—Yes. Future Shock was criticised for being terribly exaggerated when it was put out. I remember reviews saying: 'This is really taking the thing far too far'. If honourable senators care to go back and look at that book they will notice that nowhere in Future Shock are microprocessors mentioned-not even once-for the very good reason that they did not exist in 1970. That is the sort of advance that we have suffered. It is a staggering admission. When I recognised that I went back and had a look, and it is perfectly true-a most extraordinary thing when one considers the vital importance of microprocessors in the economy of today. I think that merely bears out that to set up short, narrow programs which look to next year or the year after is to be of such a defeatist, such a head-in-the-sand viewpoint as not to provide anything for our future generations. What we must be doing-what I hoped that the Senate Committee might have done, but unfortunately it did not; I am not sure for what reason-is to grasp this extremely difficult problem, to provide vision, to look ahead and to suggest really the level of funding, the level of opportunity and work that we need into the year 2000. That type of exciting report we could have looked towards not only now-a year later when this one has rather died and looks very saggy and dog-eared-but even in five years' time and said: 'Well' that at least was a breath of fresh air in this rather stodgy debate about transition from school to work'. I do not blame the Government for responding in the way that it did. It probably responded in as lively a fashion as it could to this report, but I reiterate my main point that the Government should look yet again at its co-ordination of research if we are to provide anything in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in June 1981 that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts brought to the Senate the report ' Preparation for the Workforce'. About a year later the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, in one of his first public statements on becoming Minister, brought down this statement as the Government's response to the Senate's report. The issue is: Are Australia's schools effective? Senator Macklin has said that this is a vital area of public policy in Australia. As a very active participant in the preparation of the original report, and as someone who has a continuing involvement in these education issues, I can only agree. Unfortunately the time has almost expired; only a few minutes remain for debate today. I understand the Minister wishes to introduce a Bill before we rise in a few minutes. My remarks will therefore be shortened and I hope to continue when this item comes up again .

SPEECH.PARA: The principal matter that I want to refer to is the undertaking by the Minister that he would bring this report formally and directly to the attention of State Ministers for education in the Australian Education Council, and to the non- government school authorities. I want to press that that be done, not only by circulating the report formally-this was done at the last AEC meeting in Alice Springs in June-but that the Ministers seek to have on the agenda for the next meeting of the AEC, which I understand could be in February of next year, comprehensive and formal reports on these continuing issues in secondary education so that the nation can see exhibited in a national way the responses to these calls that the Senate Committee has made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am willing to undertake to examine that to see whether I can accommodate you, Senator.
—I have other such requests that I would like to talk about when my speech is able to be continued. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 which prescribes charges payable in respect of the use by aircraft of aviation facilities and services provided, operated or maintained by the Commonwealth.
The Bill gives effect to the Government's decisions to vary the rates of air navigation charges for all domestic sectors of the aviation industry.

It was announced in the Budget Speech that air navigation charges were to increase by 20 per cent for both domestic trunk and regional airlines and by 12 per cent for general aviation aircraft. The Bill provides for the increased charges to apply from 1 October 1982.

Total revenue from air navigation charges in 1982-83 is estimated to amount to $119.3m, compared with $101.8m, from this source in 1981-82. Of the $17.5m increase, $7.1m is attributable to the payment early in 1982-83 of amounts payable in respect of 1981-82; the balance of $10.4m relates to the full effect of the 1981-82 variations to the charges, industry growth and increased revenue resulting from the increases in charges now proposed.
By themselves, the increased rates of charges for which this Bill provides are expected to yield additional revenue of $8.4m in 1982-83 and $12.5m in a full year.

Honourable senators will be aware that, since 1961, successive Governments have pursued a policy of eventual full recovery of costs properly attributable to the aviation industry for the provision and maintenance of the aviation infrastructure. The decisions taken by the Government to increase air navigation charges are in line with that policy. Overall cost recovery in 1982-83 is estimated (after adjustment for 1981-82 arrears) at about 53 per cent.

The 1981 Airlines Agreement formally recognises the Commonwealth's entitlement to recover 100 per cent of its costs. The 20 per cent increase in air navigation charges for domestic trunk airlines is expected to achieve a recovery rate approaching 90 per cent for this sector in 1982-83.
The increases in charges for regional airlines and general aviation are expected to lead to 1982-83 recovery rates from these sectors of some 25 per cent and 15 per cent respectively.

There has been considerable public comment about the possible effect on air fares of the proposed increases in air navigation charges. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, I believe in Sydney, Denis Byrne Horgan issued a statement in which he said that he was no longer the Perth Liberal Party bagman or chairman of its finance committee; that he had ceased to hold that position as from the end of June. I did not know that previously. I accept that as being correct and will in future refer to him as the past Liberal Party bagman. He also again denied any involvement in a tax avoidance scheme. He said that at the time he sold Treamog Ltd, no tax assessment had been issued. That, the record shows to be correct; it also evades the issue. It was usual; most of the companies detailed in the McCabe-Lafranchi reports are companies which had no tax assessment issued against them at the time the vendors sold the shares.

SPEECH.PARA: As was usual with the companies, Treamog, Denis Horgan's company, had a contingent liability for company taxation of $1.7m. That is the issue that Horgan has avoided. If Horgan wants to deny being a tax cheat, is he denying the facts as shown in Volume 2 of the McCabe-Lafranchi report regarding Treamog which mentions current year profits of $3.762m? Is Denis Horgan denying that the company he sold had current year profits of $3.762m, and therefore a company tax liability of almost $1.7m-a contingent tax liability? It did not have an assessment. It had a contingent liability. Is Denis Horgan denying that it had that contingent liability? Is he denying that no allowance was made in the price offered for the shares in the company for that contingent liability? If Denis Horgan wants to deny his involvement in a tax evasion scheme, let him deny those things.

At the time Treamog Ltd was sold-again my source is volume 2 of the McCabe- Lafranchi report-Treamog was fully liquid. It sold money. It had a contingent tax liability of about $1.7m and it had money amounting to just over $6.5m. It was sold for $6.181m. To simplify that, the shareholders received from the Maher agent the full value of the money that the company had, minus only $355,000, which was the agent's so-called commission. No allowance was made for the contingent tax liability. Even the National Country Party would have been able to see that there was something smelly about a deal like that where someone came along and bought a company which owned nothing but money and exchanged for the money it was buying almost an equal amount of money, knowing full well that the company had a contingent tax liability of $1.7m. Even the Country Party would know there is something wrong with that. Yet, this business tycoon asks us to believe that he did not know the deal was shonky. Horgan's denials-categorical denials as he calls them-are in fact generalised assertions. They are never specific-for a very good reason. When one looks at the specifics of the case Horgan is clearly convicted.

The statement that he issued and which was carried by Australian Associated Press is grossly misleading regarding the degree of his involvement in the Treamog share sale. He said that he was one of the seven directors. He was. He was also the chairman of directors. He did not tell us that. He said that he had paid tax on the profits earned by his 3 per cent shareholding in Treamog. Horgan in fact held directly less than 3 per cent of shares in Treamog. What he omitted from his statement was his indirect ownership of the company. Prindiville Holdings Pty Ltd, which owned 49 per cent of the shares in the company, has as its shareholders, Denis Horgan, one share, and Byrne Holdings, 299,999 shares. The directors of Byrne Holdings are Denis Horgan, Patricia Horgan and a fellow named Ingram. They own one share each. So, through his ownership of Prindiville Holdings Horgan owned another 16 per cent of Treamog. Patricia Horgan owned another 16 per cent. Rural Securities Pty Ltd, part of the Barrack House Group, controlled and primarily owned by Horgan, had a 6 per cent shareholding in Treamog. Henderson Investments Pty Ltd, a company of which Horgan is also a director, had a 10 per cent shareholding. Another major shareholder was Metro Industries Pty Ltd, a company in which Horgan, in turn, was a major shareholder. I am afraid that I do not have the details of Metro Industries in the office in Canberra.

When all those things are added up-I have incomplete records at my fingertips at the moment-Horgan owned 40 per cent of Treamog directly and indirectly, not the 3 per cent to which his statement of last night admitted. Horgan is not only a tax dodger; he is a liar as well. I note in passing-I will not go into this in detail because we all want to get away-that Horgan was a director and a shareholder of Henderson Investments. Henderson Investments also was sold to Maher and Donnelly in December 1977 and on-sold to Errol Faint in June 1978. I will not bother going into the details. I will save that ammunition for another day. Finally, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was questioned tonight on PM about the involvement of senior members of the Western Australian Liberal Party in tax evasion. He said:
I don't know what these allegations are. I never have and I don't want to.
If that is correct the Prime Minister is culpably negligent, convicted out of his own mouth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that for Senator Walsh to say that the Prime Minister is culpably negligent is beyond the Standing Orders. I have not been interfering in the honourable senator's speech.

—I withdraw. The Prime Minister is convicted out of his own mouth of gross negligence. The Prime Minister is saying that he does not know and does not care whether somebody who holds seven government sinecures, including the very important positions of directorship of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and commissioner of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, is a tax cheat. The Prime Minister has the audacity to say that he does not know and he does not care. I can imagine no more total abdication of responsibility of Prime Ministership or abdication of the maintenance of the standards of propriety about which, some years ago, we heard so much from the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
